PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 11.30 a.m ., and read prayers.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Sex Discrimination Legislation
To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully submit that:

Although many occurrences of sexual harassment in the workforce have been reported to various State government authorities, such as the Victorian Commission for Equal Opportunity, the real incidence of sexual intimidation in employment will not be known, or countered, until a national policy towards sexual harassment is determined and implemented.
We therefore submit that:

(1) The National Committee on Discrimination in Employment and Occupation be commissioned to conduct a nation-wide study of discrimination based on sex, both in the private sector and the Public Service, with a view to advising the Government on the development of national policy.
(2) The major priority of such a study should be to determine a legally- enforceable definition of sexual harassment.

(3) The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations should bring forward in Parliament legislation, arising from such a study, to outlaw discrimination and intimidation in employment based on sex.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The President, and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that 'The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State'. And whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1).
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women; Believing that its implementation would result in:
(1) Undue cost to the Nation at this time.

(2) 'The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in Article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our Nation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Peter Baume (from 147 citizens), Childs (from 24 citizens), Sibraa ( from 14 citizens) and Watson (from 82 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia, Believing that men and women are equal but different, Convinced that Australia can provide equal opportunity for all citizens without foreign treaties, Concerned that ratifying the UN Discrimination Convention would give a Communist dominated international commitee the power to judge Australia's laws, Humbly petition that your Honourable House will NOT support the UN Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women and we will always thus petition.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Boswell (from 7,061 citizens), Teague (from 522 citizens) and Walters (from 77 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Defence Service Home Loans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That all members of the Women's Services 1939-45 War qualify as 'Australian Soldier' under the Defence Service Homes Act for loans because on voluntarily joining the Australian Forces they took the oath to resist His Majesty's enemies making themselves available for combat duty in War Zones, and according to Acts and Regulations of the period the Military women had enlisted for service anywhere, some Naval women to sail in any waters, with all servicewomen available for service in Papua New Guinea.

As those members of the Royal Australian Navy, the Australian Imperial Force and the Royal Australian Air Force of 1939-45 War who were not sent to War Zones are granted loans, refusal to grant eligibility to all Ex-servicewomen of 1939- 45 War is unjust and unfair.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you amend the Defence Service Homes Act by repealing Sub-section 4 (2A) (b) (c) (d) of the Principal Act as amended by No. 137 of 1978, and grant eligibility to all members of the Women's Royal Australian Naval Service, the Australian Women's Army Service, the Women's Auxiliary Australian Air Force, the Australian Army Medical Women's Service, and the Voluntary Aid Detachment of 1939-45 War.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Bjelke-Petersen (from six citizens), Chaney (from 22 citizens) and Jack Evans (from four citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Defence Service Home Loans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the members of the Women's Services of the 1939-45 War not at present considered eligible for Defence Service Home Loans should qualify as 'Australian Soldiers' under the Defence Service Homes Act. They volunteered for service with the Naval, Military and Air Forces, serving wherever they were sent in whatever capacity they were required and yet are refused Defence Service Home Loans.

They took the oath to resist His Majesty's enemies which meant to fight His Majesty's enemies, and although not used in actual combat in war zones, they were available for that use and had a sufficiently grave need arisen would have been used, to serve with distinction as have women of other lands.

In accordance with the Acts and Regulations of the period, the women of the Military Forces had enlisted for service anywhere, some of the Naval women to sail in any waters, others with service on warships optional, while the women of the Airforce could have been sent to Papua New Guinea or other territories under the control or care of Australia.

Ex-servicemen of the Royal Australian Navy, the Australian Imperial Force and the Royal Australian Air Force who volunteered in the 1939-45 War but were not sent to War Zones are granted home loans. Not to grant eligibility to all Ex- servicewomen of 1939-45 War is unjust and unfair.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that you favourably consider amending the Defence Service Homes Act by repealing Sub-section 4 (2A) (b) (c) (d) of the Principal Act as amended by No. 137 of 1978, and grant eligibility to all members of the Women's Royal Australian Naval Service, the Australian Women's Army Service, the Women's Auxiliary Australian Air Force, the Australian Army Medical Women's Service, and the Voluntary Aid Detachment of 1939-45 War.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Crowley (from five citizens) and Haines (from 11 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:

The Universal Declaration of Human Rights affirms the principle of the inadmissibility of discrimination and proclaims that all human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights and that everyone is entitled to all the rights and freedoms set forth therein, without distinction of any kind including distinction based on sex.

However extensive discrimination against women continues to exist. It is an obstacle to the participation of women on equal terms with men, in the political , social, economic and cultural life of this country. It hampers the growth of the prosperity of society and the family and makes more difficult the full development of the potentialities of women in the service of this country and of humanity.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will act to ratify the convention on the elimination of all forms of discrimination against women.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Crowley (from 48 citizens) and MacGibbon (from 15 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Commemorative Postage Stamps
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
that to date no postage stamps have been issued to commemorate the services of Australian Forces in Korea and Vietnam.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled:
should seek and support the issue of such commemorative stamps.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Bjelke-Petersen (from 12 citizens) and Crichton-Browne (from 244 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Declaration Form
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament Assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the requirement that pensioners and health care cardholders fill in a complex declaration when presenting prescriptions is causing distress to beneficiaries and inefficiencies in the distribution of medicines by pharmacists .
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government will immediately abolish the requirement that a declaration be completed by the pensioner and health care cardholder.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Lump Sum Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President, and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Whereas the Government's announced proposal to tax lump sum superannuation payments by up to 60% is an unwarranted and unfair attack on the savings of Australians of average means and
Whereas the development of our nation requires the application of large sums of capital which can only be generated locally by the savings of Australians and
Whereas Government policies preventing the development of local capital only serve to increase Australia's dependence on foreign capital and
Whereas the encouragement of thrift and self-help should be paramount in our society,
We humbly pray that the Government will not proceed to impose a tax on lump sum superannuation payments above that presently existing.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our Nation and your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Mr Mart Niklus
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

(1) That we are deeply concerned for the well-being of Mr Mart Niklus, a leading Estonian and Baltic human rights activist who is in ill health and imprisoned in solitary confinement in Perm Labour Camp No. 389/36 in Siberia.
(2) That Mr Mart Niklus has been imprisoned as a 'prisoner of conscience' for the non-violent exercise of his beliefs and is denied visiting and communication rights.

(3) That the Australian Government give its support to any initiatives in this case by Amnesty International which has adopted Mr Mart Niklus. Amnesty International believes he has committed no real crime and has never used or advocated the use of violence.
(4) That we urge the Australian Government to make representations to the Government of the Soviet Union to promptly release Mr Mart Niklus and grant him a passport and exit visa.
(5) That in its representations to the Government of the Soviet Union advise that the Australian Government has approved the sponsored entry of Mr Mart Niklus into Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Lump Sum Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

We the undersigned herein voice our disapproval of the 30% tax on our lump sum Superannuation Payment and demand that the Federal Government does not impose this tax. If this imposition is instituted it will be a gross breach of contract . Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should request the Hon. P. Keating as Commonwealth Treasurer to assure the petitioners that this plan will be withdrawn.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Federal and State Parliaments
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Queensland respectfully showeth:
1. That one of the fundamental strengths of the Australian Federation has been the division of powers between the Federal Parliament and the various State Parliaments; and

2. The decision of the High Court in Commonwealth of Australia v State of Tasmania and associated cases seriously erodes the rights of the citizens of the various States to determine their own futures and removes from the authority of the State Parliaments the right to legislate in areas which have traditionally been their responsibility.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will:

(a) legislate to give effect to the proposal of the Queensland Division of the Liberal Party to ensure that no international treaty or convention will be ratified by Australia without the express approval of the State Parliaments; and
(b) reaffirm its commitment to the Federal system of government and continuing division of powers between the Commonwealth and State Parliaments.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Brisbane Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully shows:

We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, concerned with the cut in funding to the Brisbane Airport, concerned that this cut means loss of jobs, concerned that this cut could seriously affect the economy of Queensland:
Humbly petition the Senate to request the Australian Government to:
(1) Reverse its decision to cut funding to the Brisbane Airport.
(2) Abide by the guarantee given by the Minister for Housing and Construction that the Airport would receive priority funding.
(3) Assure the citizens of Queensland that the Brisbane Airport as the domestic and economic gateway to this State will be fully completed by 1987.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate is of the opinion that:
legislation should be introduced to enable handicapped people to undertake university or other tertiary studies, without imposing the same pace of work as for able-bodied students.

This legislation should require the pace at which handicapped students are to work to be approved by a panel of medical and educational specialists and that this pace be in direct relationship with their level of disability or capacity.

DEBATE.TITLE: PROVISION OF SERVICES FOR THE AGED

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I should like to address a few remarks to this paper, which is a very important document as it adds considerably to our understanding of the problems of the aged in the community. It is an attempt by a very authoritative group to draw together the considerations relating to the various spheres of government and the way in which they interrelate in providing services for the aged. The report contains very significant initiatives and suggestions about the way in which local government can inter-react with State and Federal governments to provide most local services for the aged. This particular point is of very great interest to honourable senators on this side of the House.

I believe that it is necessary to develop the concept that the most effective services can best be brought to the individuals concerned-that is, the aged and the disabled in the community-by drawing together government at the most local level. This report contains certain suggestions about how that can be done. It also draws to our attention the important point that not all local government bodies in Australia are suitably established or contain within their structures sufficient expertise to undertake that kind of role. It is very chastening to note the limited role of local government in that area, but it is also encouraging to note that, particularly in Melbourne and in Sydney, some suburban councils have made very significant attempts to develop the kinds of services that are envisaged in the delivery of care to the aged.

I refer to some of these developments. I believe the local council in Camberwell, Victoria, has developed very effectively at a local level the kinds of services for the aged which could be used as a model for development throughout the whole of Australia. Certainly in my State the town of Thebarton has developed a very significant interest in this area and is building its expertise towards providing a wider range of services for the aged at that most local level. One has to acknowledge, as this report does, that the key to the provision of services at that local government level relies very heavily upon the provision of funding. Obviously this report is aimed at drawing attention to that fact and at seeking ways and means by which funding can be rationalised for the other two levels of government, that is, State and Federal. In that respect I believe this report adds very significantly to our understanding of the problems. It certainly encourages us to think more deeply about those matters. There can be no doubt that on the question of developing the most effective services for the aged the answer lies in rationalising services, rationalising resources, at the most local level. If this report can encourage the Government to consider those matters more deeply and to develop policies which encourage the devolution to the most local level of the responsibility for providing services it is a most worthwhile contribution.

The Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations is certainly proving its worth in demonstrating to all of us in the Senate and in Australia as a whole the worthwhile sections of government that sometimes are overlooked in terms of the development of services to all kinds of people in this community. We on this side of the Senate believe that further thought on the part of the Government in this area is warranted. We look forward to further action and the Government's response. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

I acknowledge again that the publication of the information which is contained in these documents is a useful service to Australia. It is a matter of regret to me that the Government, having set out such clear indications for the community as to what was required, so stoically refuses to follow those broad indications and seems determined to follow courses which will not achieve the positive results which, I would have thought, were the objective of the Government and certainly would be the wish of the Australian people. But the fact of the papers being available is in itself a plus. Again, I wish to acknowledge that. DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CANNED FRUIT SALES PROMOTION COMMITTEE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Resolutions of 116th Meeting

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I speak briefly to the resolutions of the 116th meeting of the Australian Agricultural Council which was held on 7 February 1983. I note that it is now 6 1/2 months since that important meeting was held. Agriculture in Australia has been suffering from a number of problems, not the least of which has been the extremely severe and continuing drought as well as world market problems. That being so, I would have expected that with the opportunity there has been for the production of the report of the resolutions we would have had them before the Senate when we were sitting in May and the beginning of June.

Having taken some interest, in successive governments, in the time taken in the presentation of reports, I wish to draw attention to the fact that this does not appear to be a good start for the Government. I would hope that it would not be as lethargic in the presentation of some reports as governments over the years have been. I believe that constant attention needs to be drawn to this problem to ensure that people can obtain the benefit of the information which such reports contain and an opportunity can be taken to debate it if necessary and appropriate.

In relation to the Australian Agricultural Council's report, I imagine-I have not yet seen the document-that the report contains a large number of matters which the Senate would wish to debate. I imagine that the resolutions would relate to a large number of aspects of primary industry in Australia, including the marketing of wheat and the problems that one imagines arise in the various forms of marketing, such as the disaster which has befallen the Queensland Grain Growers Association. Some of us over the years have expressed our concern about the way in which some statutory authorities and others have been able to obtain power to conduct marketing schemes without necessarily being subject to a requirement of full and immediate accountability. The delay in the presentation of reports is one of the aspects of the potential delay in accountability.

The President of the Queensland Grain Growers Association, Mr Don Eather, was vigorous in his defence of the absolute propriety of that organisation and attacked the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations in relation to its comments on the Australian Wheat Board and wheat marketing in Australia. I find that there is some justification for some further explanation, some further identification, of the real reasons for this extraordinary loss. Was it just a matter of bad advice in relation to hedging transactions in regard to overseas trade and the borrowing of funds? Was it that the Association took advice from a company called Agropon, which has already been criticised for the advice that it has given other sections of primary industry? Has it terminated that company's involvement? Is it correct to say that the company was involved in questions raised in Hong Kong and other places? Were questions raised in relation to its appropriateness as an adviser to the Australian Wheat Board? All of these matters are appropriate for discussion in this chamber and an appropriate vehicle therefor is the report of the Australian Agricultural Council.

I have not the time to go into detail about some of the other questions involved but hope that the Senate will be given an early opportunity to continue the discussion of this report. I have an indication from Senator Macklin that he wishes to make a statement also and therefore will terminate my remarks at this point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the recess I was able to read the resolutions of the 116th meeting of the Australian Agricultural Council, which had been released at that time. However, as is the case probably with most honourable senators who do not live around Canberra, the report ended up in my electorate office. The Government's proposals go a long way towards meeting the objections of rural industry in this regard. I wish to make some comments on that at a later stage. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

DEBATE.TITLE: FISHING AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE AUSTRALIAN GOVERNMENT AND THE KAOHSIUNG FISHING BOAT COMMERCIAL GUILD 1983

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I would like to make one or two comments on this agreement which has existed for a number of years on a 12-monthly basis. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) recently agreed that the licences be renewed with various conditions attached. The Minister for Primary Industry, in his letter to Mr Kailis, said:
In agreeing to access on this basis for a twelve month period I wish to draw to the attention of KKFC Pty Ltd--
that is the Australian company-

and the Guild that it is the policy of the Commonwealth, the State and the Northern Territory Governments to favour, where possible and practicable, joint fishing ventures between Australian enterprises and foreign interests to develop fisheries resources currently not exploited by Australians.

There are a lot of fish in our Australian waters, as Senator Withers would know, that we do not exploit to the advantage of the Australian people. We think it is a fair thing that that resource should be made available to people in Asian countries who regard these fish as a delicacy. The agreement is quite clear in indicating that from time to time the Commonwealth Government, through the Minister, has the right to impose certain conditions. The Guild pays the Commonwealth a fee of $1,271,753 a year. The area of operations in our waters is described-the latitudes and the longitudes-as are the types of fish that are able to be caught.

I have some knowledge of the members of the Kaohsiung Fishing Boat Commercial Guild, its Chairman, Mr Kung Fu Chen, and his colleagues on the executive. I know they are very ethical as far as the operations of their ships are concerned . Incidents have occurred involving Taiwanese fishing vessels. They have transgressed the international waters regulations. However, I think it is fair to tell people now that those vessels operated independently of the Guild. The Guild specifies very carefully to its masters the regulations governing operations in international fishing waters. In fact, it has a training college. Apart from the technology of the fishing profession, the maintenance of vessels and the repair of nets, a significant part of the course deals with international law. The people from Taiwan who have transgressed in the past are not involved with the Kaohsiung Fishing Boat Commercial Guild. The Minister said in his letter:

. . . on application by KKFC in respect of any individual licensed fishing vessel of Taiwan, to authorise that vessel to enter the ports of Darwin, Broome and Fremantle and any other port which may be agreed by the Commonwealth and State Governments, at times specified in the endorsement in accordance with the powers vested in me by the Fisheries Act . . .

The endorsement . . . does not release the Guild, its members, its representatives or agents, or the operators of the vessels from compliance with any State or other Commonwealth law concerning entry to or use of Australian ports by foreign vessels.
The letter also specifies:

The aggregate quantity of fish to be made available for sale in Australia shall not exceed 15 per cent of the total allocation of catch to licensed fishing vessels of Taiwan unless appropriate commercial agreements are made to land a higher proportion of the catch. Such arrangements will be subject to approval of the Commonwealth Government.

There are quite a lot of advantages in establishing joint Australian-foreign ventures to ensure that our fishery is exploited although not just to our advantage because I believe Australian fishermen can learn something of the techniques that have been developed by Taiwan over many years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to comment a little further on what the Fishing Agreement between the Australian Government and the Kaohsiung Fishing Boat Commercial Guild can represent. An important question to be faced in regard to Australia's future in relation to fishing is how we are going to go about associating with other countries in relation to the development of the Southern Ocean, Antarctic and sub-Antarctic waters for the fishing of squid, tuna and krill and of bases in Australia. One of the questions in relation to the negotiations with the Kaohsiung Fishing Boat Commercial Guild, the Kailis company and the Australian Government, has been the question of bases in Australia for that operation. Of course the Kailis company has been associated with the Taiwan guild in providing an Australian content to the total operation. Moving from that, we should be looking to the development of attitudes with regard to Taiwan and other countries and the development of the Southern Ocean fisheries and bases for them. In relation to that, I wish to make the brief point that Tasmania is an ideal place for those bases to be located. That would provide an extra industry and extra employment for Tasmania to offset the problems that will arise as a result of other events which have taken place involving Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, what I want briefly to say is that, using this example, I hope that the Senate will have an early opportunity to debate more fully the development of the southern fisheries and the bases appropriate for that development, particularly if Australia is not going to develop its own domestic fishing industry at the rate which some people believe is necessary for us to take advantage of deep sea fishing as well as coastal fishing around Australia. I raise the point as being one worthy of further consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak very briefly on this matter, being a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce which recently looked into the Australian fishing industry. I want also to use this opportunity to draw the attention of honourable senators again to the fact that at the time of the tabling of this paper on the Fishing Agreement between the Australian Government and the Kaohsiung Fishing Boat Commercial Guild we did not have a copy of the agreement. We are now at the stage where, instead of being provided with a list of papers that are to be presented to the Senate each day, the papers now carry marks which indicate that some are to be released during the adjournment and that some will not be available prior to their tabling.
—Well why don't you do something about it?

—I am doing it now. I am bringing to the attention of the President the fact that it is not satisfactory to have papers presented which we have not even sighted. We are supposed to debate reports in this place when we have not even sighted them until we have sat at our desks. If we do not have a particular interest in an area we may not even see that a report has come across our desks in our offices. Mr President, I suggest to you that this could be done in a very rational way. It is very simple. Those papers and reports which have been distributed to members could be the subject of debate on a particular day. Until a report is available let us not stand up here and make fools of ourselves by trying to debate something about which we know nothing because we do not know what is in a written paper.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: HUMAN RIGHTS AND THE DEPORTATION OF CONVICTED ALIENS AND IMMIGRANTS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
Because of the time, I seek leave to continue my remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted?
—No. I wish to speak to this as well.

—Senator Missen, it is now 12 o'clock. Question Time is being brought on. I think Senator Sibraa sought leave to continue his remarks so that the debate would not lapse. If Senator Missen wants to speak to the motion I suggest that leave be granted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Missen

TALK.START.PARA: —I make just one point, sir. It is the same point as Senator Coleman made. An important subject such as this should not be brought before this chamber when the papers are not available and are not in our rooms.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer whether he agrees with the comment in Budget Statement No. 2:

QUESTION.PARA: It is crucial that wage and price developments be constrained within the broad guidelines set by the prices and incomes accord.

Secondly, is it not a fact that, even if the prices and incomes accord holds, interest rates will rise, unemployment will rise and inflation will continue at high levels? Thirdly, given recent wage settlements-for example, in relation to building workers and food processors-can the Minister assure the Senate that wage developments will be constrained within the broad guidelines set by the accord?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has always regarded the prices and incomes policy as essential to economic recovery in Australia. That is scarcely news. One does not have to go to Budget Statement No. 2 to find reference to that, although of course Budget Statement No. 2 is prepared by the Department of the Treasury and not by the Government per se. For several years in opposition the view was stated consistently by the present Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, and other members of the then shadow ministry who had economic responsibilities that a prices and incomes accord was essential to sustaining high rates of economic growth, without which unemployment cannot be reduced. The empirical evidence in support of prices and incomes agreements, irrespective of whether they are formally recognised as such, has been quite compelling from overseas sources where high rates of growth with low rates of unemployment and inflation have been sustained over many years. I would have hoped that by now the present Opposition might have acknowledged the existence of that empirical evidence and have begun to change its views on this subject.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to the first part of Senator Chaney's question is yes, the Government, as it has long done, regards an effective prices and incomes policy as being essential to economic recovery and lower unemployment. Senator Chaney asked also: Is it inevitable that interest rates will rise? Budget Statement No. 2 sets out in some detail the various factors which influence interest rates. Clearly, it does not endorse the simplistic dogma put forward by members of the Liberal and National parties when they were in government, and still apparently, regrettably, put forward by the present Leader of the Opposition, namely, that there is a simplistic one-to-one correlation between the size of the public sector borrowing requirement and interest rates. As Budget Statement No. 2 makes quite clear, interest rates are influenced by a variety of factors, one of which is the public sector borrowing requirement. Others are private sector borrowing requirements, anticipated inflation rates, the level of interest rates overseas and so on.

Whether interest rates will rise or fall is not something which can be predicted with any certainty, although I note in passing that in the run-up to the 1977 election it was predicted with absolute certainty by the discredited former Prime Minister and the discredited former Deputy Prime Minister that interest rates would fall by 2 per cent over the coming year. The discredited former Deputy Prime Minister said that it was a target which could and would be met. We all know what happened. Interest rates went up by 2 per cent in the following year, and not down.

TALK.START.PARA: —And he did not eat his hat.

—He did not eat his hat either, as he promised to do-another broken National Party promise. Of the various factors likely to affect nominal interest rates, probably the most important will be the future course of inflation. The Budget Papers predict a consumer price index rise of 7 or 7 1/2 per cent. The Government believes that is achievable, principally because of the consensus of the incomes policy which it has sought. If the effect of Medicare is to bring the CPI below the implicit price deflator for the gross domestic product--
—What is the effect of Medicare?

—If the honourable senator wants to argue that that artificially depresses the CPI, a case can be put for that point of view. Conversely the case can be put that other measures artificially boost the CPI. But to return to the central point, the likely most important factor on nominal interest rates will be changes in the direction of the inflation rate. Because of that it can be anticipated, without making the sorts of rash promises which were made in 1977, that provided-I stress this point, we have always said it is crucial-the incomes accord is respected, interest rates will be on a declining trend within the next 12 months.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Part of my question was not dealt with. I asked the Minister representing the Treasurer whether, given recent wage settlements-I referred to the building workers and food processors-he can assure the Senate that wage developments will be constrained within the broad guidelines set by the accord.

—This sounds like a rerun of yesterday's Question Time when Senator Button was asked an almost identical question, I think twice. He stated that the Government is putting in a submission. The decisions made by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission are not under the direct control of the Government. As Senator Button stated yesterday, the Government has made a general submission to the Commission.

—My question, which is directed to the Attorney-General, relates to the unlikely event of the National and Liberal parties being able to form a government coalition after the 22 October election in Queensland. Given the National Party's commitment to retaining a malapportioned electoral system and the Liberals' timidity to do anything about it, could the Federal Parliament legislate to insist on a one vote, one value electoral redistribution in Queensland?

—I take it that the honourable senator is referring to suggestions that have been made in various quarters since the Tasmanian dam case that the external affairs power might enable the Commonwealth to take this kind of action by implementing the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, and in particular certain guarantees of democratic political rights contained in that instrument. All I say to the honourable senator is that a very complicated legal and constitutional question is involved as to whether any such legislative enterprise involving the electoral boundaries within the States would in fact withstand constitutional scrutiny. Any further trespassing into these waters would engage me in giving a legal opinion which is, of course, outside the bounds of my duties and responsibilities as a member of this place. I simply further add that the situation in Queensland has been criticised by all responsible commentators of any colour of independence for many years now, and it is time manifestly that action was taken by all Queensland politicians of good will to put their own house in order. Hopefully that will be done after 22 October.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General and concerns articles which appeared in the National Times of 6-12 May this year entitled ' The Austeo Papers', written by the National Times editor, Mr Brian Toohey. If I show the Attorney-General a copy of the front page, I am sure he will remember the newspaper. I refer to the reproduction on the third page of that newspaper of the letters accompanying the special supplement to the fourth part of the report of the Hope Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies, classified 'Austeo', 'Top Secret' and 'Oyster'. I refer also to a reproduction of the covering letter to that report by Mr Justice Hope, dated 24 September 1976, which concludes:

QUESTION.PARA: Two copies of this supplement have been made. I recommend that it be not further copied.
I refer also to the National Times' claims of access to 'tens of thousands of pages of classified documents' and to this statement in the National Times:
Access to these documents has been backed up by interviews with dozens of officials in these fields.

I ask the Attorney-General: Does he yet know the source or sources of these leaks and who are the dozens of officials who have been interviewed? If he does know, will he make a statement to the Senate giving the information or explaining why it cannot be revealed? If he does not yet know the sources or the interviewees, will he advise the Senate whether there has been any investigation and, if so, what, into these questions? Finally, in due course will he inform the Senate of the results?

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it at the moment, the situation is that intensive investigations involving the Australian Federal Police and other appropriate agencies have been taking place since the time of publication of the articles in question, with a view to identifying the sources. This is a matter which the Government manifestly took seriously at the time and continues to take seriously. My further knowledge at this point is that those investigations are still proceeding. I certainly do not know who the sources are or whether the investigations have succeeded in pinning down the sources in question. I am not sure but, if and when information comes to light as a result of those investigations, no doubt it will be made public in the ordinary and proper way. Whether it will be appropriate to do so by a statement in this House or whether, rather, it will be more appropriate to do so through the ordinary processes of criminal law is a matter for judgment, which will need to be made at that time.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. I ask: What hormones and other additives are permitted in the diet of livestock produced for human consumption in Australia?
—I will refer the question to the Minister for Primary Industry and secure an answer as soon as possible.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. I ask: Will the Government make an immediate approach to the Indonesian Government for an absolute guarantee that no items included in Australian military aid to Indonesia will be used against the people of East Timor? Will the Government, while still pressing for an act of self- determination in East Timor, seek as an interim measure a full and permanent amnesty for those Timorese who have opposed the Indonesian invasion? Will the Government seek, through the good offices of the United Nations and with the concurrence of the Indonesian and other interested governments, an open door for a comprehensive pattern of aid for East Timor in the form of both money and expertise that would enable it to become a prosperous and viable society? If that last objective could be achieved, and I believe it could, can that be on the basis of normal disclosure of events in East Timor being permitted by the Indonesian Government so that world opinion can be satisfied as to the intentions of Indonesia in regard to East Timor?

—The Government's intense desire to protect and advance the interests of the people of East Timor has been made explicit on many occasions, including by me in this chamber. I assure the honourable senator that there is no resiling whatsoever on the part of this Government from that endeavour. Nonetheless, given the quite explicit and specific nature of the questions that have been put this morning by Senator Mason, the best I can do by way of an answer at this stage is simply to give an undertaking to him that I will immediately refer his questions respectively to the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Foreign Affairs to ensure that answers are given to those questions as soon as possible.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: THE PHILIPPINES: DEATH OF FORMER SENATOR BENIGNO AQUINO

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs : Has the Government expressed any concern at the brutal murder three days ago of the Filipino democratic opposition leader, Senator Benigno Aquino? In light of this murder, will the Government re-assess its substantial aid program to the Philippines?

—Two days ago the Minister for Foreign Affairs stated publicly that the Government deplored the death by violent means of former Senator Benigno Aquino on his return to the Philippines on 21 August. Senator Aquino had long enjoyed a fine reputation world-wide for the force, vigour and persistence with which he advanced civil liberterian and democratic values in the Philippines. His loss is a gigantic one, not only for the Philippines and those who over the years he represented in that country by the force and vigour of his advocacy, but also to civilised values world-wide. I understand that the Australian Ambassador has conveyed to the Philippines Foreign Minister, General Romulo, the Australian Government's concern that the Philippines Government spare no effort in bringing to justice the perpetrators of this brutal assassination. Our concerns in this respect cover the manner of Senator Aquino's death, the need for the full processes of law to be brought to bear on the incident and the continuing uncertainty in the accounts of his death. I note that in a statement a day or two ago President Marcos condemned the assassination and pledged that his Government will apply all its resources towards bringing the perpetrators to justice in the quickest possible time. We certainly look forward to that occurring. As to the final part of the honourable senator's question, about the implications of this for Australia's aid to the Philippines, I will bring that to the attention of the Foreign Minister and seek an early reply.

—I ask you, Mr President, whether you are able to assure the Senate that the offices of senators and members and the committee rooms in the Parliament are not subject to electronic surveillance. If not, will you engage an electronics expert to conduct a thorough investigation-I think the technical term is electronic sweep-of Parliament House to ensure that the offices and committee rooms of the Parliament are not bugged, provide peace of mind for constituents who wish to discuss in confidence personal representations with their parliamentary members and ensure that civil liberties in this sense are preserved?

—I have already arranged for discussions to take place this afternoon between myself and the security controller of Parliament House. I will ask the security controller for a report and I will present the report to the Senate.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs: Given the fact that the Polish trade union movement, Solidarity, will celebrate its third anniversary on 31 August, will the Minister again convey to the Polish Government the Australian Parliament's support for a free trade union movement in Poland?

—I will draw the honourable senator's question to the attention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs, who I am sure will be very receptive to that suggestion. Of course, it is one which not only is very much in accordance with the views of the present Government but also has across the board bipartisan support from the Parliament. That is a very significant state of affairs. As to the larger situation that now prevails in Poland, the Polish Government has lifted martial law and announced a partial amnesty for detainees, including Solidarity members, although, as the chamber will be aware, special legislation has been brought into force to cover the period following the lifting of martial law, which could well have the effect of maintaining essential elements of that martial law notwithstanding its formal removal. It is to be regretted, and is regretted by this Government, that the amnesty for political prisoners was only partial in nature. Under these circumstances a good deal of further study will be needed and representations made to ensure that the measures introduced by the Polish authorities are, in fact, appropriate to meet the expectations and aspirations of the Polish people, particularly as expressed through the free trade union movement.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. I refer to the Prime Minister's secret telephone conversation on 24 April, which is a matter of public record, warning Mr Richard Farmer and Mr Bill Butler not to enter into a lobbying partnership with Mr David Combe. As the warning gave confidential information to Mr Farmer and Mr Butler 17 days in advance of the rest of the community receiving knowledge of this matter and saved those two would-be lobbyists many hundreds of thousands of dollars in partnerships costs, I ask: Is the Government considering any course of legal action open to the clients of Mr Combe who were not in receipt of Mr Hawke's privileged information and who, in those 17 days, were entitled to expect that Mr Combe was still lobbying Ministers in a service for which they were paying high fees? Do they have a case against the Prime Minister or the Government on any grounds whatsoever?
—Insofar as the question does not seek a legal opinion I shall allow it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even with the help that you have now given me, Mr President , I still think it will be possible for me to resist the temptation to answer Senator Walters's question, canvassing, as it does, numerous matters of detail that are presently before the Hope Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies and which will be the subject of report by His Honour in a matter of weeks. I do not want to be taken, by my non-answer, as in any way giving credence to any of the allegations and fantasies that have been perpetrated in the course of the question by Senator Walters. I simply make the point that it is no more appropriate now than it was during the last session of this Parliament for me or anyone else to be canvassing matters which are properly being dealt with by the Royal Commission.

ANSWER.PARA: Might I also say, Mr President, that, indebted as I am to the Opposition for giving me so much attention this morning, I and other members of the Government front bench are viewing, with some fascination, as no doubt will be most people in the Australian community, the profound indifference-indeed, it may be ignorance-of the other side of this chamber to the fact that last night a Budget was handed down in this place with quite profound implications for the future course of the Australian economy and the Australian people. It is a matter of very considerable fascination that the Opposition should be so concerned with pursuing hares and Will-o'-the-wisps of the kind involved in Senator Walters's question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Is the Attorney saying that my question was sub judice? If so, does the Chair give that ruling, because I would be most interested to find out from the Attorney, who on previous occasions has never considered that that was relevant in this chamber. Why has he changed his opinion? I would like a ruling from the Chair.

—I think I should intercede and say that the rule of sub judice is a matter for interpretation by the Chair. If the Chair thought that sub judice was involved, the Chair would have intervened. Having said that, I invite the Attorney-General to reply to the supplementary question in the way in which he chooses.

—I would not be allowed to, Mr President. I simply make the point that I was making no formal claim of protection or otherwise under the sub judice rule. I was simply making the point that it is manifestly improper, in terms of the normal conventions of decent behaviour and respect for the operations of tribunals of this kind, that Senator Walters should be pursuing such matters while they are still being dealt with by that tribunal.

—I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate . Recently the Government announced assistance to Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. Why is assistance, and assistance of the magnitude announced, justified? Is there any guarantee that the Big Australian will not retrench any more workers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The plan announced by the Government in respect of steel involves the payment of bounties to BHP and other steel producing companies over a period of five years. The first point I want to make clear is that the reason for Government assistance, which was negotiated over some period with the companies involved and others, was simply to encourage an investment program by BHP over that period of five years. It was determined by the Government, having regard to all the circumstances, that that degree of assistance was necessary and desirable in order to encourage an investment program by BHP. I must say, in answering this question, that yesterday a comment was made by the Opposition spokesman on industry, Senator Peter Rae, which suggested that the level of investment undertaken by BHP was insufficient. The level of investment was compared by Senator Peter Rae with the level of investment which BHP had put forward as the desired level before the Industries Assistance Commission in November 1982. I just make the point that the level of investment over the five years of the plan is in excess of the level of investment over the first five years proposed by BHP to the IAC in November 1982.
—But theirs was part of a 10-year plan and this is only five years.

—Theirs was part of a 10-year plan which sought certain concessions from government, such as immediate expensing at a cost to revenue of about $2,000m-that would have been the total cost if immediate expensing had been introduced-group taxation at a cost of $150m in revenue to the Government in the first year, and a number of other matters, including an 85 per cent market share, which the Government was not prepared to guarantee to BHP. So I do not think it is feasible to compare the wildest aspirations of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd put before the IAC with the details of the plan which has been announced.

ANSWER.PARA: The essence of the steel industry plan is that there be contributions from all those involved-contributions from the Government in terms of bounty assistance, contributions from BHP in terms of investment and particularly in terms of the question which Senator Cook addressed in the second part of this question relating to employment. The undertaking given by the company in respect of employment is that there will be no compulsory redundancies during the five years of the plan. That does not mean that the size of the work force may not be reduced by a process of attrition or by voluntary retirement schemes. But there will be no sackings during the five years of the plan. I simply make the point, because it has become a matter of some issue, that the cost to the Government of providing the level of assistance to BHP which has been agreed on is something in the order of $2,000 per year per employee. That is the cost of assistance. The cost of non-assistance to BHP by the Fraser Government was 14,000 jobs in the steel industry at an estimated cost to revenue of $7,000 per employee. I think that is an important point to draw to the attention of the Senate. Up until May of this year 14,000 jobs were lost in the steel industry, and the cost to revenue of each of those who became a recipient of unemployment benefit is in the order of $7,000 a year.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was avoidable, was it, by State Government intervention?

—It may have been avoidable, if the Fraser Government had done something more than just refer the matter to a steel industry advisory council. Whatever bleatings might rise from the Opposition, those facts are essential facts to remember when considering the steel industry package. The answer in relation to employment and the level of investment is clear.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. The Budget Papers indicate: Firstly, an anticipated decline of 13.1 per cent in the collection of company tax, thereby indicating a turndown in private sector activity and profitability; secondly, a marked fall in private business fixed investment; thirdly, an increase in the average number of unemployment beneficiaries from 540,200 last year to 680,000 this year, revealing a rise in unemployment to 11 per cent or at least 30,000 more unemployed on top of the peak; and, fourthly, a predicted rise in interest rates . In view of these indications, I ask: How can the Government reconcile its rhetoric in the Budget Speech that the Budget will stimulate activity and reduce unemployment with its statements in that Speech that there will be higher unemployment and reduced activity?

—It would be idle during Question Time-I am sure Senator Sir John Carrick would want to lead a debate on this issue-to reconcile a series of figures plucked out of the Budget Papers, some of which, by the way, are not as stated by the honourable senator in his question, with what he describes as the rhetoric of the Budget Speech. That is a matter which in due course undoubtedly will be debated and about which we will hear from the Opposition in the course of its attack-if there is such a thing-on the Budget. It is not a matter which I propose to deal with in terms of reconciliation during Question Time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Since the Government Leader indicated that what I said was not in fact what was said in the Budget Speech-I interpolate that the phrases I used were taken from Budget Paper No. 1-will he now indicate where the deviation occurs? I repeat that the Budget indicated that there will be a decline of 13.1 per cent in company tax. Is that right or wrong? The statement that there will be a marked decline in fixed capital business investment is taken straight from the Speech. On the statement that there will be an increase in the average number of unemployed, I refer the Senate to page 135 of the Budget Statements where those exact words can be found. The Government also predicted a rise in interest rates . Where do my words differ from those of the Speech? Where was I in defect or fault in what I said?
—I have only to go to one matter. Senator Sir John Carrick referred to the projected decline in the collection of company tax. As I recall, it was not stated in terms of a projected decline.
—Actual.
—Yes, it is an actual decline in company tax which reflects last year's activities.

—I address to the Attorney-General a question in relation to an article that appeared in the Bulletin on 28 June regarding the fate of Lord Casey's diaries. Is it true that the diaries, which were willed to the National Library of Australia by the late Lord Casey when he died in 1976, have not yet been delivered to the Library? If this is the case, are the diaries in the possession of the Australian Security Intelligence Service or the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation? If the diaries are in their possession, have these organisations tampered with, edited, altered or interfered with in any way the contents of the Casey diaries? Given that the diaries would be of immense value to Australia's historical and political heritage, when can the Minister assure us that the diaries in their original state have been delivered to their rightful place in the National Library?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised by my Department and the Department of Foreign Affairs that officers of the Foreign Affairs Department have had access to the diaries of the late Lord Casey. On the basis of the briefing material before me, I am not clear as to whether those diaries are still in the possession of the Department of Foreign Affairs. If that is the case I will certainly make representations to ensure that they are transmitted to the National Library as soon as possible. This access by the Department of Foreign Affairs was, I understand, authorised by the Director-General of the National Library of Australia, the inheritor of the diaries. I further understand that it was in accordance with Lord Casey's wishes. The purpose of access was to allow a check to be made for material injurious to the reputation of individuals or of continuing diplomatic sensitivity. Any embargo that may be placed on particular words or passages in the diaries in pursuit of one or other of those two objectives will be temporary only. I am further advised that there will be no interference whatsoever with the physical integrity of the diaries. The original itself comprises both typed and bound volumes, and sensitive material will be masked in a way that is common to both archives and libraries.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the particular role that has been played by the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation in this matter as distinct from the Department of Foreign Affairs, the situation, I am advised, is as follows: ASIO has not at any stage had physical access to the papers or sought such access; at one stage comment was sought of ASIO by the Department of Foreign Affairs in relation to one matter of detail concerning a particular person, namely as to whether that person had been or was still an ASIO officer. The advice given to Foreign Affairs was in the negative and that remains the one and only contribution to the saga that, notwithstanding all the publicity to the contrary in the Bulletin , has been made by the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs. On what grounds or with what educational advice has the Government been so quick to abolish the equity principle, until now long established, that financial support for non-government schools be a determined percentage of the cost of a government school place? At the same time, why has the Government sacked from the Schools Commission representatives of non-government schools leaving these, one quarter of all Australian schools, inadequately and disproportionately represented at the very time that the basis for funding these schools is being comprehensively reviewed by the Commission? By these actions- the abolition of the percentage link and the sacking of the non-government schools representatives-is the Government putting all non-government schools on notice that they are to be undermined by this Government, partly directly and partly by stealth?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose I had better make some effort to address myself to the substance, insofar as there was any, in that outburst by Senator Teague. The first matter that Senator Teague raised was the question of the changing of the formula by which non-government schools are assisted through the Commonwealth Schools Commission. This was actually the subject of a question yesterday. I will just repeat very briefly that the formula which gave to non-government schools a set percentage of government schools' cost was changed by us because it was not achieving equity and was not leading to a situation where schools which were struggling to provide proper education for the students in them were able to improve at an adequate pace.

ANSWER.PARA: We have made a series of decisions whereby extra resources have been allocated to those schools most in need. In the non-government sector there are about 2, 200 schools, the vast majority of which received increased funding under our new way of funding non-government schools. Indeed, the vast majority of non- government schools which were in category 3 received a 3 per cent real increase on the funding they received last year. So I think that any questions about equity will be resolved very clearly in favour of the Government's recent decision. I also informed the Senate yesterday that so as to have a better way of judging the needs of schools and achieving an even more equitable result than we have achieved this year, we will be developing a new formula for assistance to all non-government schools and all non-government schools and their representatives will have the opportunity to participate in the development of that formula.

The second part of Senator Teague's question concerned what he liked to describe as the sacking of a member of the Schools Commission who represented the point of view of non-government schools. The first thing I would like to say about that is that nobody has been sacked from the Schools Commission. The Schools Commission is so composed that there are three full time commissioners and several part time commissioners. The terms of the part time commissioners expire, of course, at different stages. Shortly after the change of government there was an opportunity to make some new appointments. I did what I think all my predecessors have done and sought views from different sections of education as to who would be appropriate members of the Commission.

Clearly, with a commission which has only eight members, not all sectors can be represented at all times; not all States and Territories can be represented at all times. With regard to the replacement of the part time position, which had been held by a representative of the Australian Parents Council, I decided to do something which was an innovation and was very important. I think all honourable senators will agree with that. I decided to appoint somebody with an expertise in Aboriginal education. I appointed Mr Paul Hughes, who is also the full time Chairman of the National Aboriginal Education Committee, thus bringing together the work of that Committee and the work of the Schools Commission and giving, for the first time, a real policy emphasis in the very difficult and complex area of providing adequate education for Aboriginal children. However, it is simply untrue-I think it is very mischievous-to suggest that there is no voice for the non-government sector on the Schools Commission. Mr Dudley Clarke, who is the Principal of the Hutchins School in Tasmania, is a part time commissioner who was appointed by my predecessor. He is still a member of the Schools Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is not on the Commission.

—Mr Dudley Clarke is a part time member of the Schools Commission, as he has been for some time. I also invited some suggested participants from the National Catholic Education Commission. From the suggestions that it made I appointed Mr Vin Falconer, who is the Administrator of the Catholic Education Commission in Victoria. I thought it was very important that there should be somebody on the Commission from such a large system as the parish system in Victoria because clearly the vast majority of non-government schools are schools in the Catholic parish system. I thought it was most appropriate to have the benefit of Mr Falconer's contribution.

ANSWER.PARA: However, having said that, I indicate that other vacancies will occur from time to time. It is certainly my intention and the intention of the Government to continue to have a representative group of commissioners and to rotate, amongst the different interests and the different States, participation in the work of the Commission. I do not know that Senator Teague raised any other matters. I hope that he will pay attention to what I have said today because, unfortunately , there has been some misrepresentation of the matter concerning appointments to the Commission. I hope that I have clarified that position for him today.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I do so because we still receive hundreds of letters from all over Australia about these matters. There is concern in the community. Will the Minister give consideration to non-government schools being able to make direct representations since the basis for funding is being so comprehensively reviewed and they feel so strongly that they are not sufficiently represented on the Schools Commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator Teague's supplementary question, I can only agree that there is a great deal of concern and a great deal of very legitimate interest in the question of how the Government is going to undertake its responsibilities for the non-government school sector. I agree that there ought to be very extensive consultation between the representatives of those schools and officers of the Schools Commission. I told the Senate yesterday that these consultations are already under way. The commissioners are travelling around Australia meeting, week by week, with the various representatives of the non- government sector. I endeavour to meet with as many representatives as I can, although I am sure Senator Teague will understand that some of this consultation work has to be carried out by the Schools Commission itself because of the sheer number of people who are interested in education. I do meet as often as I can with national organisations and State organisations. Apart, of course, from the work of the Schools Commission in consulting, all non-government sectors are represented on the State planning and finance committee. There may still be a need for consultations over and above those which I have described.

ANSWER.PARA: I would be very interested to hear from Senator Teague any suggestions that he may have so that we may carry out even more fully the consultation process because it is not in the interests of the Government and it is not in the interests of anybody concerned for education that there be misunderstandings, feelings of neglect or points of view not taken into account. We really want to resolve in a long term way a method of dealing equitably with all sectors of education, and I am hoping for-and I must say I am getting-a great deal of co- operation in this exercise.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. What measures have been taken in the Budget to assist with the problems of our ageing veteran population?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has recognised the importance of taking steps in this Budget to improve visibly the problem facing the ageing sections of the Australian population. Veterans, an important segment of that population, come within that category. So, within the context of the Budget, a major initiative has been taken. In excess of $2m has been made available to the Department of Health and $1m to the Department of Veterans' Affairs for the purpose of establishing geriatric assessment units. In my case these will be in each of the six repatriation hospitals. In Dr Blewett's case, in the Department of Health, similar assessment units will, on a regional basis, concern themselves with what is regarded by social scientists and others as the problem of the ageing section of the Australian population. These units will operate to assess the needs of ageing veterans, in the case of the Department of Veterans' Affairs, and make available to them a combination of services suited to their medical, social and emotional situations.

ANSWER.PARA: The aim of the units-I heartily endorse the comments of Senator Messner who said earlier today in response to the bringing down of a report that there was a need for local government to be involved in looking after our ageing population- will be to give veterans the ability to maintain their independence and dignity at home rather than in nursing homes or institutions. That is a very important commitment which this Government accepts. I hope it is accepted by the Opposition on a non-partisan basis. The service will be made available to the general public, where possible. It is expected that this approach to care of the aged will develop rapidly in the life of this Government. I hope that in the Budget next year we will be in a position to take very big strides towards recognising that we have a major social problem on our hands. My department accepts without hesitation its obligation to provide an increasing range of services and particularly to apply them to the home care situation and not see aged persons just sent off to institutions, nursing homes, hostels and such like which has been the practice in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is the Minister aware of the statement by Mr Eric Risstrom, Secretary to the Australian Taxpayers Association, that extra taxation to be paid this year will have a staggering effect on the typical Australian family? Does he know that Mr Risstrom has stated that a man on an income of $15,000 last year, in line for the Budget-estimated 7 per cent wage rise during 1983-84, faces a 16 per cent increase in tax? Will Senator Walsh confirm Mr Risstrom's assessment of the extra tax burden to be borne by the ordinary Australian?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot confirm off the top of my head the accuracy of the figures quoted or alleged. However, I can confirm that the same Mr Risstrom has described the Budget as being a very responsible Budget. Members of the previous Government ought to be well aware of the phenomenon of fiscal drag-their revenues were boosted very substantially almost every year they were in government because of it-whereby the proportion of income paid in tax on the same taxation schedule increases while incomes rise. If incomes rise by 7 per cent and the taxation schedule remains the same then not only the absolute amount of tax paid increases but also the proportion of income paid in tax increases. The discredited former Prime Minister made a very heavy feature, prior to his election in 1975, of a promise to index automatically--

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Every time Senator Walsh says 'the discredited Prime Minister' I believe we must take into consideration the fact that he, as Minister for Resources and Energy, was sacked by the Prime Minister from taking part in negotiations with Tasmania on energy matters. Therefore, if anyone is discredited it is certainly Senator Walsh who is a discredited Minister.
—There is no point of order.

—On the authority of the present Leader of the Opposition, Senator Walters's own Leader, we have it that Mr Fraser and his comments on current political events should be taken about as seriously as another former Prime Minister, Sir William McMahon. To return to the question and the phenomenon of fiscal drag to which Senator Collard has drawn attention, the discredited former Prime Minister featured very heavily in his 1975 election campaign a promise to index automatically the entire income tax schedule so that the phenomenon of fiscal drag would no longer apply. If I remember correctly, that promise lasted for one year. It was then cut by half and in the following year it disappeared, never to be seen again.

ANSWER.PARA: The general theme of this Budget, as the Treasurer stated last night, is one of equity, fairness, fiscal responsibility-of which there was a notable dearth in the dying days of the previous Government-and a reordering of priorities. Even if the figures which were cited by Senator Collard are correct, it is the judgment of the Government that in this time of economic crisis it is quite reasonable to expect that those who are fortunate enough to be employed, particularly those who are employed under somewhat more favourable conditions, might make some contribution to alleviating the plight of those who have been most severely and innocently affected by the depression which was caused partly by external forces and partly by the mismanagement of the previous Government. Last night's Budget has focused its assistance on the people most in need. Throughout it the consistent theme which has been followed is equity, fairness, fiscal responsibility and a reordering of priorities in accordance with the present needs of the nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. In May of this year I asked a question concerning repatriation payments made to Torres Strait Islanders and Aborigines and I was critical of those payments. Since the question and the answer raised the expectations of these people, I ask the Minister whether any progress has been made in this direction.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do recall Senator Georges asking a question in the autumn session about the underpayment, during World War II and subsequently, of Torres Strait Islanders and Australian Aborigines who served in the Australian Army during World War II. At that stage I indicated that I believed the Government had a moral obligation in this respect to rectify the decisions that were made during World War II. I recognise that the honourable senator is one of the leading exponents of the principle of overcoming all forms of discrimination in Australia, and he finds that particularly difficult in a National Party State such as Queensland. However, I undertook to take this matter up with the Government and I am pleased to announce that, as announced in the Budget last night, the Government has agreed to allocate $100,000 for payment to those Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders and their dependants who served in those special units during World War II.

ANSWER.PARA: In my area of repatriation this will cover the differences between what they actually received in disability pension payments between 1943 and 1962 and what they should have received under their full entitlement. This goes some way towards redressing the discriminatory legacy of a most unfortunate World War II decision which was made by a small group in the War Cabinet during that period, not properly endorsed either by the Cabinet or the Parliament at that time but, of course, reflecting the attitude then held by the community that a different rate of pay and benefit should be available to Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders.
