After consultation with the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs I have undertaken to seek the assistance of the National Aboriginal Conference in locating the veterans and their dependants so that our obligations in financial terms in this matter are met.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry and Commerce. In the light of the importance of small business to employment and to the economy within Australia, and in view of the restraints imposed on corporate structures for small businesses under existing legislation, will the Minister confirm that a Small Enterprise Incorporation Bill, as proposed by the Company Directors Association of Australia Ltd and as presented to the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities, will be introduced during this session of Parliament? I point out that this Bill would provide for a new type of business structure which would combine a corporate structure with a limited liability partnership. If such legislation is not to be introduced will the Minister inform the Senate of the action which the Government intends to take in order to relieve the burdens and handicaps imposed upon small businesses by the existing legislation?

—I cannot confirm that a Small Enterprise Incorporation Bill will be introduced in this session of Parliament. I certainly am able to say that the Government will examine that question, but I cannot confirm that legislation along the lines suggested by Senator Jack Evans will be introduced.
—It is not in the list for introduction.

—It is certainly not in the list for introduction. I am indebted to Senator Chaney for his help. The point I am essentially making is that the introduction will be considered but not confirmed in any way. Senator Evans raises the question of assistance to small business generally. There are a number of matters in the Budget and under consideration by the Government in relation to assistance to small business. I will be able to detail those matters at length if Senator Evans requires. But let me say briefly that the question of taxation and retention allowances under Division 7 is under examination by the Government. The small business division of the Department of Industry and Commerce has been established. In due course the Government will make an announcement about a number of other matters, including the consideration of the Espie proposals, which are relevant to small business.

—Will the Minister for Social Security clarify what is meant by the types of assets which will be taken into account in assessing pensioner benefits? There seems to be a great deal of confusion surrounding the $1,500 value placed on assets in the Budget Papers under the heading 'Other Assets'. Does this mean that if a person has $1,500 invested at, say, 10 per cent for a yearly return of $150 or $3 a week his or her pension will be affected?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, indeed, it does not mean that. The only reason that people may think it means that is the misrepresentation of the assets test by honourable members opposite. In fact, under the proposal that the Government has foreshadowed, single pensioners without other income will be able to have $17, 000 in a savings account and still receive a maximum pension. A married couple will be able to have $28,500 in savings and receive the full pension.

ANSWER.PARA: I think it is important to realise that the introduction of an assets test will take about 12 months because of the need to consult and the need to introduce administrative changes. In reverting to an assets test of the type that existed before 1976 certain assets will be excluded, including a pensioner's home, car and other personal possessions such as caravans and boats. We will not count other assets on top of these to the extent of $1,500 for single people and $2, 500 for married people. That is similar to the situation which existed before 1976 when, for the purpose of administrative ease and so that people were able to have at least that amount of money available, $400 and $800 for single and married people respectively were added to those assets.

The assets test is aimed at overcoming the situation whereby certain wealthy people are exploiting and circumventing the existing income test. It is a problem which has been addressed not only by this Government but also by previous governments. One would have to be blind not to realise what is going on . A reading of the financial Press and of various pensioner journals will show numerous advertisements for artificially contrived schemes to enable those in the fortunate position of having large amounts of assets to convert them into capital and therefore avoid the income test as it existed. This is to the detriment of the taxpayer generally and in particular to the detriment of those who are not in that fortunate position and therefore have to cope on a lower pension than one would like.

So the misrepresentation being put about that people with only $1,500 in the bank will have their pensions affected is an unfortunate one. It does not assist sensible debate in this area. One can expect, as one heard this morning, someone like the Premier of Queensland, Mr Bjelke-Petersen, to go on in this way. One would hope that responsible members of the Opposition in this place, who when in government battled with this problem over the years, would take a more responsible attitude.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate or, alternatively, to the Attorney-General. I refer to the undertaking given on 25 June 1978 by the Rt Hon. Malcolm Fraser on behalf of the then Government that the responsible Minister would report within six months of the tabling of a parliamentary committee report indicating the Government's attitude towards recommendations in that report. I draw particular attention to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs entitled 'The Constitutional Qualifications of Members of Parliament' tabled by me on 2 June 1981, to which neither the past nor the present Government have made any considered response. I ask: Does the present Government intend to maintain the undertaking given by the Fraser Government to respond to parliamentary committee reports within six months of tabling? If so, will it ensure that at least an interim response will be given within the period indicating the progress made in processing or implementing the recommendations in a report? Can the Parliament anticipate an early response in respect to the detailed recommendations contained in the Senate Committee's report on the constitutional qualifications of members of Parliament?

—Irrespective of any undertaking given by the previous Government and the previous Prime Minister, the Government has decided that a response to parliamentary committee reports will be made on behalf of the Government by way of a ministerial statement in Parliament. It has been determined by the Government that the period in which such response should be made should be reduced from six months to three months. That has been done because it is desired to make the reports of committees as relevant as possible to any considerations which the Government may have to make in respect of policy matters. The period of response will be reduced from six to three months. In terms of Government responses it may of course be that the response can take the form of only a statement of principle about policy issues raised in the relevant parliamentary report.
—It might be just a reponse you are dealing with.

—Yes. I also make the point that in order to try to meet the time which the Government has imposed on itself when Parliament is not sitting, if it becomes necessary Ministers will be asked to respond in writing to the committee . Senator Missen then asked what would happen in the event of the Government not being able to respond within a three-month period, or a defined period as he put it. Ministers responsible have been requested to advise Parliament accordingly, together with reasons why responses cannot be given. There are certain reports to which the new guidelines determined by the Government do not apply, such as house management reports, reports of the Joint Committee on Public Works, the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House and the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. The last part of Senator Missen's question is appropriately a matter for the Attorney-General. I will ask the Attorney-General to provide an answer as quickly as possible.

—Yesterday at Question Time Senator Chaney asked me a question relating to an argument allegedly advanced by the Government on the question of capacity to pay in the course of national wage cases. The position is that the Commonwealth Government in the national wage case argued the relevance of national economic capacity to pay. In the course of that submission a question was asked whether the Commonwealth should look to an industry's capacity to pay as the determinant for the wage fixing process. The answer given to that question by the Commonwealth counsel was 'no'. The basis for that answer was that if one agrees to that proposition, namely that an industry's incapacity to pay is relevant, then one must also in the course of national wage hearings make available to parties an argument that an industry's capacity to pay is relevant. If one advances incapacity and accepts that as an argument, capacity becomes relevant. In the Government's view that would lead to an encouragement of sectional wage claims where industries are clearly in a position of having the capacity to pay. The Government is determined to avoid sectional wage claims. It is the Goverment's view that there should be national standards and that the centralised wage system to which the Government adheres should not be prejudiced by the capacity to advance sectional wage claims.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Without trespassing too much on the time of the Senate, I will give an answer to Senator Missen's question today about the future of the report of the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs on constitutional qualifications of members of Parliament. That report was languishing for nearly 18 months during the life of the previous Government. There was a question, when we came into office in March, of our giving an immediate response. It was thought preferable not to do so given that the matter was on the agenda for the April Australian Constitutional Convention. It was dealt with by the Constitutional Convention by way of simply referring it to a standing committee for further consideration. Although that consideration will be actively pursued, I understand, there will not be a report from that standing committee until the middle of next year. Under those circumstances it is the Government's intention as quickly as possible to move to give a reply on its response to the recommendations in the report. We will endeavour to do so before mid-September which will be the expiry of at least six months since our coming to office. I assure the honourable senator that how this issue is addressed is a matter of great interest to members and senators. There are many anomalies, many inequities and many instances of unfairness in the way the existing rules operate. It is something which needs priority and we will give it that priority.

QUESTION.PARA: Sitting suspended from 1.10 to 2.15 p.m.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President has received a letter from Senator Chaney proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's adoption of wages policies which will increase unemployment.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has brought before the Senate as a matter of public importance the Government's adoption of wages policies which will increase unemployment. Mr Deputy President, as was observed in Question Time this morning, the Opposition has brought a number of matters of public importance before the Senate and has raised this matter for debate since the Hawke Government took office. Indeed, we have raised it on each of the major economic debates which have occurred in the Senate and in particular on the discussion of the National Economic Summit Conference communique and the economic statement put down by the Government on 19 May. On both of those occasions we pointed out to the Senate and to the Government the very real danger that the Government's policies, whatever other effects they might have, neglected the fundamental task of halting and reversing unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: In a debate which takes place in the context of a Budget having been brought down yesterday it is important to note the significance of the question of wages policy to the general economic performance of Australia. Indeed, on the day of the Budget, in an article which I think Government Ministers could profitably read, the following appeared on the front page of the Australian Financial Review:

While the wages pause has led to a moderation in the growth of labour costs, these costs have continued to rise in the first half of 1983, and the prospects for 1983-84 are that labour costs will rise more rapidly in Australia than they will for our main trading partners. This represents the main threat to Australia achieving a sustained economic recovery over the next two years.

It would be common ground in this place that Australia requires a sustained economic recovery. It is not some partisan Opposition view that there is an unemployment problem in Australia and that the problem is getting worse. The Government's own spokesmen have been very clear in their statements that unemployment in Australia will rise further. In a statement made on 10 July and reported on 11 July, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, confirmed that unemployment will continue, in his words, 'to creep up' next year, despite his prediction of an economic recovery. He predicted at that time that unemployment would not start to 'creep down'-again his words-until 1984-85.
Mr Deputy President, another leading Labor spokesman, Premier Wran, when he was emerging from the aftermath of the Royal Commission in New South Wales a couple of weeks ago said:

The biggest problem for Australia and Australians is that the economy's going to get better but there aren't going to be many more jobs . . . We've all thinking of getting inflation down, holding M3, all these economic indicators, we're grasping bits of the bloody web but no one's worried about the spider because when that's happened the people who are out of work, the bulk of them are going to stay out of work.

I think that is a matter of deep concern to all Australians. It is certainly a matter of deep concern to the Opposition. Last night the Treasurer, Mr Keating, put down a Budget Speech. We heard in that Speech, which was the third of the Government's major economic statements since it took office, that the fears that have been expressed about unemployment are correct. Mr Keating confirms Premier Wran's prediction and Mr Willis's prediction that there will be increased unemployment in Australia. The Budget, on the Treasurer's own confession, is predicated on increased unemployment. The most optimistic gloss that he could put on the situation was to say that the average level of employment this year may not be very different from that of last year.

Budget Statement No. 2, at page 65, puts it more bluntly. It says that there will be an edging up in the rate of unemployment. That report is worthy of reference for many reasons. At page 68, from the comments made on the labour market, one sees that there is great cause for concern about what will happen to employment in this country. They set out clearly that the labour force will grow by 2 per cent while employment might grow by 1 1/2 per cent. On that prediction we will get an addition of another half per cent to the unemployment lists in the course of this financial year.

Mr Deputy President, the debate takes place in the context of a Budget which again, on the face of the documents which have been put before the Parliament by the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins), make it clear how fragile the Government's assumptions, including its assumptions on employment, really are. Budget Statement No. 2, at page 70, notes:

A wages outcome higher than currently assumed would have an especially damaging impact on business confidence and private sector spending propensities. The renewal of pressures on corporate profitability, together with a consequent slackening in private demand, would be likely to manifest itself in a further round of labour shedding and another sharp ratcheting up in the rate of unemployment.

Put simply, the documents put before the Parliament by the Treasurer himself, and by the Minister for Finance, point out that a wages outcome higher than that assumed by the Budget, namely about 7 per cent, will damage business confidence and lead to labour shedding and another sharp ratcheting up in the rate of unemployment. That is something of a message of despair, given the reality of pressures on wages at present and the great difficulty which it is apparent the Government will have in delivering on the accord which it has entered into with the trade union movement.

Mr Deputy President, again, one only needs to look at contemporaneous activities within the wage fixing sector to see how real those difficulties are. A headline in one newspaper on the day of the Budget stated: 'Heinz wages surrender'. That article pointed out that there had been a settlement of the 11- week industrial dispute at H. J. Heinz and Co. Australia Ltd which had added to an emerging $15 to $20 pay rise trend for pay movements outside the wages pause. That is not a lonely example of the sorts of pressures which exist outside the centralised wage fixing system for wage rises which exceed the 7 per cent on which the fragile holding situation of the Budget is predicated. We have that particular example before us. We have also the situation of 130,000 building workers seeking a rise outside the guideline and oil industry workers seeking reimbursement of medical insurance payments and so on. There is a whole series of pressure points on the wage system which it is quite clear present a great challenge to the ability of the system to maintain the situation on which the Budget is purported to be based.

Of course, the Budget is only one of the instruments which the Government has to hand if it wishes to affect the economic performance of Australia. Indeed, at the moment we are seeing something of a diffusion of the instruments which are available to the Government. In the very short life of this Government so far we have had the May economic statement, which made a number of decisions which were of a budgetary nature. We see in the Budget the extension of indexation-upwards, of course, not downwards-to certain taxation arrangements. This will result in biannual adjustments to excise. There is outside the confines of the Budget a whole series of ways in which the Government affects the economy of the country. I refer for instance, to the biannual indexing of pensions and benefits introduced by the previous Government. So a great deal is happening, outside the Budget Statement which was put down by the Treasurer last night, which will affect the vital question of employment and the operation of the economy generally.

In this debate I draw attention particularly to a matter which was raised in Question Time in the Senate yesterday and which was mentioned again today in a supplementary answer given by Senator Button. It relates to the tool which is available to the Government through its appearance before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and the stance which it takes on wages generally before that Commission. I believe it is a matter for grave concern that, despite the overwhelming consensus that the wage pause was useful-and that , of course, is acknowledged in the Budget documents over and over again-and notwithstanding the broad public support which has existed for the wage pause from its very inception, the Government has acceded quite supinely to the request for a full flow on of the consumer price index since March. Support for that 4.3 per cent flow on, on the Government's own statement, will be damaging for employment. Given the outlook for inflation, it is now extremely unlikely that the next indexation flow on, which can be expected next year, can be limited to a total of 7 per cent within the calendar year. Of course it is a total wage rise of 7 per cent which underlies all of the Government's assumption in this Budget.

May I repeat the key assumptions which exist as far as the Budget is concerned and the Government's economic strategy is concerned. The Government assumes a centralised wage system; it assumes half yearly indexation; and it assumes strictly limited sectional claims. The Opposition has raised a warning on frequent occasions about the sectional claims to which I have already referred and no one who has been watching the recent activity by the Builders Labourers Federation, the Australian Workers Union and the Food Processors Union of Australia can avoid the conclusion that they are breaking the bounds of what could be defined as strictly limited sectional claims. This morning there has been newspaper comment on that matter. I believe that this morning's editorial in the Australian Financial Review puts the matter in a nutshell. The editorial states:

Already there is clear evidence that the union movement has no real intention of sticking to centralised wage fixation which delivers only indexation. The H. J. Heinz settlement reached this week is one indication of this. Rather the unions are already moving towards using indexation only as a way of generalising wage increases to weak unions while the stronger ones bargain for sectional increases outside indexation.

We have the facts before us. It is quite clear that unions which see themselves as having a strong bargaining position, unions which can take advantage of the fact that they are in employment and that their employers will try to stay in business, can use the system to obtain claims which are outside the centralised wage fixing system and at the same time use the centralised wage fixing system to obtain general claims, even when those claims have to be paid by industries which cannot afford them.

The National Economic Summit Conference gave us many useful contributions to economic debate and we should all go back and read the speech which was made by Mr Fitzgibbon, the Deputy President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. He made the point very forcefully that a centralised wage fixing system meant something to which there were no exceptions. One received the rises that were awarded by the central authority and not any others. It is quite clear that large sections of the trade union movement, without any serious or significant opposition from the Government, are flouting that principle.

One might also think that the future of indexation is in doubt when one looks at the effect of the shift in the figures which the Government achieves through the change to Medicare. It will be interesting to see how long it takes the unions to realise that the predicted 7 per cent to 7 1/2 per cent increase in the CPI is something of a con job based on the exclusion of those Medicare costs because of the way the Australian Statistician works on the CPI. It will be interesting, too, to see how social security beneficiaries respond to indexation which is made on the same basis when they are not subject to charges for their medical costs at the moment.

The consequences of the mishmash which we have in this area at the moment needs to be spelt out with great clarity. It is clear, on the Government's own statements, that the Government's permissive stance on wages is in itself a guarantee of continuing and increasing unemployment. That is true even if all of the assumptions on which the Budget is based hold true. The Government tells us that we will have continuing and increasing unemployment. Second, it is quite clear, on what the Government has told us, that even if there are wage increases outside what we would regard as that quite permissive stance then the outlook for employment is even worse, and the evidence is that we will get those increases. I believe that the Opposition, and the Australian people who have so recently elected this Government, are entitled to ask: Does this Government really care about unemployment? Indeed, the Government's arguments before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission suggest that it does not care two hoots about the unemployed in Australia. It certainly cares about the situation of those employed who believe that they should be getting more, but it accepts that they can get more at the cost of those who are unemployed.

If I may touch on the question which I raised during Question Time yesterday, and to which I got some response in a supplementary question from Senator Button this afternoon, dealing with the industry's capacity to pay, this Goverment's counsel, speaking on behalf of Mr Hawke and his Ministers before the Commission, argued strongly against any consideration being given to capacity to pay. Counsel summed up his arguments as follows:
In any economic circumstances marginal firms or industries will experience economic difficulties. This is part of the normal process of growth and readjustment within the economy.
The Government sees no compelling reason why these firms or industries should be subsidised by the wage system.

What an extraordinary proposition to be put forward by the Hawke Labor Government. It is suggesting that if an employer is in economic difficulties, if he is in a marginal situation, if he might be about to sack his workers, then tough luck; he will wear the wage increases which are granted because otherwise he would be subsidised by the wage system. What an extraordinary argument to be put forward on behalf of a Labor Government which should be concerned about unemployment. That sort of logic pervades the whole of the Government's approach to the national wage case, and indeed, the supplementary answer that Senator Button gave to the Senate today highlights the logical problem for the Government in this whole area. Senator Button pointed out to us-I do not yet have a full record of his reply-that if we look at the industry's capacity to pay, if we agree that the capacity of an industry to pay is a reason for refusing a wage rise which cannot be afforded by that industry, then we will encourage people who work in more profitable industries to seek sectional wage claims outside the centralised system. I agree with that. I think that is a correct statement of the difficulty the Government faces. But it is simply not good enough to pose that difficulty, to pose that dilemma; to say that the Government's hands are tied and that the Commission's hands are tied; to say that we simply have to put up with the fact that where an industry cannot afford to pay its workers at the present rates of pay or cannot afford any increases, those increases will have to be granted in any event in the interest of some sort of wage justice.
Mr Justice Issaacs, during the hearing, asked this perfectly reasonable question:
To what extent can a centralised system operate if there are breaches of the guidelines outside the system taking place?
The reply by Government's counsel was:

. . . when that problem arises it is precisely the sort of problem that we would see as appropriate to be addressed when the review of the principles, which we would hope arises out of this decision, occurs . . .

Those words are cold comfort to those people who are told they must pay wage rises which will close down their place of work and which will ensure that further jobs are lost. It appears to be quite clear that a government which is committed to the submissions that this Government is putting to the Arbitration Commission at the moment has no commitment to reducing unemployment, and it is eminently clear from the Budget that this Government certainly has no program to reduce unemployment in Australia. The Government predicts a rise in unemployment . Labor spokesmen, from Mr Willis to Mr Wran, accept it as a fact of life.

The usual response from Senator Button in these debates is to complain about the Fraser Government. I can only say to him that I hope that he heeds the words of Mr Keating who pointed out in an interview this morning that the members of the Government 'have engaged ourselves in an enormous clearing exercise to clear away a very large part of the programs of the former Government.' He continued:
What we have done is to put in place thereof the expenditure priorities of the present Government.

I should like to remind Senator Button that this Government, the Hawke Government, has set aside the wage pause which its own documents acknowledge was one of the positive effects on economic affairs in Australia in 1983. We are now living in an Australia which is governed by the Hawke Government. The policies of that Government are in place and it can no longer blame the previous Government for what has gone before. I commend to the Senate the words at page 70 of the Budget statements which point out-I read part of them before-that a wages outcome higher than the 7 per cent assumed can lead to another sharp ratcheting up in the rate of unemployment. It appears that under the policies of the Hawke Government that is what we have before us. As far as wages policy is concerned the Hawke Government has rejected the wages freeze which was supported by the Australian people. It has embraced anti-employment policies. There was one message of comfort for the unemployed in the Budget last night-a rise in the unemployment benefit. Of course, the Opposition welcomes that message of comfort but it says to the Government that that is not the message that the unemployed of Australia wanted. They wanted a message that the Hawke Government would set about fulfilling its promise to reduce unemployment in Australia. That is what is sought and demanded. The Government must find a wages policy which will reduce unemployment. It must work out how it can apply such a policy. It must not apply policies which will increase unemployment as it has persisted in doing since it was elected in March of this year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President--
—Where are your troops? Press the button.
—I am asked where my supporters are in this matter. I think they are probably bored with Senator Chaney's contribution to this Blue Hills debate and have left the chamber.
—So are the unemployed.

—Senator Chaney makes that statement on the basis of five months experience in opposition and seven years in government. In the course of this debate he will not, by reading some totally irrelevant statement that Mr Keating made this morning, stop me from discussing the seven years which the Fraser Government--
—What about the three dark years of Whitlam?

—If I might say so, that is a good interjection, because Senator Sir John Carrick, if he speaks in this debate, will no doubt crank that up. But the fact of the matter is that the seven years of Fraser Government have vital relevance to current economic policy and Government wages policy. In the course of his remarks Senator Chaney seemed to be saying that the one policy on wages that seems to have had some success was that which was characterised as the ' need to be seen to be doing something' policy. He suggested that that policy, I suppose, be extended. Is that the Opposition's view? Is that Mr Howard's view? I think it is Mr Howard's view. Is it Mr Macphee's view? I do not think it is his view. The Opposition comes here with no coherent view other than the implicit suggestion that if it were in Government the wages freeze would be extended. Would it be extended for another six months or another 12 months? As I have been reminded by Liberal Party spokesmen in earlier stages of this debate, the whole issue is that of the competitiveness of Australian industry. Both in government and in opposition the Liberal Party has had only two things to say about that issue. The competitiveness of Australian industry is dependent on wages policy or, alternatively, on industrial relations policy. One of those two policies can be blamed for the lack of competitiveness of Australian industry. That argument went on for seven years and it is still going on as if the Opposition had learnt nothing. Of course, the two policies, wages and industry, are very much related.

SPEECH.PARA: I would have thought that the debate might now be broadened to include a number of other issues when examining the competitiveness of Australian industry. Such issues include: Investment in industry; on-wage costs-not wage costs-which are very high in Australia; industrial unrest, which has been a factor militating against the competitiveness of Australian industry; and the level of inflation. All of these things, to mention but four, might be relevant to the issue of competitiveness and the capacity of Australian industry to sell its products and employ people in those industries. I concede quite frankly that if the national wage Bench this year determines a wage increase which amounts to full indexation that will create difficulties for some Australian industries in some areas. I concede that. That is not shrunk from by anybody who is concerned about this issue. I think Opposition senators know that. The point involves what a Government is to do on balance in a period of economic recovery in terms of ensuring as far as possible that wage levels and increases in wages do not get back to the sorts of figures which we saw in 1981 and 1982. In 1981, for example , there was a 15 per cent increse in wages in Australia. In 1982, there was an 11 per cent increase. In Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries during each of those years the equivalent figure was about 9 per cent. If we average the figures out for the two years the Australian figure is 26 per cent and the OECD figure is 18 per cent. According to the wildest predictions which can be extracted from either the Budget Papers or any other comment which has been made, in 1984 the level of wage increases in Australia will be 0.5 of a per cent above the OECD average for the same period. In our view that is a vast improvement on the pattern of the past. The main objection which the Opposition has to the Government's wages policy, from what one can guess, is that it is different from what it might have done in similar circumstances. Had the Opposition been in government, I suppose it would have extended the wages pause. No other suggestion has ever flowed from the Opposition as to what might have been done about wages.

I refer very briefly to the likely outcome of the national wage case. I cannot be sure what the national wage Bench will do. I put it to the Senate earlier that the Government's approach is based on balancing short and longer term economic and industrial relations considerations, both of which are relevant to the future success of Australian industry. There is a no extra claims provision which the Government has argued for which will provide employers with economic and industrial stability. We have already had questions in the Senate from Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle yesterday about the so-called Heinz settlement and again suggestions from Senator Chaney today about the increase in relation to the building industry. The building industry increase has to go before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission before it is dealt with. The Government will intervene in that case in the public interest. The Heinz claim has to go before the Arbitration Commission in the context of any outcome of a national wage case. As I said before, the Government will intervene in that case before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. It is not the Government's intention to allow sectoral claims. It might be open to the Opposition to wish that the Government's position on that does not succeed. I am not sure that that is helpful, but the Government is determined that that position will succeed in relation to sectoral claims made outside the centralised wage fixation system.

The Government would argue that extending the existing wage pause is simply not sustainable in the light of what Senator Chaney in his speech referred to as pressures in the wages system. What would the Fraser Government have done about those pressures? Would it have passed another law to penalise unions in some way ? Is that how it would have dealt with the pressures in the wages system? The Opposition passed 11 such laws in its seven years in Government and the pressures in the wages system were never worse than in 1981 and 1982, its last two years in government. What would the Opposition do to alleviate pressures in the wages system, as Senator Chaney calls them? Would it pass another piece of wage freeze legislation? I do not believe that that argument has any viability or logic at all. Any attempts to continue the wages pause can result only in the sort of leapfrogging that has gone on in the past and which is building up and occurring as the economy recovers.

I make just one point about a matter of fact that Senator Chaney dealt with: I ask the honourable senator next time we have this debate not to confuse a projected 7 per cent increase in earnings with a 4 1/2 per cent projected increase in wages, because there is a difference. There is a considerable difference between an increase in earnings, which Senator Chaney talked about, and an increase in wages. That is a different thing altogether.

I say this about the Government's attitude, because it is not perhaps quite clear: First, the Government is committed to a return to the centralised wage fixation system for the sorts of reasons which I have suggested. The Government is committed to an effective prices and incomes policy. It may be that that policy will fail. However, the time to criticise us is when that policy fails. The Opposition should not indulge in dire prognostications. It is buoyant and excited with gloom at the prospect of the Government's wages policy failing. Nothing turns the Opposition on or makes it happier than the prospect of the Government's wages policy failing. That has been the point of the last three, I think, matters of public importance we have had on this question.

In talking about a centralised system and an incomes and prices policy, the Government is concerned to avoid the confrontational approach of the previous Government. Discounting of indexation of wages occurred in 12 out of 18 decisions between 1975 and 1981. The then Government's attitude finally destroyed wage indexation in 1981. Although there was a minor upturn in the economy in 1980-1981 there was no rational and equitable approach to wage fixation. There were increases of 15 per cent and 11 per cent in those two years . The problem was aggravated by Government indecision and conflict between Senior Ministers in the Government. The consequent wage pause was introduced as a matter of panic and had disastrous effects in terms of inequities for low income earners. No prices surveillance was considered. There was no policy, and there still is no policy, for coming out of the wages pause. So it remains a problem for the Opposition to advance a coherent and rational argument against the Government's position.

In terms of Government policy, there has been an extended period without adjustment of general award wages in Australia. A year will have passed by the time the national wage case decision is known. Let me just say that in terms of the many other factors which are irrelevant to an industry's capacity to pay, to produce goods and to employ people, nothing has happened as a result of the wages pause in terms of investment policy and so on. It is time now to establish a viable and equitable system of wage determination before the economy moves into a period of expansion. This is necessary on both equity and practical grounds. We want a lasting system. We want to escape from the ad hockery of the previous Government. The Government advanced support for full indexation in its submission to the national wage case. It went on to say that we would not expect any review of real wage levels until late 1984. No 'extra claims' measures have been suggested to the Commission and these, of course, have been referred to during Question Time in the Senate.

On the question of growth in wages, both independent and Government estimates suggest a much lower increase in award wages in 1983 and 1984 than in previous years if this Government's policy is followed. Average weekly earnings for 1983- 84-Senator Chaney referred to this-are estimated to rise by about 7 per cent, representing a marked slowing down from the 11 per cent of last year. That estimate is supported not only by the Government in its Budget Papers but also, for example, by the Victorian Chamber of Manufactures, which put a slightly lesser figure on it in its economic outlook statement of two or three weeks ago. So, in looking at the potential rate of wage increases and earnings increases in 1983-84, I just want to say that the Government's policy is in general line with the views which were enunciated at the National Economic Summit Conference. Government policy, if agreed to by the Arbitration Commission, will result in award wage increases of 5 per cent in both 1983 and 1984, compared with 15 per cent an 11 per cent in 1981 and 1982 respectively. This is a vast improvement when one looks at the other factors which are relevant to the broad question of unemployment.

I turn to the question of employment under the previous Government. Seven years of the previous Government saw an initial period of virtual stagnation in employment give way to a final period of unprecedented absolute declines in employment. The traditional approach to economic management based on the indirect control of prices and wages by restrictive fiscal and monetary policy has succeeded in effectively stalling the long term growth of jobs for Australians. From 1976 to 1983 employment grew by less than three quarters of one percent and teenagers and older workers had absolute falls in employment during that period. The combination of the failure of growth in employment and continued growth in the labour force meant that the level of unemployment doubled-up 118.4 per cent in the seven years to February 1983. This happened despite a substantial decline in the level of labour force participation in that period.

The consequences of those disastrous policies, both in terms of wage fixation and unemployment figures, have of course been reaped by this Government. We came into government, as the newsletter of the sharebrokers, Potter Partners, put it, with the worst economy this country had seen for 50 years. The ex-Treasurer, who now talks about this Budget with such concern, is rightly concerned because the parameters of this Budget, both in terms of what this Government could do about unemployment and this Government's capacity to deal with the wages issue on the basis of its own assumptions about wages policy, were very much determined by the actions of the previous Government.

This matter of public importance has been raised often and no doubt it will be raised again. If I might say so without undue patronage, the standard of the debate is improving and more issues are being raised that are relevant to the vital question which I believe sincerely concerns all Australians. But a very highly speculative argument was advanced by Senator Chaney today--

TALK.START.PARA: —You should not wait till it is all over to argue about it. You are arguing in prospect.

—I am sure the honourable senator will do both: He will argue in prospect and he will wait till it is all over. I am not sure which gives him the most pleasure. But I am not sure whether arguing in prospect will in the longer term give him the most pleasure. I summarise by saying that this Government has commitments in respect of employment. It has never shrunk from the fact that these commitments would not be easily dealt with. But this Government also has commitments in terms of other factors which affect the capacity of industry in this country. Those factors, amongst others, include a desirable, stable and predictable industrial relations environment and a desirable, stable and predictable economic environment-something which industry in this country has not had for years. It is in that context that the Government embarked on its present wages policy. It is in that context that it will pursue it. It is in that context that it will insist that the wages policy which has been enunciated will be carried out by all concerned. We reject the nexus which is drawn artificially in this matter of public importance between the two issues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: -The Senate is debating a matter of public importance, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's adoption of wages policies which will increase unemployment.

The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) has complained and has chastised the Opposition for raising this matter as though it is unimportant . He further chastised the Opposition for raising it during the all too short autumn sitting of this Parliament. I would have thought that the Leader of the Government would have said: 'This is singly one of the most important issues facing Australia and I am glad that the Opposition is showing concern about it'. I would have thought that the Leader of the Government would have been more positive by indicating some of the things that the Government proposes to do rather than chastise and lecture us, advocating, as he did, the sorts of measures which we have been advocating for years and which this Budget, in its strategy, does not in any way implement.

It is all very fine for Senator Button to come into the chamber and say that we need to restore competitiveness and that we need to ensure that there is a reduction in wage on-costs; that need to ensure that militancy in the workplace is reduced, that inflation is reduced and that Australia's competitive position in relation to its Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development partners is not higher than the average but lower than the average. All of those things we have been saying repeatedly in debates on matters which we have raised in this chamber both before the last election and certainly since the election. Senator Button has adopted our rhetoric and apparently has adopted our policies but has done nothing to persuade his colleagues, in particular the newly discredited Treasurer, Mr Keating-I am adopting what Senator Walsh has been saying about others for some time-of the importance of the points about which he has been lecturing us. He has singularly failed in any attempt to persuade Mr Keating.

If we look at the wages policy of this Government and the effect that it has on unemployment the first thing we should look at are some sections of the accord upon which the wages policy is based. The first quote I should like to read to honourable senators appears at page 9 of the accord. It states:
The maintenance of real wages is agreed to be a key objective. It is recognised that in a period of economic crisis as now applying that this will be an objective over time.

I wonder, therefore, what sort of time scale the Government is talking about. Whereas the accord said that there would have to be some recognition that there could not be maintenance of real wages during the crisis period, what is proposed by this Budget is a maintenance of real wages during the crisis period; that is, unless the Government is suggesting that the crisis is over. Nothing in its economic projections indicates that the Government believes that. One of the factors which appears throughout the whole of the Budget document is the difference between the Government's rhetoric about what it says it is trying to achieve and the economic projections, particularly those of its advisers in the Treasury. The accord goes on to state:
Accordingly it is agreed:
To protect the purchasing power of wages and salaries the adoption of a system of full cost of living adjustments will be strongly supported in tripartite consultants and before industrial tribunals.
It also states:

In formulating claims for improved wages and conditions at the national level the unions will have regard to government economic policy and will consult with the Government on the amount of such claims.

Obvious to everyone in Australia is the fact that this part of the accord has already broken down quite disastrously. The Leader of the Opposition in the Senate has already referred to a number of the aspects of that breakdown. Let me summarise by saying that we have seen in particular the agreement between H. J. Heinz and Co. Ltd and its workers to which I believe the Leader of the Government referred. We have seen the reimbursement of medical insurance payments as part of an agreement in relation to building workers. We have seen the Altona Petrochemical Co. Ltd building workers agreement. Average weekly earnings are forecast to increase seven per cent year on year compared with the consumer price index rise of about 7.5 per cent. That, of course, leaves out all of the separate agreements which appear to be flourishing in Australia notwithstanding anything that may have been said in the accord. It is relevant to refer to an article by Bob Carr in the current issue of the Bulletin which was published today and which stated:
Wages policy could well become the bane of the Hawke Government, as it became for the Whitlam Government half way through its life.
It states further:

The Australian Workers' Union in New South Wales and the Electrical Trades' Union in New South Wales and Victoria have lodged claims based on the building industry agreement. It is too early to say if these claims amount to a new wages push. But, on the other hand, they suggest scepticism about any assertion that the building settlement can be fenced in.
Current wage pressures in the industrial system can be summarised as:
Government support for full indexation for the March and June quarters this year;
The new $17 to $19 standard at tradesman-level set in the building industry.

That such pressure has built up in a depressed economy is further proof of the resilience of wages in the Australian industrial relations system. It offers little hope that when the economy picks up the government can persuade unions to temper pay claims.

That is an expression of a view of concern which I think is held by most commentators who look at what is the difference between what the Government has said and agreed, what it is in fact doing and what is in fact happening. In addition to the parts of the accord to which I have already referred I wish to refer briefly to pages 5 and 6 on which it is stated:

Government taxation and expenditure policies also markedly affect the distribution of real disposable incomes. Traditionally LNCP Government's policies have considerably increased the inequity of that distribution.

Current and past policies of the Fraser Government are completely repudiated by the parties to this statement as manifestly unfair; they promote industrial confrontation and they provide no effective resolution of the fundamental economic problem of achieving low unemployment with low inflation.

All of this is very fine except that the previous Opposition critcised some of the major points in the former Government's policies. It said that they increased the inequities of distribution and created unemployment. They are the very things which this Government is implementing in the Budget it has brought in and in the policies which it is adopting. I turn to what the pressures on wages will be in the forthcoming year. One of the aspects of this pressure is described by Mr Risstrom, the Secretary of the Australian Taxpayers Association as staggering. On the national Today show on television this morning, he said:
Now the effect on the typical family is staggering . . . a staggering 16 per cent increase in tax this year.
He was asked the question:
That could have put pressure on the prices and incomes accord. If the Australian work force says we are not going to cop this, we want more, then the budget is in trouble.
Mr Risstrom replied:
Yes, I believe that it is.

He referred to the fact that there was a $2 billion addition to the tax bill last May. A lot of the impact and the pressures on the wages system in Australia are not just the product of the Budget which was introduced last night but rather the product of the mini-Budget introduced in May. When those effects are taken cumulatively we find that scenario A of the National Economic Summit Conference-it has already been exceeded by nearly 50 per cent-will be exceeded by far more than the 50 per cent which this Budget projects.

There is an upward trend in unemployment which is acknowledged in the Budget. In the Budget's economic assessments the fact is that the growth in demand for jobs will be greater than the creation of jobs which will result in a net half a per cent or something like 35,000 extra unemployed people in the next 12 months. The point that I think has to be made is that criticism has been made of the wages pause policy which was implemented by the former Government. It has been successful because the downward trend in wages, the breaking of the disastrous trends in Australia, came as a direct result of that wages pause. The fact is that from early this year until the middle of this year there was an expectation -in fact, the figures reveal this-that the downslide had bottomed out. Two things happened: The wages pause had its effect and there was an effect from the upturn in world trade and the breaking of the drought. Those things had nothing to do with this Government's wages and incomes accord. Insofar as Australia could take advantage of them, this was the product of the former Government's wage pause-now so discredited by this Government. In substitution of that wages pause, the Government wishes to put in place something which, if I had more time , I could show is inherently unlikely to succeed because of the tremendous pressures on wages in Australia that will result from this Budget.

The possible effect of the withholding tax on small business employment, unless that measure is cleaned up, is one more matter to which reference has not been made. Undoubtedly, the huge demands imposed by government and semi-government borrowings on the capital markets of Australia will, unless the Government is saved miraculously by an inflow of capital from overseas, have a tremendous impact on interest rates, which will in turn have a further impact on inflation.

Insofar as projections go, page 66 of the Budget Speech gives some indication that public sector employment will be down, because capital expenditure is down in real terms. Therefore, this government is not investing as much in the provision of capital and the employment which it creates; rather, it is approaching the probem from the point of view of making handouts. It is saying that it would rather pay somebody a bit extra for being unemployed than create real employment. Public sector borrowing amounted last year to 6 per cent of gross domestic product. This year it will amount to 8 per cent, which means that it is up by 33 1/3 per cent. That pressure would be serious enough without the fact that GDP fell last year and is anticipated to grow this year. Those facts will have a cumulative effect, making the increase in the pressure imposed by public sector borrowing much greater than 33 1/3 per cent. There is to be an increase in the deficit and an indexation of outgoings such as pensions which, during times of inflation, is bound to have an effect upon the need to raise further taxes. Simply put, greater indexation of excise will not provide the extra revenue needed and the net result will be further pressure on wages.

So far as jobs are concerned, an alarming prospect is created by the various Budget projections. I refer, for example, to that for the textile industry. The anticipated bounty payment for that industry will suffer a net 10 per cent drop. In other words, there will be a 10 per cent reduction in the production that is eligible. I do not have time to go through the other areas of policy to show the large number in respect of which a drop in assistance is projected. If one takes inflation into account, the maintenance of bounty or assistance payments at the same level represents a significant reduction in support. We have the disaster of some of the aspects of the steel package, particularly as it impacts on wages policy. The Government agreed to the unions building in further automatic increases at consumer price index levels-the very antithesis of the prospect that was in view for Australia had the wage pause been maintained. The unions have given some quid pro quo so far as productivity is concerned but that has no real sanction. They have given no quid pro quo for the protection which the industry is receiving, that is in relation to wages, one of the things which has built into Australian industry a lack of competitiveness, as demonstrated by the impact which the 28 per cent increase in the metal trades industry had. It was followed immediately by a drop in metal industry jobs of 82,000 in a period of 12 months.

I agree completely with what Senator Button said about the importance of Australia getting back to a competitive state, about the importance of a number of those issues which he identified as being significant. But none of them are taken into account in the Budget. Nor are they taken into account in the Government's wages policy or its wages accord. All of the pressures which can be identified at the moment are pressures for a break in the prices and incomes accord and the whole Budget is predicated on the basis that that will hold. Inevitably, the pressures will blow out this Budget, which will reduce job opportunities even further. Already the Government is projecting an increase in unemployment of 35,000. We believe that if this policy is pursued the figure will certainly be far in excess of that Government projection.

Time does not permit the further identification of the various aspects of the ironical position in which we find ourselves-a government that says one thing, which sounds quite good, but clearly does something else which will have a disastrous effect. I support the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) in submiting this matter of public importance for discussion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find this matter of public importance to be a very narrow proposition indeed. It implies that the level of wage costs is the only cause of changes in labour market conditions and the only cause of changes in unemployment levels. Of course that is not so. The level of wage costs is just one factor amongst others. It just suits the Opposition to talk about wage costs being a cause of unemployment. It fits the Opposition rhetoric; it is as simple as that. There are a number of causes of labour market slack and high unemployment levels. The Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, has referred to the sheer lack of competitiveness of sections of Australian industry. I would like also to draw attention to the absolute low levels of aggregate demand in the economy at the moment. If there is one thing that is reducing demand for labour at the moment, it is the shortage of aggregate demand and, particularly, the low levels of investment and capital spending. Those things have been conveniently ignored by the Opposition, which seeks to focus entirely on wage costs as the cause of unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like also to examine the wording of the proposal before the Senate as a matter of public importance because it refers particularly to the concept of increasing unemployment. I am especially surprised that this Opposition should talk about increasing unemployment as though it was something that had happened in just the last couple of months. The electorate knows full well that rising unemployment has been with us for some time. Indeed, the former Government now occupies the Opposition benches because it was repudiated by the electorate as a result of rising unemployment last year. For example, in April 1982 436,000 people were unemployed in Australia. In April 1983, a staggering 707,000 people were unemployed. That was an enormous, unprecedented rise. A 60 per cent increase in unemployment in Australia in one year had never before been experienced.

That rise, by itself, has done enormous damage to the Liberal Party in the long term because for so long its members traded on the myth that they were the only competent economic managers; they were the people who knew how to run the economy; they were the people who could keep demand at high levels, keep production at high levels and keep unemployment at low levels. Of course that myth was abolutely destroyed in the space of 12 months in 1982, and they will find it very difficult to recover lost ground.

This Labor Government, unlike the previous Government, or this Opposition, has a labour market policy. The former Government fuelled wage rises in 1981 an 1982 by talk of the resources boom. We know what happened to the resources boom, but the former Government bid up wages in the market by such talk. All it could offer was the concept of the wages pause-a concept that was pulled out of the hat like a rabbit for the Premiers Conference in December last year. The only thing that Government could come up with during the chaotic rise in unemployment which occurred last year was some sort of holding operation. Basically, it was a gimmick for the election. It was designed to hang together for only a few months and tide the Government over its very difficult election passage. But of course the former Government did nothing to identify or explain what would happen after the wages pause ended. That was the big question. The then questions asked by the electorate were: What is going to happen after the wages pause? Is there going to be a market forces approach and decentralised wage fixing? That was the approach of the former Treasurer, Mr Howard, who believed in market forces. He believed in a decentralised approach to wage fixation, reflecting the rather Friedmanite ideas that were permeating the Government at that time.

On the other hand, was a centralised wage system to follow the end of the wages pause? Was there going to be a return to the former system, whereby the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission had an overview of wages in Australia, which had been gradually eroded? That was the position supported by the former Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Macphee, and it was radically opposed to the view put forward by the former Treasurer who believed in a decentralised or market forces approach to wages setting. That would have led to many members of the community being left out. Was there to have been support for indexation after the end of the wages pause? Was it intended to gain support for this and make it stick? These questions were never addressed. No answers were ever given.

We in the Government do have a wages policy. In fact, I wish to castigate the Opposition on this matter of public importance because, as I have said, it is very narrow. We have something better than a wages policy; we have an incomes policy. I think it is about time the Opposition woke up to the fact that there are other incomes in the community besides wages. The Opposition might advance its cause enormously in the electorate if it were to address itself to the twentieth century and talk about incomes policies. I do not think the Opposition has any policies over prices, dividends, other non-wage incomes and rents. Does the Opposition have any policies regarding those things? All the Opposition can do is talk about wages and the cost of incomes earned by blue collar workers. We have a more comprehensive policy than the Opposition. It is a more equitable policy. Unfortunately, the Opposition still thinks in sectional terms. It lives in the past. It looks only at wages. All sections of the community should bear the burden if there are to be cuts in the growth of incomes.

Within the incomes policy we favour a centralised wage fixing system. We reject the market forces, decentralisation approach which was pursued by some sections of the former Government. I remind the Senate that the centralised wage fixing concept was endorsed by all State Ministers for labour at a conference which was held in May this year. I am not quite sure how the Premiers would react to the mishmash of ideas and concepts spraying around in the Opposition at the moment. The incomes policy is a feature of the accord with the Australian Council of Trade Unions. It is our strategy to reduce inflation and unemployment simultaneously, instead of the old so-called 'fight inflation first' policy which we had to put up with for five or seven years. That policy was bankrupt. The central strategy of fighting inflation first was sales tax increases. Sales taxes were increased by record levels. Our policy is to allow controlled expansion of demand in order to boost economic activity without large inflationary pressures. The accord was an historic first. It attempted to establish, by mutual agreement, non-inflationary income settlement arrangements. It related to incomes, not just wages. I remind the Opposition that many sorts of incomes beside wages affect costs. The accord gives scope for an expansionary fiscal policy.

The Government's support for centralised wage fixing and wage indexation gives wage earners confidence that the particular system will endure. It is a strategy to keep down sectional wage pressures. That is why the Government has supported quarterly wage indexation for the March and June quarters in the Arbitration Commission. Such an approach gives predictability in the wage system and, along with higher demand, gives employers more certainty about investment, production and employment decisions. Greater certainty will mean more investment. Confidence is returning amongst employers. The Government's major initiatives to date, including the National Economic Summit Conference and the currency devaluation-to give added protection from imports-have added to confidence amongst employers.

Let us look at the economy as it is now. Since April this year there has been an increase in employment of 41,000. I remind the Opposition that for the same period last year the level of employment actually fell. Unemployment has been stable, in seasonally adjusted terms, for four consecutive months-that is, from April to July. Before that we had an inexorable increase month after month; the figure just went up and up. For the corresponding period last year, unemployment , in seasonally adjusted terms, rose from 6 per cent to over 10 per cent. That was a very poor record indeed.

There has been a very strong increase in dwelling approvals in Australia in the last two recorded months. There was positive growth in May and June compared with the corresponding months of the previous year. Before that time there had been 19 consecutive months in which there were annual falls in dwelling approvals. The Budget has been introduced in that context. It will boost employment and give a major fiscal stimulus. The structural domestic deficit- that is, the deficit in the domestic economy excluding overseas transactions- will be much more expansionary. This shows the impact of the Budget on the economy without the effect of the economy on the Budget being brought into the calculations. The stimulus to the economy will be around $2,600m this financial year over and above last financial year. It actually moves the Budget into a positive stimulus phase rather than a contractionary situation as applied last financial year under the previous Government. The key elements of the Budget include a direct job creation program, that is, the community employment program ; a very imaginative housing scheme to boost home ownership by enabling people to borrow more money from building societies and savings banks; a program of bounties for the steel industry valued at around $70m; and a major and overdue increase in capital works programs.

The Premiers Conference endorsed the overall Budget parameters. The Budget will boost employment this financial year by 1.5 per cent compared with the 1.4 per cent decline last year under the former Government. There will be a turnaround from negative employment growth to positive employment growth. One hundred and thirty thousand jobs will be created this financial year. This is the first instalment of the creation of half a million jobs over the three-year life of the Government.

This Government does have a strategy to deal with unemployment. It has an incomes policy, not just a wages policy, of which the Opposition is so fond. The Government has an incomes policy, plus fiscal stimulus. The 1982-83 Budget actually withdrew funds from the economy. As I have indicated, this Budget will turn that around to the extent of $2,500m. That means that $2,500m more will be in circulation in the economy. That is the way to get the economy moving. That is the way to boost employment. That is the way to reduce the blight of unemployment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a moment of the Senate's time to convey the compliments of the Australian Democrats and, I am sure all honourable senators, on this historic occasion at the arrival of a lady at the table. It is my understanding that this is the first time we have had a female Clerk and we hope it is the forerunner of many more such occasions.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —I am concerned at the tenor of the debate on the matter of public importance. I know we have heard it all before. I know we are dragging out the old rhetoric, but it concerns me that today, during one of Australia's greatest economic crises and with the worst unemployment situation we have had, the best that some people can do is to try once more to find some old scapegoats . Will we go back to the last Government and blame Howard and Fraser? Will we go back before that and blame Whitlam? Will we go back to perhaps Menzies, Chifley or Barton? How far back will we go to find a scapegoat for the present economic and employment situation? My concern is that in looking for scapegoats rather than looking for solutions-I believe there is one solution which stands out above all others-we will unfortunately continue to drag not only this Parliament apart but also the whole country and take a great risk at destroying what might become an ecomonic recovery, given some support and assistance from all sides of this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I will be quite happy to enter into the debate on the Budget in due course, at which time I will certainly make it clear that as far as the Democrats are concerned the Government has muffed its chance to improve the employment situation in the coming 12 months. We believe it could have presented a stimulating Budget last night instead of the stagnant status quo Budget which was presented. Plenty of avenues could have been entered by this Government to improve the employment situation within the next 12 months instead of asking everybody to hold his breath for another 12 months while the Government allows Australia to catch up with the rest of the world.

It is fair to suggest that the Government does have an employment policy as well as a prices and incomes policy. The problem with those policies is their fragility. They will become even more fragile if we continue to denigrate the approach which the Government is taking, particularly in trying to bring together what would normally be the quite disparate approaches of employers and employees. I am worried that in bringing on this matter the Opposition may be seen in the outside world to be deliberately undermining the policy of the Government. I do not think it is in a position to do that because it is itself bereft of a policy. Its only policy on unemployment and the economy when it was in Government was to use it as a weapon to reduce inflation. The results of those policies, of course, were quite disastrous. In the context of this matter the results are self-evident. The Opposition needs to note this. Over the last couple of years average weekly earnings have increased. In 1980-81 they went up by 3.7 per cent in real terms. In 1981-82 they went up by 3.8 per cent, and in 1982-83 by 0.4 per cent. Of course the bulk of the reason for that was the wages pause.

I compliment the Opposition-the Government as it was then-for introducing the wages pause, but that was the beginning and the end of its policy. There was no way of coming out of that wages pause. That was the tragedy that led to the last election because there was no policy with which to escape from the wages pause. There was no forecasting, no predicting and no planning for escape. We finished up instead going to the people and asking them either to return that Government and possibly to follow the same policy after that election, or to elect a new government of a different complexion which would follow with a new policy. The people have chosen a government with a different approach. I am suggesting that the Senate needs to be conscious of the potential harm that it can do not just to the Government but to the policies which may get Australia out of its economic recession.

If this policy remains intact-there is a possibility that it may-we can avoid the excessive increases in wages. I am the first to acknowledge that those excessive increases would cost jobs. On the other hand excessive constraint would equally cost jobs because the restraint would lead undoubtedly to industrial pressures. It would lead to strikes and to the Opposition doing what it did in Government, would honourable senators believe, and going overseas and preaching to the world that this is a country on which one cannot rely because of its industrial record. That was tragic for us. Speaking as a Western Australian senator, I can assure honourable senators that even when our Premier went overseas and talked to overseas customers about the effects of industrial disharmony in this country, he created the atmosphere which led to our loss of iron ore orders this year. It is time that we all behaved as Australians and stopped this bickering, this nonsense which unfortunately is communicated overseas once we get into an industrial conflict situation. We should endeavour to create industrial harmony.

It is said that politicians follow the people rather than lead the people. Well , we have an example to follow. We have employers and employees working in harmony. They are willing to sit down and work out a prices and incomes policy with the Government. They are willing to support such policies. Far be it for this Senate to destroy the harmony which has been created as a result of the National Economic Summit Conference. Far be it for us to break up the harmony which is coming out of the current approach to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Let us recognise the impact that uncertainty will create on those people who are seeking the harmony which will allow this economy to recover. Let us look at the impact on small businesses. They need certainty. They need good industrial relations. They do not need the implementation of government policies which intrude on the good relationships between employers and employees, and they demonstrated this last year when they fought against the introduction of the Industrial Relations Bureau. They do not want Government interference. They are capable of getting on with the job on their own. I believe that the prices and incomes policy of the Government does have a chance of maintaining the sort of harmony which has been building up in the first few months of this year. The desperate need is for predictability. I am sure I speak not just for small business but also for large businesses. We need to be able to plan in small and large businesses. The creation of the Economic Planning Advisory Council may contribute towards that ability to plan. There is a potential now for us to work with at least a degree of certainty provided we do not cause unnecessary disruptions, provided we do not create an aura of uncertainty.

The Government's wages policies, as implied in the Budget, are not all that I would like to see in terms of both wage justice and economic stimulation. I believe there are better ways of getting the economy going. For instance, if this Government were really interested in wage justice it would fight the unions for an approach to plateau indexation instead of succumbing meekly to the unions ' opposition to this approach. It would then have the opportunity to see justice done across the Australian economy, not just vis-a-vis business and unions but between highly paid workers and low income workers. The potential would exist for injecting the sort of economic stimulus where it is needed to help low income earners and to obtain economic justice for the workers of this country.

The Government has to take that suggestion on board. It has to be willing to stand up to the Australian Council of Trade Unions and it has to be willing to set new parameters. It has indicated its willingness in terms of pensioners and disadvantaged people. It is willing to set new parameters, new guidelines, for all other sections of the community, but it is timid in its approach to the unions. I appeal to the government to recognise the justice in plateau indexation.

My final appeal is to both the Opposition and the Government. The Opposition's approach has been either to use the sledge-hammer or do nothing. In government it used the sledge-hammer approach when it belted the unions and it used the do- nothing approach when it allowed the laissez-faire market to increase wages dramatically over a period, matching the 1974 Whitlam era in the damage that it did to the economy. Then it returned to the sledge-hammer approach and belted the unions because they obtained increases for their members way above what the economy could cope with. Regrettably, the Opposition never had a prices and income policy when it was in government.
