It introduced the interim measure of the wages pause but gave no indicators as to how and when it would end. This Government came into office with an appeal for consensus. It got the support of the unions, the employers and the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. It now needs the support only of this Parliament. I therefore appeal to the Opposition to give that support in an attempt to gain consensus. The Opposition should not become isolated, as its attempts today have indicated it is willing to be, simply to score political points. Let us get the members of this Parliament, this Senate, working together in an endeavour to make both the economy and the wages policy, the income and prices policy, which are so desperately needed for this country, work and then increase employment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: -Today the Senate is debating this matter of public importance:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's adoption of wages policies which will increase unemployment.

There is probably no more serious and worrying matter that the Opposition could raise. It is a pity that Senator Jack Evans believes that the matter was raised simply for political point scoring. This is quite incorrect, particularly when one considers the tragic circumstances currently facing the unemployed in this country. The issue is unemployment-jobs, jobs, jobs, as Premier Wran said at the recent National Economic Summit Conference.

Unemployment stands at 10.3 per cent, about the highest level since the 1930s. Hundreds of thousands of Australians are out of work. The last figure I saw showed that 718,700 of Australia's most valuable resource were unemployed. When one assesses not only what these people could be contributing to the economic growth and strength of the nation but also the cost involved when a huge proportion of Australia's population requires to be supported, and reasonably so , the immensity of the problem and the loss facing this country can be realised. It is not just an economic problem; it is a social problem. The social instability of a generation of unemployed, hundreds of thousands of disappointed , disillusioned, disheartened and distressed Australians, is yet to be measured.

What do those people see? They see this Government, upon which many pinned their hopes, going to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and saying that it supports wage rises for all those employed, proportionate to increases in their cost of living. What the Government is not saying is that it supports such rises notwithstanding the effect upon the unemployed. It is therefore saying either that its action will not affect the chances of the unemployed getting work or that it does not care. I think we accept the Government's motive to be the former. One must think that the Government must care. No Australian who is employed could be unconcerned at the totally unacceptable level of unemployment which exists currently in the community.

The argument of the Government is that its wages policy will not detrimentally affect the unemployed or the potential unemployed, and let us not forget the potential unemployed. Many Australians who are in work at the moment are worried about their employment future, and they have reason to worry. Talk of the recession being over is premature. I remind the Senate of a survey recently compiled by the Metal Trades Industry Association of Australia and the Commonwealth Bank, which was referred to in an article in the Australian of 2 August. The article stated that the survey was 'a sobering reminder of the difficulties now facing the economy'. The article continued:
The survey points to a number of economic indicators in the metal sector which demonstrate that the industry, which is in many ways an economic pace-setter, may not yet have hit bottom.

The policy of this Government is inconsistent with the best prospects of the potentially unemployed to keep their jobs. In the same way, it is inconsistent with the best prospects of those unemployed to obtain jobs.

I remind the Senate that Australia relies on trade for 30 per cent of its gross domestic product. To trade successfully we must be competitive. Our inflation rate was 11.2 per cent as at the June quarter. That of our trading partners, taken at the same time, is, on average, 5.6 per cent. Some of our major trading partners, such as Japan, have a much lower rate-approximately one-quarter of our inflation rate. Indexed wage rises will play a significant part of inflationary growth. The Government's policy is therefore inconsistent with strengthening our trading position as far as that relates to employment and to creating and safeguarding jobs.

The wage freeze initiated by the former Government was never seen as an end in itself. It was seen as an important part of a package to enhance competitiveness , a realisation that, to stay in the market, costs had to be reduced and/or productivity improved. One major cost was labour. Thus Australians were asked- they responded readily-to be prepared to make small sacrifices and to realise that in a recession they must expect less or they would simply put themselves or their work mates out of business. As I said, Australians responded admirably, and a number of gallup polls have indicated that Australians are prepared to sacrifice further. Regrettably, certain union leaders have been unable to see what is so obvious and they locked the present Government into indexation as a trade-off for political support at the last election.

Indexation does not take into account profitability or the ability to pay, and in the last few years firms have been unable to maintain profit levels. On a ratio basis of wages to costs, between 1980-81 and 1981-82 there was an increase from 65.7 to 66.3. Profit to cost fell from 14.7 to 13.9. Declining profit levels mean that firms have less operating surplus available for investment from internal funds. Continuing high interest rates have limited the borrowing alternative. What happens is that previously intended investment expenditure is shelved, stocks are allowed to run down, and pressure exists on payroll costs. I remind the Senate that profit share was higher a decade ago. In pressing its indexation policy this Government has failed to appreciate that increased employment prospects are linked to improved business profitability. I ask whether members of the Government have read the Government's Budget statements. If one looks at page 66 of Budget Paper No. 1, it reminds one of the difficulties we face. It states:

Business fixed investment is projected to fall again in 1983-84 at about the same rate as the very sharp decline of 14 per cent recorded in 1982-83. The forecast reflects the view that, given current low levels of capacity utilisation, business wil be cautious in responding to the pickup in activity and improved profitability in the face of high real rates of interest and uncertainties about wage moderation, international competitiveness and the durability of the recovery.

We are far from out of our difficulties. There has been room for some restraint on the average worker without undue suffering. Why is that? It is because from about early 1980 until the commencement of the wage pause last year the average increase in weekly earnings had significantly exceeded the increase in the consumer price index. This is part of the explanation for the lower corporate profitability to which I just referred. In 1980-81 average weekly earnings increased by 13.5 per cent whilst the CPI increased by 9.4 per cent. In the following year, 1981-82, average weekly earnings increased by 14.6 per cent as against a 10.4 per cent increase in the CPI. Whilst no one wants to trim an improving standard of living, the sacrifice has not been as great as the Government wants us to believe.

Where do we go now? The long term beneficial effects of continued wage restraint via an extended wage pause were confirmed in the information provided to participants at the National Economic Summit Conference. The Senate will recall that of the three economic scenarios presented to the Summit it was scenario C, which in part encompassed an extension of the pause until April 1984 , which provided the best results for the economy in terms of lowest inflation, highest profit shares, highest gross domestic profit growth, strongest private investment activity and, most importantly, lowest unemployment. But the Government could not accede to scenario C, let alone the call by the late Sir Keith Campbell for even greater wage restraint, because it was locked into its indexation deal with the unions. It was its part of the 'industrial peace in our time' bargain.

Now the Government is before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commision arguing for full indexation. But it has already been caught out. In accordance with scenario A it envisaged a wage rise of about 3 per cent over the remainder of 1983. So in the lead-up to the national wage case it said to the Commission:

In the light of its assessment of the national economy . . . the Government considers that the economy can only sustain a national wage rise in the second half of 1983 in the order of 3 to 4 per cent without serious detrimental effects .

But the March and June quarters CPI figures have compounded to 4.3 per cent which, not surprisingly, the Government has accepted. That emphasises the extent to which the Government is locked into its no compromise position notwithstanding the damage it causes to the economy and to the unemployed. Last night's Budget, which has built CPI increases into the excise structure, can only compound the matter further.

It is of regret that the Federal Government will not heed its colleagues in New South Wales who are opposed to full wage indexation and who expressed concern that the system would collapse because the economy could not yet afford full indexation. The Australian Financial Review of 21 July, which in turn was quoting the New South Wales Government advocate, stated:
What we fear is that the guarantee now of full indexation simply may not be capable of being sustained and there is no surety yet of economic growth.

The Government would do well to reassess the benefits of the wage pause it is so keen to abandon. I remind the Senate that the wage pause had two purposes. The first was to ensure sufficient time for firms to recover profit levels which had fallen to an historic low, as I have indicated. There has been insufficient time , although there have been positive steps in the right direction with the growth of wages in the June quarter falling to one per cent. The second purpose was to allow money saved through the wage pause to be applied in employment creating programs. The Sydney Morning Herald of 18 July 1983 reminded us that money diverted as a result of the wage pause had allowed a total of 4,597 jobs to be opened up from money that was originally earmarked for federal public servants. I remind the Government of that because positive job creation has come out of this wage pause that the Government so readily wishes to condemn.

The Labor Government would do well to look at the experience of wage indexation elsewhere. France has recently abandoned indexation as a failure. In France, as in the United States of America, West Germany and Japan, wage indexation is not part of the wage negotiating process. Examining that, the Australian Financial Review of 25 May stated:
Even the most cursory of examinations of OECD experience with these matters shows the ACTU demand for a return to full wage indexation to be the dreamiest of pipe dreams.

It is precisely these nations, out trading partners, who are now, in the face of economic reality and logic, refusing to adopt indexation into their wage fixing procedures. Instead they accept a vital link between money wage growth and productivity increases, which in turn impacts upon their international competitiveness. The Australian Financial Review editorial of 25 May stated:

As a small trading nation we do not have the luxury of adopting a head-in-the- sand or emu-like posture on these matters. We cannot ignore what out trading partners are doing on the wage front . . . the ACTU must accept the inexorable logic of our current plight. A return to full wage indexation would be economic madness.
The editorial in today's Australian Financial Review brings me back to where I started, that is, with the New South Wales Premier. It states:

While the central problem of economic policy ought to be, as the NSW Premier put it at the summit, ''jobs, jobs, jobs,'' there is no doubt that the central pre-occupation of this Budget and the Government's economic policy so far has been wages, wages, wages.

The Government has called for sacrifices, the community is prepared to make sacrifices but it is of great regret that the Government's preoccupation with increasing wages of those employed can only at this time further disappoint those who need support more-the unemployed and potentially unemployed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since Senator Robert Hill concluded his remarks by quoting from a number of editorials in the Australian Financial Review and the Sydney Morning Herald, I hope that when the debate on the Budget comes before the Senate he will accept the opinion of those editorial writers that it was a good Budget, a strong sound ahead for economic growth Budget for Australia, and that he will not selectively quote those parts of the editorial that he chose to use in his argument. I take some solace from the fact that he resorts to those editorials as though they are definitive judgments. When the Budget debate comes around, I hope he will not retreat from that view.
—We are talking about the Government's wages policy, not its Budget .

—We are talking about the Budget. The editorial in the Australian Financial Review from which Senator Hill quoted was about the Budget and it delivered a verdict of approval for this Government. However, most of the speeches in the debate today have had an air of deja vu about them; we have been there before. Nothing new has really been said by the Opposition, which is the tragedy that Senator Jack Evans pointed out about the contributions made by the speakers from the other side of the House. Obviously, the rule that is being followed by Opposition speakers in this debate is: 'If you have nothing to say, trot out the old cliches and have a bash. That might at least cover the fact that there is really nothing serious that you can comment on'.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst many things can be said about the speeches made by Opposition senators, I will concentrate my remarks, on behalf of the Government, on about four areas. As I have said, we have heard a replay of the old record: Blame wages and unions for the level of unemployment and then pretend that if something is done about that all problems will be resolved. That is a simplistic view. My colleague Senator Maguire dealt quite extensively with that in terms of macro-economic policy and I do not propose to dwell on it, except to say that the Fraser Government, of which honourable senators opposite were members, was responsible in the seven years of its office for increasing unemployment in this country by 100 per cent. It seems to me odd that, after six months of Hawke Government, they should say that our wages policy will create unemployment. After all we the Opposition had seven years to employ a wages policy and unemployment has doubled as I have indicated. It is from those who created the problems with which the Hawke Labor Government is grappling that we get criticism and the claim that we will fail. It seems that the Opposition does not really have a defence on that argument. We will not adopt the economic policies of the Liberal Party; we will pursue the economic policies of the Australian Labor Party for which we have a mandate. I do not think it is useful for the Opposition to continue to argue that its economic policies of the past carry any sustainable evidence of creating employment. Empirically they do not.

The second area I want to comment on is that essentially there has been an attack which has ignored the fact that the Government has a mandate from the electorate to pursue an income policy. That mandate was achieved in two forms. As I have said before in other debates in this House, it was achieved firstly by the electorate voting for a Labor Government after it was clearly aware of the content, even though somewhat misrepresented by the Opposition in the election campaign, of the prices and income accord. Secondly, it was achieved because the accord was supported at the National Economic Summit Conference. That Summit represented a supportive view of all major sectors of Australian industry and commerce and all other sections necessary to seek and find a consensus of approach in this country in getting a resurgence of the economy. It seems to me that what has been overlooked by the Opposition is that the quite reasonable proposition which underpinned the deliberations of the National Economic Summit was a recognition that in order for Australia to manage its way out of recession restraint needed to be shown on all sides and that that restraint should take the form of a recognition that there needed to be an equality of sacrifice.

I do not want to harp on the record of the Opposition in this House, but when it introduces a proposition such as this the point ought to be made that it was the Opposition in this Parliament that voted against the bottom of the harbour legislation. Here we are talking about an economic scenario that involves equality of sacrifice and here we have an Opposition which voted against legislation to recover money lost to revenue by tax avoidance and allowed those who have avoided their taxes to go free. At the same time the Opposition says to workers in this country: 'Restrain your incomes'. The Opposition is holding up by its example an argument on workers to say that they will not do as they are required but will do as the Liberal Party suggests and go out and achieve in the economy as best they can. They would say: 'Let us not follow the line of equality of sacrifice. If it is good enough for the Liberal Party to oppose bottom of the harbour legislation then it is good enough for us to maximise our wage claims'. I think the Opposition should consider seriously the example it sets in economic conduct before it starts preaching to other sections of the community what the conduct should be.

The other area in which the Opposition's performance is, to say the least, a little patchy, is that during the recess a number of Opposition spokesmen criticised the Government on the withholding tax. This is another area in which taxes have not been paid. The obligations required of all wage and salary earners should be fully met but they have not been met in the cash economy. So in giving a principal foundation for conducting a reasonable discourse over the issue of wages and employment it seems to me that the conduct of the Opposition in the bottom of the harbour and withholding tax areas cannot be ignored for the example it sets for other sections of the community.

Let me turn to a third area. Senator Chaney, in opening the attack for the Opposition, dwelt on this matter to some extent. He tried to argue that a swallow proves the coming of spring by citing a number of areas in which wage settlements and wage adjustments could be described as sectional claims. The first thing that can be said about all of those areas to which he referred is not original to me. In immediate rebuke Senator Button pointed out that all of those wage settlements will go to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission for scrutiny. In terms of a national wage case decision, obviously they will be held up to the criteria brought down by the bench on that occasion.

In Question Time this morning Senator Chaney inferred that the whole of the food industry would be subject to an outbreak of wage claims following the H. J. Heinz and Co. Australia Ltd settlement. At least that was the implication. I think that that is trying to pretend again that a swallow makes a spring. The Secretary of the union concerned indicated to the Australian Financial Review in the article from which Senator Chaney quoted that the settlement would not flow on to the rest of the food industry. For the record, the Heinz factory employs 400 people. There are 162,095 workers in the whole of the food industry. The 400 employed by Heinz represent only 2.4 per cent. I do not think it can be said that if 2.4 per cent of workers in the food industry receive a wage increase which, according to the Secretary of their own union, will not flow on to the rest of the industry, the whole industry is involved in a wages breakout in terms of the accord. If we want to set the hares running I could make the ridiculous comparison that those 400 people represent .0064 per cent of the entire Australian work force.

The Opposition has also identified the building industry as one of unrest because the Australian Workers Union and the Electrical Trades Union of Australia have filed wage claims to pick up the building trades settlement. The thing that has to be said about the building trades settlement is that clearly its conditions have not finally been determined and the Government will intervene before the Commission in the public interest to put its views. But, on the credit side, the settlement seems to have tied up all unions in a two-year agreement which will bring some peace to the blighted building industry for at least that time and allow, in the economic regrowth under the policies of this Government, some consistency of approach in an industry which has been dispute- ridden in the past. Demarcation problems and others that have blighted previous practitioners in the field of industrial relations are involved in that agreement. Hopefully, that will mean a much greater degree of peace in the building industry than we have seen before. Again, the Government will appear before the Arbitration Commission. The terms of that agreement are such that the agreement will go before the Arbitration Commission for ratification.

I could go to other areas that have been referred to but the story is the same. Certainly there have been negotiated changes in wages in other industries but in each case they ended up before the Commission to which this Government can appeal and before which this Government has already made its position clear in the national wage case. The Australian Government, in dealing with the possibility of sectional wage claims being promoted in the national wage case, has asked the Commission to bring down a decision whereby unions which accept the national wage case increase will have to agree to comply with the guidelines of the decision or they will not get the increase. The Victorian Government has gone a bit further and asked unions to sign a declaration to that effect. But the Australian Council of Trade Unions, on behalf of unions, has indicated that it supports a declaration of that nature. Thus we have, from the union side, at least from the ACTU, a commitment to comply with the guidelines. That submission has been supported by the Australian Government. The argument attempting to be sustained in talking up the image of a wages breakout from the accord is empirically, on the facts, not sustainable. I find it surprising that, from a party--

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope you are right.

—That is the record. I have the figures here. I am happy to discuss them with Senator Chaney in this forum or any other forum. It comes as more than passing strange from a party which has stated publicly that it does not have a wages policy, that it should make those criticisms of a government that does. The Government is operating an orderly policy which, in the very few minutes left to me, I will talk about. Our policy provides predictability in the area of wage fixation. It is a basic tenet of industrial relations that where there is uncertainty and anxiety on the part of workers, they go out militantly to protect their interests. That is the nature of the market form of wage approach which it seems Mr Howard favours. Our system, under the accord of industrial relations, provides a degree of predictability that reasonable expectations will be met and thus absolve workers from the inducements to take industrial action which is inherent in the system advocated by the Opposition. The primacy of the predictability, the certainty about the future-that wages will rise according to prices-is essentially what underpins the approach of the Government. Our Budget has set down a series of measures which by themselves will lead to slow-ahead but steady growth. It is from growth based on a sound and predictable, well understood and clear wages policy that industry can plan and start to develop, in terms of where the real jobs will come from. While this Government has made a very strong allocation of funds for job creation, the strategy of the Budget is to rely not on that short run mechanism but on a system in which there can be overall growth in industry and real long term sustainable jobs can be developed.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude by saying that the Liberal Party should keep two questions in mind when next it contemplates bringing this matter before us as one of public importance. The first question is: What would its policy have been, if it had followed the wages pause, when that pause ended. The question of how one transfers from a pause of the sort that it advocates to a normal area of wage fixation is critical and our policy addresses that matter correctly. I make the point that in 1974-75 nearly four million man days were lost in Australia as we transferred from a system of wage fixing to the centralised system under wage indexation brought in about March-April 1975. There have been far fewer disputes since. The sorts of disputes that have been cited by speakers from the Opposition are those which can best be described as transitional problems, as we move from one form of wage fixing to another. We never though that it would be perfect.
