The speeches read as follows-
OMBUDSMAN AMENDMENT BILL 1983

The Ombudsman Act 1976, which came into operation in July 1977, was the result of bi-partisan support for the proposal that there should be an Ombudsman with jurisdiction over the administrative actions of Commonwealth Government agencies . Legislation to establish the office was an initiative of the Whitlam Labor Government, carried forward by the succeeding Government.

In a similar way the present Bill exemplifies the bi-partisan approach to Ombudsman legislation; it is substantially the same as the Ombudsman Amendment Bill introduced in the last Parliament by the previous Government which was designed in accordance with recommendations of the Administrative Review Council , a statutory advisory body set up under the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975.

This Government has undertaken to be closely guided by the Administrative Review Council in further developing the administrative review system. The present Bill instances that undertaking and provides a development and expansion of the Ombudsman's role.

The Bill has two purposes. First, it will create and confer on the Commonwealth Ombudsman a statutory office of Defence Force Ombudsman. Second, it will amend the Ombudsman Act in the light of operational experience to date.
Defence Force Ombudsman

The proposal to create a Defence Force Ombudsman with jurisdiction to investigate administrative actions related to or arising from a person's service in the Defence Force, had its origin in the platform of the last Labor Government. Legislation to establish the office lapsed in 1975, though an interim office of Defence Force Ombudsman has continued to operate in the Department of Defence since that time. In 1979 the previous Government requested that the Administrative Review Council examine the proposal. Its report was tabled of 4 July 1981 and the present Bill reflects its conclusions.

The Bill proposes that the office of Defence Force Ombudsman, although being established within the Ombudsman Act as a complement to the Ombudsman's general jurisdiction, should be identifiable and distinct. In particular, the Bill provides for a Deputy Ombudsman (Defence Force) to be designated to perform the day to day work of the Defence Force jurisdiction. Recognising the importance of this new position for the Defence Forces, before a Deputy Ombudsman is approved or designated for the Defence Force jurisdiction, the Prime Minister will consult with the Minister for Defence.

While the creation of the new statutory Defence Force jurisdiction will result in some extra costs, notably the salary (approximately $50,350 pa) of the new deputy ombudsman, establishing the jurisdiction within the Ombudsman's office will avoid administrative duplication and ensure that it is effectively exercised at minimum cost.

The creation of a statutory office of Defence Force Ombudsman will provide an important advance in the conditions of employment for service members. Serviceman and women differ from most other Australians in that their relations with their employers can extend into almost every aspect of their lives. It is in the nature of Defence Force service that members do not have the advantage of external grievance mechanisms typical in civil employment. With the creation of a Defence Force Ombudsman an independent avenue for the review of grievances will be established.

The Defence Force Ombudsman's function is to investigate, either on complaint being made or of his own motion, administrative actions related to or arising from a person's service in the Defence Force. Although most complaints will come from current or former service members, other persons, such as their dependants, will also be able to lodge complaints if they are affected by actions which are within the Defence Force Ombudsman's jurisdiction.

In recognition of service members' special position, the Defence Force Ombudsman's jurisdiction is defined by service in the Defence Force, whereas the Commonwealth Ombudsman is excluded from investigating matters arising in Commonwealth civilian employment. There are, however, some exclusions from the proposed jurisdiction which parallel exclusions from the Commonwealth Ombudsman' s existing jurisdiction. In addition, the Defence Force Obudsman is excluded from investigating action taken in the conduct of disciplinary proceedings, and action relating to the grant or refusal of most honours and awards though not, for example, campaign medals.

Review by the Defence Force Ombudsman will complement, rather than compete with , existing internal redress procedures: for effective management in the Defence Force, officers should usually hear and have the first opportunity to remedy the grievances of those under their command.

The legislation applies most of the procedural provisions in the Ombudsman Act to the Defence Force Ombudsman-such as those concerning the conduct of investigations. As well, transitional provisions in the Bill provide for the transfer to the statutory office of Defence Force Ombudsman any unfinished business of the interim non-statutory office.
Other Provisions

The remainder of the Bill makes a number of amendments to the Ombudsman Act based on the Ombudsman's operational experience to date, drawing on the review by the Administrative Review Council. The full report of that review was tabled in the House on 23 September last year.

The main theme to these amendments is that the Ombudsman, an independent officer with the statutory formal duties and powers essential to vigorous investigation and reporting of defective administration, should normally operate less formally than is appropriate for other administrative review mechanisms, such as courts and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

Accordingly, several amendments are made which give the Ombudsman greater discretions and flexibility by modifying procedural requirements in the Act. In particular, the Bill includes amendments which:
recognise that the Ombudsman may accept and resolve oral complaints (unless there is a need to investigate formally);
simplify the Ombudsman's discretion not to formally investigate certain complaints;
streamline the requirements for the Ombudsman to notify the Minister and agency head of his decision whether to investigate a complaint; and
give legislative backing to the Ombudsman's practice of making informal inquiries.
This last amendment will also clarify that the Ombudsman may inquire informally to establish that a matter is within his jurisdiction before investigating formally.

In amendments which are similarly to facilitate his role in encouraging better and more accessible administration, the Bill also gives the Ombudsman greater discretion to disseminate information or comments on his investigations to Commonwealth agencies, the Parliament, other people with an interest in the outcome of investigations (for example, Parliamentarians) and, where special circumstances so warrant, to the public at large.
Other amendments variously strengthen or widen the Ombudsman's role in line with developing practice and the intention of the Ombudsman legislation. These amendments will:

provide a sounder statutory basis for co-operative investigation by the Commonwealth Ombudsman and his counterparts in the States and Northern Territory where both Commonwealth and State or Territory activities or undertakings are involved;
empower the Federal Court to determine issues that may arise in relation to the Ombudsman's powers and jurisdiction;
expand the circumstances in which the Ombudsman can cause matters to come before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal; and

clarify certain doubts that have arisen regarding the Ombudsman's jurisdiction over particular types of action, including administrative action leading up to or following action by a Minister, and jurisdiction over particular types of Commonwealth bodies.
More detailed information on the provisions of the Bill is set out in the explanatory memorandum which has been circulated. I commend the Bill to the House.
OMBUDSMAN (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL 1983
This Bill makes amendments, primarily to the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act 1981, which complement the provisions of the Ombudsman Amendment Bill 1983.

The Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act 1981 in part provides for the independent investigation by the Ombudsman of complaints against the Australian Federal Police. The Act provides a role for the Ombudsman in relation to complaints, substantially similar to that in the Ombudsman Act 1976. Parallel amendment of both Acts is desirable to ensure basic uniformity in the Ombudsman' s powers and duties in relation to complaints.

The explanatory memorandum which has been circulated provides more detailed information on the manner in which amendments to the Ombudsman Act have been reflected in this specific complaints jurisdiction. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON ELECTORAL REFORM

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President has received the following message from the House of Representatives:

INTERJECT.PARA: Message No. 62
MR PRESIDENT,
The House of Representatives transmits to the Senate the following Resolution which was agreed to by the House of Representatives this day and requests the concurrence of the Senate therein:
That paragraph (14) of the resolution of appointment of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform be omitted and that the following paragraph be substituted:
(14) That the committee report by 15 September 1983.
J. A. JENKINS SPEAKER
House of Representatives,
Canberra, 23 August 1983
Motion (by Senator Grimes) agreed to:

(1) That the Senate concurs in the Resolution transmitted to the Senate by Message No. 62 of the House of Representatives relating to an extension of time for the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform to report.
(2) That the foregoing Resolution be communicated to the House of Representatives by Message.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Grimes)-by leave-agreed to:

That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent such senators as are members of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform attending a meeting of the Committee during the sitting of the Senate on Thursday 25 August 1983.
Reference to Standing Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations: The Income Tax Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1983 No. 111, and made under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936.
(2) That the Committee report to the Senate on or before 4 October 1983.

I do not want to speak at great length on this matter. The motion relates to the regulations which have been made with respect to the Government's new withholding tax. That is a matter which has received a great deal of public interest over the last few weeks. I think it would be well known to all honourable senators that there is widespread concern in the business community over the introduction of the withholding tax scheme. Much of the concern arises from the lack of time for businesses to become familiar with their rights and obligations under the regulations and the short amount of time which has been available to them to apply for exemptions or for variation of tax rates before the system begins. It is said by many of those who are making representations, both to the Government and to the Opposition, that employment is threatened by the precipitate introduction of this proposal. The Opposition is of course concerned at these representations and it has sought the delay of the implementation of the proposal, as indeed have the Australian Democrats and other people but the Government has indicated that it proposes to proceed to the implement the regulations from 1 September. It is prepared to make certain administrative concessions, but it wishes to proceed. I indicate why the Opposition believes that the matter should be subject to committee examination. It is of some importance because of the suggestion that businesses and hence employment are being threatened. I will go quickly through the facts. Less than one month before the introduction of the regulations, information booklets were still not widely available. The Commissioner of Taxation, in a statement dated 22 July, said:
The Taxation Office anticipates that limited supplies of officially printed copies of the various papers will become available from the Taxation Offices on the following dates:
General explanatory booklet and schedule of prescribed payments, 4 August 1983;
Paying authority notification form, 4 August 1983;
Applications for variation or exemption, 8 August 1983;
Booklets of deduction forms, 8 August 1983;
Explanatory booklet for householders, 18 August 1983;

Bearing in mind that the new system was to commence on 1 September but the forms and the instructions issued are quite complex, it can be seen that the amount of notice given has been very limited. The Government has made a lot of the fact that about 16,000 taxpayers have applied for exemptions or reduced rate certificates and most have been approved. But the Opposition is concerned that this is a very small portion of the 300,000 or more taxpayers who will be subject to the new system. There is also widespread concern that the administrative arrangements which the Government has introduced are unnecessarily complex. The Housing Industry Association on 3 August stated:

The proposed system of paper work is so complex as to confirm that the Government's advisers know absolutely nothing about the way in which a small business is run . . . Most small builders and subcontractors will now need to pay an accountant on a continuous basis adding further unwarranted costs to their businesses and hence to their price of housing.

It is a fact that large companies have their lawyers and accountants who can examine and comply with new requirements. No doubt they are the taxpayers who have already lodged their exemptions and applications. Small business and individuals do not necessarily have the same facilities and ready access to all extra professional help and have to struggle, often by themselves, through what is a maze of bureaucratic red tape and very difficult forms that have only just been made available. It is understood that for those people who feel they may need to apply for an exemption, considerable costs can be involved in obtaining professional services. There is also concern over the unrealistic requirements placed on honest taxpayers to become eligible for a deduction exemption certificate.
In a letter to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) dated 5 August, the Institute of Chartered Accountants wrote that it is:

. . . considerably concerned that the legislation requires 'prescribed persons' to go beyond reasonable standards of either audit or professional care in the provision of declarations for the purpose of applications for deduction exemption certificates.
In the light of these concerns I think it is appropriate that the Senate examine the matter and satisfy itself as to the arrangements which have been made for this method of tax collection.

Finally, there is concern that while various members of the Government have acknowledged problems in the proposed system and some attempts have been made to remedy them, no serious attempt has been made to remedy all of them. Mr Hawke, the head of this Government, on 9 August was reported as saying that he and his Ministers could see that there were some elements of the proposed new tax 'that may need to be refined'. The Acting Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, said:
The Government would press ahead with the tax despite fears in the building industry that it would cause widespread bankruptcy.
He went on to say, rather inelegantly:
Builders are always going to the wall, nothing is new about that.
I do not think that comment cheered up those people who are objecting to the tax . Mr Hawke is also reported as saying:

. . . the Government had the choice of waiting either until it had 'some perfect completely acceptable system on the one hand' and allowing in that context hundreds of millions of dollars to be avoided, or going out and tackling it immediately and then 'refining it as you go along'.

The Opposition is heartened to see yesterday's announcement by the Commissioner of Taxation that was brought into the Senate by Senator Walsh yesterday in Question Time. The announcement allows for a two-month breathing space in processing applications for exemptions under the new system. The Opposition believes that a public examination of this matter will provide an opportunity for the Government, the Taxation Office and those who are concerned about the administration of the tax to put the facts before the Senate so that the matter can be examined. I anticipate that in the event that the Committee examination shows continuing real difficulties in the administration of the tax of a sort which poses real difficulties for people who are in business and trying to maintain employment in Australia, the Government and the Commissioner would look further at the administrative arrangements. That is a matter on which, I suppose , the Government can give no prior assurance but I express the hope that the Committee examination would be positive in that sense.

I had indicated an intention to give notice of motion to disallow the regulations which have been made under the Act. I have not done so. Instead, I seek in the motion to have a report from the Committee by 4 October, which is within the time permitted for notice of disallowance to be given. No decision has been taken by the Opposition to disallow the regulations. It believes that the principle of the withholding tax is one which it should support. However, it is concerned that the administration of the withholding tax should be in accordance with the views which it held in Government and which it still holds; namely, that it should not be cumbersome and difficult for people who are honest taxpayers and it should not impose unnecessary administrative burdens on taxpayers. We will make our judgment on the matter in light of the facts which emerge from the Committee's inquiry. I commend the motion to the Senate and hope that the Committee will make a speedy examination of this matter and report back to us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a clear distinction between a proposal to refer this matter for study by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations and the campaign which has been waged, if not by Senator Chaney himself then certainly by some of his more primitive Western Australian and other colleagues. I refer to the campaign of distortion and misrepresentation against this legislation which, I emphasise, was forecast in a more severe form by the former Treasurer more than a year ago. The Government has no objection to the Committee conducting the proposed examination and will therefore not oppose the motion. However, we do so with the proviso and in the expectation that the sword of Damocles, the disallowance of the essential regulations, is not to be held over the implementation of the Act proclaimed last June. It would obviously be intolerable if, at the same time as the pre-payments are actually being collected and source deductions are being made and transferred into a Taxation Office account, there were any doubt as to whether the regulations under which those source deductions were being made and paid to the Taxation Office were endangered ultimately in the Senate. I know that there are legal precedents and even if the regulations were disallowed by the Senate the Government could immediately re-issue them. They would remain valid until such time as the Senate again disallowed them, but the Government regards it as quite intolerable that the effective enforcement of an Act already passed by this Parliament should be held under threat when it is actually in operation. I seek from at least two non -government senators an assurance that the regulations will not be disallowed.

SPEECH.PARA: On the understanding that the regulations would not be disallowed, yesterday I gave to Senator Chipp in the Senate an undertaking on behalf of the Government that if the Senate Finance and Government Operations Committee study, which was then proposed and for which Senator Chaney has now moved a motion, uncovered clear anomolies or administrative shortcomings in the application of those rules and the effective enforcement of an Act of this Parliament the Government would act accordingly. That has been completely consistent with the attitude the Government has taken all along on this matter-that is, that our objective is to stamp out tax evasion in the industries concerned, as it is to stamp out tax evasion generally. We were at all times willing to review the operation of the legislation and accompanying regulations if it could be shown that it could be administered more efficiently. Likewise, we were willing to review the rates and the notification threshold. I make that clear distinction between not opposing a committee examination of this question and the opportunistic hypocrisy of many members of the present Opposition. The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey ) is to my knowledge the most startling or most disgraceful example of the type of opposition which has come from some members of the Liberal Party. The honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) probably runs him a close second.

I want to set some facts straight in response to the misrepresentations and the spurious and ill-informed arguments which have been advanced on this question. It has been asserted that when the previous Government forecast the introduction of this system more than a year ago it had led people to believe, or it had been understood, that it would be an easy matter-indeed, virtually a formality-to obtain an exemption certificate. I quote from the information paper distributed by the former Treasurer on 17 August last year in which, amongst other things, he said:

In recognition of the fact that there will be business taxpayers receiving prescribed payments who can demonstrate that they have clearly maintained a satisfactory level of compliance with income tax law, provision is to be made in the new system for such a payee to be granted a certificate authorising a payer to make payments without any deduction of tax.
The important points now follow:

Among the tests that a payee would have to satisfy to obtain exemption would be that he or she has been in business for a significant period during which time a satisfactory taxation record has in all respects been maintained, that the business is carried on from established business premises and that all financial transactions of the business are conducted through a bank account separate from any private or domestic account or accounts.

That is what is said in the information paper that was distributed by the previous Treasurer more than a year ago. Those same conditions still apply. I would like to return to Senator Chaney's motion that this matter be examined by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. I think that such a proposal could have some real value in another respect. It may have some value in exposing the previous abuse of taxation laws in the industries concerned. I note that the West Australian newspaper of 18 August reports a meeting held in Perth the previous day and the comments of a Mr Jack Furey, the President of the Western Australia Sub-Contract Bricklayers Association. Mr Furey is reported as having said that because of the introduction of this source deduction system it would be necessary for the contract rates paid to sub- contract bricklayers to be increased by 5 per cent. On the assumption that no tax evasion was previously involved, given the fact that all that is required by the new Act and its consequential regulations is that a maximum amount of 10 per cent of the payment made to the sub-contract bricklayer in this case-I stress the words 'a maximum of 10 per cent'-would be lodged with the Taxation Office by the payer as a credit against the sub-contract bricklayer's ultimate tax liability, there seems to be no reason whatsoever to support the assertion that the contract price would have to be increased by 5 per cent. But Mr Furey was even more illuminating in a subsequent comment. The newspaper report stated:
Mr Furey said sub-contractors also had to deduct 10 per cent of payments made to people working for them.

Bearing in mind that the case outlined is that of a sub-contract bricklayer who has employed other people, the prima facie case is that these employees should always have been subject to full pay as you earn tax deductions. The prima facie assessment of this report is that the fears expressed by Mr Furey are compatible with a tax evading situation but they are not compatible with the legislation which has been passed and which will come into operation on 1 February. There seems to me to be a very strong prima facie case for the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations to call Mr Furey as a witness to explain how he and other sub-contract bricklayers dealt with the tax liabilities of their employees-that is, the people who actually have the trowel and lay the bricks-in the past. Such an investigation might have considerable value.

Before closing, I want to make two or three other points. With respect to the spurious and/or ill-informed arguments which have been used in this campaign to have the Government delay the introduction of the legislation which I stress was forecast albeit in a somewhat harsher form by the previous Government, a Housing Industry Association letter of 3 August argued that while supporting the Government's objective of eliminating tax evasion in the building and other industries, the method chosen by the Government was flawed.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was that?

—Flawed; not 'fraud' but 'flawed'. It was asserted by the HIA that a notification system would be adequate as distinct from a source deduction system. Some paragraphs later in the same letter the HIA asserted that as a result of the introduction of the source deduction tax a phoney system of owner- builders would develop within the industry-that is, people would call themselves owner-builders and engage their own sub-contractors. Instead of engaging a master-builder, a normal householder would call himself an owner-builder and engage his own sub-contractors thereby escaping the necessity to deduct portion of the tax liability at source but comply with the obligation to notify the Taxation Office. According to the Housing Industry Association letter of 3 August this would still leave the industry wide open, under the owner-builders loophole, to tax evasion. So it was proposed in this letter that a notification system would fail when applied to owner-builders but would succeed if applied to the entire industry-a proposition which I found difficult to accept.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to state two other facts. The legislation originally forecast by the former Treasurer was to provide for a maximum-I stress this-of a 25 per cent deduction as against the 10 per cent deduction in the Act finally passed by the Parliament and for private householders a threshold of mandatory notification of $3,000 per construction job as against the $10,000 notification threshold finally adopted by the Government. Whether the judgment used by this Government or the previous Government on those matters was more correct is something that I believe only experience with the operation of the Act will reveal.

TALK.START.PARA: —It could be that more of the abuse is at the lower end of the scale.

—That is a matter of judgment. I have said and other members of the Government have said that if experience suggested that there should be a lower notification threshold than $1000 the Government would alter that threshold accordingly. But that is something which, by definition, cannot be stated with any certainty in advance. Nor, of course, can it be judged within the next month in any informed way by the Senate Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: In closing, I indicate that we do not oppose the proposition to refer this to the Committee. But the Government is seeking a guarantee from at least two non- Government members in the Senate that the threat of disallowance of the regulations which would place the administration of this law in a completely untenable position will be removed. We are seeking a guarantee from at least two non-Labor senators that the regulations will not be disallowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats also support the motion moved by the Leader Opposition (Senator Chaney ). It looks as though the Senate will have a unanimous vote on this question because the Government also is wisely supporting this reference to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. What are we talking about? We are talking about a proposition to prevent disclosed tax evaders from avoiding, and to make tax evaders who are operating in the cash economy pay, their just taxes. This proposal was first put by Mr Howard on behalf of the Liberal Party, over a year ago. That proposal was put in a much more severe form than the proposal now before the Parliament. Any ojections that any member of the Liberal Party of Australia might have towards the present proposal will ring a little hollow because, as I understand it, that proposal in a more severe form in fact was agreed to by the Liberal Party over a year ago. I commend Mr Howard. I commend the Liberal Party for taking action to attack one of the most vexed questions of tax evasion-namely, the black economy, the cash economy.

SPEECH.PARA: I was informed by a reputable economist last week of the shocking estimate of tax evasion in this country-something like $9 billion or $10 billion a year. I find that figure almost incomprehensible because, after all, it is more than the current deficit. People are ripping off the system by tax evasion of one form or another. The figure involved is greater than the deficit. This economist went further and suggested that at least half of that $9 billion was being ripped off , or evaded, in the cash economy sector. Therefore, this move which was originated by the Liberal Party and is being sustained by the present Government is to be commended. Both the Liberal Party and the Australian Labor Party are to be commended for going into this area. The Government has the total support of the Australian Democrats in this.

After legislation was passed in May at the end of the parliamentary session, and the regulations were put down, certain reputable people in the building industry and the road transport industry raised genuine objections to the scheme . I am sure that the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh), who made reference to certain people a moment or two ago will recognise the fact that genuine people have raised genuine objections to this scheme in the past two or three months. Those people have put their objections to both the Liberal members of Parliament and the Australian Democrats. I point out that I have registered with the Treasurer (Mr Keating) the objections we consider proper. We found him most receptive in contemplating those objections. I compliment him on that.

What does this legislation seek to do? What it virtually seeks to do is-I am putting this in precis form-unless a subcontractor can produce a certificate of exemption or variation to the payer, who might be a contractor, the contractor or payer must deduct 10 per cent of the contract price. This is designed to eliminate the possibility of the subcontractor or the payee putting the money in his pocket. This, as all honourable senators know, is a flagrant and blatant form of tax evasion. Last week a person told me-I want to get hold of the documentation-of a bricklayer who was so brazen and arrogant in his attempt to evade tax that he put in writing a quotation to build a domestic barbecue for $1 ,800. A note at the bottom of the quotation said: 'If you pay in cash I will reduce the sum to $1,300'. All of us know that this goes on. This legislation is designed to correct that situation and to collect some of the tax which is being evaded.

The Australian Democrats would have preferred to see a reporting system instituted initially rather than a withholding system. In effect, this makes people in private enterprise become unpaid tax collectors for the Government. One could argue that it does no more than what the system does to private enterprise employers in forcing them to deduct pay as you earn instalments each week and remit them to the Australian Taxation Office. That is a valid argument. But it is worth noting that this is an extension of the load on private enterprise, particularly small business. It puts the onus on them to collect tax in an unpaid capacity on behalf of the Government. Notwithstanding that fact, we support the legislation because it has been illustrated to us that if a reporting system only were instituted-namely, that the obligation on the payer was only to report to the Taxation Office each month the name, address and amount-there would be a loss of revenue of something like $70m a year. We, of course, unequivocally accept the figures supplied by the Taxation Office. Therefore, with some reluctance we support the withholding system, which obliges the payer, the contractor or the builder to withhold a certain amount each month from the payments he makes to subcontractors.

All through our negotiations with the Treasurer he has provided senior officers of the Taxation Office to discuss these matters with us. Those discussions have been taking place regularly over the past month. We finally came to the view late last week that the regulations were still unacceptable to the Australian Democrats because they could well place undue and onerous burdens on small businesses. As a consequence, I asked for an appointment with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer and the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford), which was readily granted. As a result, the Australian Democrats were successful in gaining concessions. Those concessions were announced in the Senate yesterday by Senator Walsh. They were announced also by the Commissioner of Taxation on the same day. The first concession is that if the Taxation Office , notwithstanding the fact that it will possibly have an additional 800 new staff and has been instructed that its officers can work virtually unlimited overtime, cannot process all the applications for exemption or variation by 1 September it will grant an interim zero rate of variation certificate for a period of up to two months in relation to any application that has not been processed. That virtually defers the scheme for two months in relation to those applications which have not been processed. I believe that is a very generous and flexible action by the Government and the Commissioner of Taxation. Secondly , the Commissioner has agreed that if tax agents or accountants make an application for clusters of clients whose applications they have not been able to complete by 1 September, then the same variations down to zero certificates- interim certificates-will be issued. Again that is a generous concession. The fear that the Democrats had of total confusion and chaos reigning and onerous, unnecessary hardships being placed on people who could not comply with the Act by 1 September have essentially been removed.

The third concession the Government gave the Democrats is even more significant . If any anomalies are exposed by the reference to the Committee contained in Senator Chaney's motion, which will be agreed to by the Senate, the Government has undertaken to remedy those anomalies as they are exposed by that Committee. I believe also that that is a most responsible, receptive and co-operative action on the part of the Government. I commend it and I commend the various Ministers I have mentioned, including Senator Walsh who I think has been most approachable in this matter.

In conclusion, the Government has said, I believe quite properly, that it cannot proceed with this matter with the threat of disallowance of the Income Tax Regulations hanging over its head. I do not know to what extent the sword of Damocles is being waved, or whether it is being waved at all, but I can understand the Government's reluctance to proceed and I can understand the reluctance of the Commissioner of Taxation to proceed. What position is a responsible Commissioner of Taxation put in if he believes it is possible that these regulations could be disallowed by the Senate within 15 sitting days, five sitting weeks, or whatever it is? In other words, will he employ 800 more people and process these certificates with the possibility that in five weeks time the regulations will be disallowed by this Senate and hundreds of thousands of dollars will be wasted, along with thousands of person hours, for no purpose?

Therefore, I believe the Government is quite within its rights, in view of the undertaking it has given to remedy the anomalies exposed by the Committee, to request that in the circumstances any such motion to disallow should not have the support of the Senate. I am prepared, on behalf of myself and my Party, to give an assurance that that motion for disallowance would not have our support if it were moved from any direction in this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —None of this debate would have been necessary had the Government taken a little more time over the measure and allowed more time for its discussion when it came before the Senate in the dying stages of the last session of Parliament. It is all very well for the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh, to stand up here and criticise those who have taken the part of persons who feel that they will be unfairly treated by the regulations that are to come down and by the actions of the Australian Taxation Office. It is all very well for him to name certain members of parliament in another place. I cannot even bring their names to mind at the moment, but he mentioned the electorates of two of them. I just have this to say to Senator Walsh, through you Mr Acting Deputy President: That leaves me cold. Senator Walsh is quite adept at vilifying members of this Parliament, from throughout the length and breadth of Australia. On a number of occassions during the recess he accused members of this chamber of acts which, of course, would be inconsistent with the integrity of those honourable senators, and, indeed, the integrity of this chamber itself. Let the Government realise that so far as I am concerned, if Senator Walsh does not take action either to apologise for those references--
—What references?

—I will be able to name the date, the time, the place and what the Minister said on an appropriate occasion but it will not be this occasion. I just point out to the Government, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that so far as I am concerned, if Senator Walsh takes carriage of any of these measures and is not prepared to have the matters debated on their merits without improper reflections on the integrity of members of parliament, he will get the answer that he deserves. This particular measure was pushed through the dying stages of the last session of Parliament, despite the concern, expressed by an Opposition amendment, that it failed to protect the independence and continued survival of sub-contractors. That opinion was expressed freely at that time, yet the measure was hurried through in the dying stages of the last session.
—And the Representatives were up.

—Yes, as Senator Chipp has reminded me, the House of Representatives had risen for the recess. As Senator Chipp has said, everyone agrees that the blatant cash economy abuses and the gross evasion of taxes, require remedy. Not one member of this chamber would say otherwise. The concern, of course, is to protect the independence and continued viability of sub- contractors. I have received a number of representations about this matter, not so much from industry groupings but from individual contractors-people who have regularly paid their taxes, people who are concerned about the fact that they will be hit in advance for taxes and that these taxes will have to be paid on materials some of which already incur substantial sales tax.

SPEECH.PARA: I welcome the proposition that this measure go to the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. I hope that that Committee will have sufficient time to hear representations not only from industry groupings but also from individual contractors who are likely to be affected. I take this opportunity, publicly, to alert all those contractors, those small business men and women who have expressed concern about this, to come forward and give evidence to the Committee. I commend the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, for moving this motion for reference and I give it my wholehearted support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank honourable senators for their support of the motion to refer this matter to the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. I express regret at the intemperate remarks of the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh, who I think should have borne in mind the fact that we are dealing with a Government measure, the administration of which the Government has been prepared to modify in light of the representations which have been received. That ought to indicate that there is real substance to the complaints which have been made. It may well indicate, of course, that there is substance to the outstanding complaints which have not been met, so far, by government action. Senator Walsh mentioned two members of the other place-the honourable member for O'Connor and the honourable member for Curtin-and suggested that they had been inconsistent in their approach to this matter. Again, that is typical of the broad brush way in which Senator Walsh is prepared to criticise and abuse members of the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: To my knowledge the honourable member for Curtin, Mr Rocher, has held an utterly consistent view on this matter. To the best of my knowledge so has Mr Tuckey. In other words, they have always been concerned about the practical implementation of this measure. They have always been concerned about it being implemented in a way which would not interfere with the business of people, in a way which would not be destructive of business, employment and so on. I believe they have been assiduous in responding to the genuine concerns of their electors and of those who have made representations to them. On behalf of the Opposition I reject the personal criticisms which were made of those members who have, I think, been carrying out their representational function.

Also, it should be made clear that Senator Walsh seems to have a misunderstanding of the procedures of this place and the effect which would flow from any action to disallow the regulations. When I spoke earlier I indicated that I did not propose to give notice of disallowance at this stage, although that is something that might flow from the findings of the Committee. If disallowance were effected by the Senate the regulations would no longer be valid. They would be in operation, and would retain their validity, until the point of disallowance was reached. Senator Walsh suggested that the Government could then step in and simply repeat the performance. I draw the attention of Senator Walsh and the Senate to section 49 of the Acts Interpretation Act, which points out that where any House of parliament disallows a regulation, no regulation being the same in substance as the regulation so disallowed, or deemed to have been disallowed, shall be made within six months after the date of disallowance unless there has been a turnabout by the House of parliament which is concerned.

Senator Walsh, in his approach to this matter, showed ignorance on two counts: Firstly, there would not be a situation in which action would have been taken by the Commissioner of Taxation under regulations which were, in a retrospective sense, made invalid and, secondly, if the Senate were to take action it would not be open to the Government to step in and simply repeat the regulations within that six-month period. I do not think we should muddy the waters at this stage with too much reference to disallowance. I share the view expressed by Senator Harradine that it is important, since there is support for this motion, that those people who feel they are adversely and improperly affected should put the facts before the Senate Committee so that they can be examined by this chamber. I welcome the fact that the Government has indicated that it is prepared to make changes where anomalies and shortcomings are disclosed. There may, of course, be differences of opinion as to what are anomalies and what are shortcomings.

I express regret at the fact that the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Chipp, is prepared to prejudge this matter and to say that he would not support a disallowance at this stage. It seems to me that until we have the benefit of the Senate Committee inquiry, until we have the evidence of the Commissioner of Taxation and of those who say they are affected in a damaging way, it is a judgment that should be suspended. For Senator Chipp to say that he would rely upon the good faith of the Government is admirable, but I suggest that Senator Chipp has forgotten his Shakespeare. The most important advice which I think Shakespeare would give to Senator Chipp would be to put not his faith in princes. When the Senate has some very limited power to influence the actions of government, I do not suggest that we should trade that off in anticipation of right actions by government. This is a significant matter to many self-employed Australians and others who, in turn, employ other Australians , many of whom are struggling in a difficult economic climate. I believe it most appropriate that the Senate should examine the administration of this proposal. I commend the motion to the Senate and thank honourable senators for their support.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1983 [No. 3]
Motion (by Senator Chipp) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 in relation to gifts of certain property to charitable funds .
Bill presented by Senator Chipp, and read a first time.
Second Reading

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The aim of this Bill is to remove a serious anomaly from the Income Tax Assessment Act. Under existing legislation, farmers who donated food and other products after the disastrous Victorian and South Australian bushfires could be asked to pay income tax on their donations. This is incomprehensible and blatantly unfair. A producer who donates some of his produce to a recognised charity has his gift treated as income for taxation purposes. A money donation, however, would attract a tax deduction. There seems to be no good reason for rewarding one act of charity whilst punishing another. At present, the producer could sell the produce and donate the money but then the charity would have to pay the market price when it sought to buy similar produce. This, in effect, would leave fewer products, be they food, shelter or blankets, in the hands of the charity. Apart from this, it seems to me that there would be many instances where it would be preferable for the charity to get the goods rather than the money.

Taxing donations to charities seems incredible at any time, but it actually stands in the way of getting help to people quickly and effectively during a national disaster. In these instances, our aim should be to get aid to the victims in the quickest possible way. Yet those who are in a position to donate food, shelter and the whole range of products needed to sustain and rebuild the lives of those adversely affected are discouraged from doing so by the current legislation. Should a farmer be penalised for donating food to those who have lost everything, or livestock and seed to a fellow farmer, whose property was destroyed by a bushfire? Should a manufacturer be penalised for donating blankets, processed food, clothing or furniture to recognised charities? Should he be taxed on his generosity?

When I first began to receive representations on this issue, I was amazed that his anomaly had not been rectified before. The Australian Taxation Office is aware of it; governments have been aware of it for years but nobody has been prepared to act. I understand that some members of the government and Opposition have, in the past, expressed interest in correcting this situation, yet the anomaly remains. This legislation will rectify a long standing problem. It will remove the penalty presently attached to donations of trading stock. It will, therefore, facilitate a speedy and more effective transferral of goods to those adversely affected by national disasters. It will allow more people to make a gesture of humanity and generosity without being punished for their troubles. I thank the Senate for its indulgence and commend the Bill to it for a speedy passage.
Debate (on motion by Senator Grimes) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: DAYS AND HOURS OF MEETING AND ORDER OF BUSINESS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. DAYS AND HOURS OF MEETING
Unless otherwise ordered, the days and hours of meeting of the Senate shall be Tuesdays at 2.00 p.m., Wednesdays at 10.00 a.m. and Thursdays at 10.00 a.m.
2. SUSPENSION OF SITTINGS
Unless otherwise ordered, on Wednesdays, the sittings of the Senate, or of a Committee of the Whole, shall be suspended from 12.45 p.m. till 2.00 p.m. and from 6.30 p.m. till 8.00 p.m.
3. ADJOURNMENT OF THE SENATE

Unless otherwise ordered, at 6.30 p.m. on Tuesdays, 11.00 p.m. on Wednesdays and 7.30 p.m. on Thursdays the President shall put the Question-That the Senate do now adjourn-which Question shall be open to debate; if the Senate be in Committee at that hour, the Chairman shall in like manner put the Question-That he do leave the Chair and report to the Senate; and upon such report being made the President shall forthwith put the Question-That the Senate do now adjourn- which Question shall be open to debate: Provided that if the Senate or the Committee be in Division at the time named, the President or the Chairman shall not put the Question referred to till the result of such Division has been declared; and if the business under discussion shall not have been disposed of at such adjournment it shall appear on the Notice Paper for the next sitting day .
4. ROUTINE OF BUSINESS
Notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders and unless otherwise ordered, the Senate shall proceed with its ordinary business in the following routine:
Tuesdays: (1) Petitions
(2) Notices of Motion
(3) Questions
(4) Any proposal pursuant to Standing Order 64
(5) Presentation of Government Papers and consideration pursuant to Sessional Order
(6) Formal Motions-Discovery of Formal Business
(7) Postponement and re-arrangement of Business
(8) Motions and Orders of the day, or vice versa, as set down on the Notice Paper
Wednesdays: (1) Petitions
(2) Notices of Motion
(3) Formal Motions-Discovery of Formal Business
(4) Postponement and re-arrangement of Business
(5) Motions and Orders of the day, or vice versa, as set down on the Notice Paper
(6) At 2.00 p.m., Questions
(7) Any proposal pursuant to Standing Order 64
(8) Presentation of Government Papers and consideration pursuant to Sessional Order
(9) Consideration of Committee Reports, pursuant to Sessional Order
(10) Further Motions and Orders of the Day or vice versa, as set down on the Notice Paper
Thursdays: (1) Petitions
(2) Notices of Motion
(3) Any proposal pursuant to Standing Order 64
(4) Presentation of Government Papers and consideration pursuant to Sessional Order
(5) Formal Motions-Discovery of Formal Business
(6) Postponement and re-arrangement of Business
(7) Motions and Orders of the day or vice versa, as set down on the Notice Paper
(8) At 2.00 p.m., Questions
(9) General Business
(10) Motions and Orders of the day, or vice versa, as set down on the Notice Paper
5. GOVERNMENT AND GENERAL BUSINESS-PRECEDENCE

On all sitting days of the Senate, unless otherwise ordered, Government Business shall take precedence of General Business, except that General Business shall take precedence of Government Business on Thursdays after Questions until the expiration of two and one half-hours or until there is no further debate; and that, unless otherwise ordered, General Business Orders of the Day shall take precedence of General Business Notices of Motion on alternate Thursdays.
6. CONSIDERATION OF GOVERNMENT PAPERS
Unless otherwise ordered, and notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing and Sessional Orders:

(1) On Tuesdays and Wednesdays after Questions and any proposals pursuant to Standing Order 64 and on Thursdays after Notices and any proposal pursuant to Standing Order 64, Papers may be presented by Ministers. Upon the presentation of such Papers a motion may be moved, without notice, that the Senate take note of one, or several, of the Papers.
(2) The debate on any motion moved pursuant to this Sessional Order shall be conducted as follows:
(a) No Senator shall speak for more than five minutes;
(b) If debate pursuant to this Sessional Order is not concluded it shall be interrupted after 30 minutes, and the Senate shall proceed to the consideration of the Business of the Day;

(c) If the debate is adjourned or interrupted by Sessional Order, a motion may be moved for the resumption of the debate either for the Thursday of that week at the time for the consideration of General Business, or for the next day of sitting;
(d) On Thursdays, at the commencement of General Business: (i) when an Order of the Day is called on under this Sessional Order, Senators who have previously spoken may speak again for 5 minutes;
(ii) motions without notice may be moved to take note of Government Papers tabled during the current sitting week and in relation to which no such motion has previously been moved:
provided that debate under this Sessional Order shall be interrupted after 1 hour.

(3) Where debates on motions moved under the provisions of this Sessional Order are adjourned until the next day of sitting and are called on in the normal course of business, Senators who have spoken to the motions under the provisions of this Sessional Order may speak again for the time allowed under Standing Order 407A.
7. CONSIDERATION OF COMMITTEE REPORTS

(1) Notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders, and unless otherwise ordered, where in any week there are Orders of the Day for the resumption of debate on motions for the consideration or adoption of reports of committees:

(a) on Wednesdays after Questions, any proposals pursuant to Standing Order 64 and consideration of Government Papers pursuant to Sessional Order, Orders of the Day relating to reports of committees presented to the Senate during that week shall be severally called on, in the order in which the respective reports were presented;

(b) if there were no committee reports presented during that week, or if debate on motions relating to such reports concludes before the expiration of one hour, Orders of the Day relating to committee reports presented prior to that week shall then be severally called on in an order which is the reverse of the order in which the respective reports were presented;
(c) in any debate on such motions so called on, each Senator may speak for not more than 10 minutes; and
(d) any debate pursuant to this Sessional Order shall be interrupted after the expiration of one hour.

(2) Provided that, where debate on any motion debated under the provisions of this Sessional Order is adjourned or is interrupted under the provisions of this Sessional Order, Senators who have spoken to such motion under the provisions of this Sessional Order may speak again to the motion for the time allowed under Standing Order 407A when the debate on the motion is again called on in the normal course of business.
8. That the foregoing Resolutions have effect from Tuesday, 30 August 1983, and cease to have effect on the first sitting day after 22 September 1983.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is happy to formalise the agreement made with the Opposition and the Australian Democrats that these hours apply for a trial period of three weeks. The effect of this motion can be readily determined by reference to the notional pattern of sittings, copies of which have also been distributed to honourable senators. I will not seek to debate the matter further at this stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the amended motion just moved by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) as it gives effect to an agreement between the parties in the Senate that we should at least, in colloquial terms 'suck it and see'.
—But you do not put your trust in princes either.

—It is a classic case of not putting my trust in princes because I did ask the Government, and I am grateful that it acceded to my request, that it specifically make the proposal the subject of review after three weeks in accordance with the agreement between us. In any event I would like to move one amendment to what has been put forward. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: In paragraph 1. 'Days and Hours of Meeting':
Leave out '2.00 p.m.',
Insert '2.30 p.m.'.

I will speak both to the general proposal and to the amendment. The general proposal with respect to sitting hours is not regarded as satisfactory by the Opposition and I would like to place on record why that is so. The proposed sitting pattern needs to be considered alongside the sitting pattern which is proposed for the House of Representatives. In the broad what we now have is a proposal for sittings during the afternoon of Tuesday for the Senate and during the afternoon and evening for the House of Representatives; during the morning, afternoon and evening on Wednesday for the Senate but during the morning and afternoon only for the House of Representatives; and on Thursday for the morning and afternoon for the Senate but the morning, afternoon and evening for the House of Representatives. In other words there is a very considerable degree of difference between the sitting hours proposed for the two chambers.

There are long periods when neither chamber is in session but not enough of those long periods coincide. The difficulty which the Opposition has with the Government's proposal for both here and the House of Representatives is that taken together they present very real difficulties for running the normal party arrangements which are a part of the operation of this Parliament when a party is represented in both chambers, as of course are the Australian Labor Party, the Liberal Party and the National Party. The Australian Democrats are peculiar in that sense in that they have representation only in the Senate and it is immaterial to them when the House of Representatives chooses to meet.

The sitting hours which are proposed for the two chambers effectively limit the opportunities which we will have to meet as Opposition parties. Traditionally Tuesday morning and Wednesday morning have been available. They were available to the Labor Party when it was in Opposition. It asked, sought and obtained the maintenance of those free mornings not because it liked to have mornings off but because it wished its Caucus and its shadow Cabinet to meet. We have precisely the same wish. Unfortunately, with sittings on Wednesday morning, our shadow Cabinet is required to meet on Monday. That puts a requirement on those of us who live in the more distant parts of Australia, such as Western Australia, north Queensland, the Northern Territory and so on, to leave home, if we can get home on the weekends, on Sunday. That is disruptive both to one's time in the electorate and to one's domestic life. The arrangements we therefore see as being not those which are most favourable to the orderly running of the Parliament-certainly not to the orderly running of the parties which are such an important part of our parliamentary system. I want that put on the record because I hope that the experience of the sitting hours will demonstrate to the Government that more convenient arrangements could be entered into and that in the trial period we might have some further positive discussions on some rearrangement.

I acknowledge the very real concern on both sides of the Parliament to try to find more satisfactory sitting hours. I think that in every debate we hear about the health of members and senators, both mental and physical, and I suspect that both suffer from the arrangements we have. There has been a series of attempts to find more satisfactory hours. I agree that members of the Labor Party, the Australian Democrats, the National Party and my own Party have joined in common searches for sitting hours. When I look at the pattern of sittings I find a standard pattern up to March 1982. There was a change in the period from March 1982 to the end of 1982. We changed again until the end of May 1983, and we are now changing again. I think those changes evidence the very real difficulty in meeting the demands of the chambers, the demands of the parties and the problems of operating a multi-party system in a bicameral legislature. They are real difficulties. Most honourable members and honourable senators live in their respective States and travel great distances. I wish to put on the record my concern that we do more to seek more sensible sitting hours which will enable us to conduct our business better in the national interest.

I am sure that the taxpayers who are paying for this place would not want us to be standing around endlessly discussing this issue. I will close by saying that I move with a clear conscience on behalf of the Opposition the amendment which would give us an additional free half hour in the afternoon on Tuesday because the sitting hours proposal which the Government has put before us provides for 24 1/4 actual chamber hours per week. In my experience that is an all-time high for the number of hours provided. If honourable senators look at the history of sitting hours over recent years they will find that the traditional sitting pattern provided for 21 1/2 hours. The amendment which we made in 1982, very much in co-operation with the then Opposition, was for 21 1/2 hours of sitting. The further change under the new Government took us up to 23 3/4 hours and these proposals are for 24 1/4 hours. If the amendment which is put forward by the Opposition is supported it would take us back to 23 3/4 sitting hours per week, which would match the highest point we have attained in the past, and would, I think, be quite reasonable.

I should explain that the reason why that half hour is required is that it is the normal practice of our Party to meet before the Tuesday sitting to make the necessary arrangements for the week's sittings. We, as a Party, need that additional time. We think it is a reasonable request and we think it leaves the Government with an adequate number of sitting hours. Our history during the life of this Government has been not to waste unduly the time of the Senate. We ran a very modest number of matters of public importance during the first five weeks of sittings-far fewer than the number sought by the previous Opposition. In the interests of fairness to everybody I ask for the support of the Senate in this reduction and I ask the Government to consider very carefully the actual operation of these revised sitting hours with a view to, if possible, making more satisfactory arrangements for the rest of the Budget session.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the beginning of this week we were all circulated with a set of sitting hours which again would have had us sitting late on two nights and in fact would have had us very close to the hours that were rejected previously by the Senate. Rumour had it that the Executive of the Government was ambushed in Caucus by some people who did not like that idea and that the proposed sitting hours we have before us are a result of that. The Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Chaney, has outlined the difficulty this set of hours raises for the Opposition and for its personal arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason I rise is to make a point and a plea. In the great saga of the subject of sitting hours in this place, which now is spread over years, I think one lesson surely has been learnt and that is that one group of people, getting together in someone's office or wherever and trying to draft a pattern of sitting hours, does not have all the information that is necessary for workable sitting hours. Two problems confront the Opposition as a result of this arrangement, matters which, when we were in government and attempts were being made to decide on new sitting hours, the Australian Labor Party in opposition said were absolutely fundamental in any agreement on the matter. I am not suggesting any breach of faith because I understand that these suggested hours do not come entirely from the people who were involved in the previous discussions and negotiations. However, the fact is that things that were previously agreed as being fundamental are not met in the new pattern of sitting hours.

I will be supporting the Opposition amendment because it does make the sitting hours a little more workable for us. However, I wish to make a plea, because I understand that this will be on trial for several weeks, and difficulties will emerge. If we are going to change sitting hours again, and I hope they will be changed or modified a little, could we possibly look at putting together a parliamentary committee-it would not need to meet for very long-to examine the interests of all parties involved. The very long procedure we went through some time ago before we all balloted in this Parliament was one in which I was very involved. I will state briefly to the Senate the major factors that have to be taken into account. One has to take into account Government and Opposition Caucus meetings or party meetings, shadow Cabinet and Cabinet. One has to consider back bench committees, Government, Opposition, parliamentary committees , the dining room, Hansard, even matters such as Senate transport. These are all factors to be considered in putting this piece together. When one puts all that information together and looks at it objectively, one can come up with a pattern which suits all parties.

One side is not trying to ambush the other by suggesting hours that do not suit it and destroy its party meetings or committees. We are trying to agree on sensible hours that will enable us to do our work properly. So if we find bugs in this plan and there is a desire to look at it again, I indicate to the Senate that I think the sensible thing to do is to put together a committee-we could make it a parliamentary committee or an informal committee, as it was previously -put down the information and work it out in a spirit of good will. I think the subject of sitting hours has been basically a subject of good will, although there have been the odd hiccups along the way in debate on it. If we can approach the subject in that sense then we may finally arrive at a set of sitting hours that will stick. I speak, I am sure, for many of my colleagues when I say that I am terribly confused at the moment about when the Senate is sitting and when it is adjourning, because day after day it is different. It is a subject that we would like to see resolved to everyone's satisfaction to the satisfaction of the Western Australians', Government Ministers, and everybody else who has a particular interest in the hours that the Senate meets.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion moved on behalf of the Opposition by Senator Chaney does not have the support of the Australian Democrats. We are basically neutral in regard to the sitting hours during the day. We do not have any members of our Party in the other place and therefore we do not have any interest one way or another as to whether that place starts at 2 p.m. or 2.30 p. m. However, in negotiations the Government has given away half an hour at the end of the afternoon by moving the suspension time from 7 p.m. to 6.30 p.m. and has indicated its willingness to give away another half an hour elsewhere in the program. It seems to us that those are reasonable concessions. The fact that the Government has agreed that Parliament will sit for three-week periods seems to be a major concession and therefore, on balance, we will support the Government' s proposition at this stage and give it a trial for three weeks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose the amendment moved by Senator Chaney, although not out of malice or for any similar reason. As Senator Macklin said, the Government was willing to remove half an hour from another day's sitting if the length of the sitting hours on Tuesday was a problem. I understand that the problem is the desire of the Liberal Party and the National Party of Australia to have a meeting on Tuesday at 2 p.m. The Government is faced with the problem that the sitting hours on Tuesday are very short for the introduction or application of any Government business, and if a matter of public importance were to be moved there would be almost no time. For the short three-week period our preference is that we sit from 2 p.m.

SPEECH.PARA: From a personal point of view and as one who has been involved for almost as long as Senator Martin in trying to settle some sensible sitting hours in this place, and as one who has been-euphemistically, I suppose-negotiating on this matter in the last couple of weeks, I share Senator Martin's frustration in trying to get sensible sitting hours for this chamber. I put it to the Senate quite frankly that certain difficulties exist. I wonder whether we will ever overcome them unless we do what the House of Commons in the United Kingdom and the House of Representatives in the United States do, and that is to ignore the nonsense such as the calling of quorums unless we consider sitting through the meal hours.

There seems to be a basic intractable difference between the attitude of people in this place and people in another place. The people in another place seem to be dominated by those who live in the Sydney-Melbourne-Brisbane axis, although Senator Martin cannot be considered in that group, who have a very different perception of how long we should be here and what constitutes reasonable hours. They seem more determined to get out of this place and this town as quickly as they can, more often than we do. I wonder whether we will ever reach the stage, which I agree with Senator Chaney is the more satisfactory stage, where both Houses have essentially the same sitting hours and the same time off for parliamentary committees and party meetings. I think that, unless we can overcome those difficulties, the Senate will have to do what it has done in the last few years and that is largely to ignore the sitting hours of the other place, except perhaps on Tuesday and Wednesday mornings, and go our own way.

I ask the Senate to support the sitting hours proposed for the next three weeks . Certainly in that time I will talk to the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney), the Australian Democrats, Senator Martin, and anyone else who is interested to try to get some sensible hours for this place, hours which do not disrupt the functions of parties and government, or disrupt them as little as possible. I am almost resigned to the fact that we will have to go our own way. I say to Senator Martin that I will not give up. It has been a long time.

TALK.START.PARA: —How about back to back sittings?
—If Senator Kilgariff, who like me has to change planes to travel to and from his State, and for whom the airline schedules are not very convenient--
—That applies to Brisbane too.
—Yes. If Senator Kilgariff would like to put a proposal for back to back sittings, he will find that it does not fall on barren ground in the case of many people on this side of the House.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Chaney's amendment) be left out .

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to make a personal explanation .
—The honourable senator may proceed.

—During the previous debate it was indicated by the Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Grimes, that the Government was prepared to discuss the question of sitting hours with any honourable senator or honourable member. The fact is that no such discussion has taken place with me. It appears that it has taken place with all other senators or their representatives. Under Standing Orders measures are available to me to disrupt the proceedings of the Senate and, if a similar situation arises at some future stage, those measures will be used.

—by leave-I apologise to Senator Harradine for not involving him in previous consultations. In future negotiations I will ensure that he is included because that is the right thing to do, not because of any threat he makes in this place.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 August, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Family Law Amendment Bill 1983 and I sincerely hope we are able to get through it in this session. It has been a long drawn out debate which first started in 1981. At that time, as the Government of the day, we gave a conscience vote on this legislation. This Government now has decided for the first time not to allow a conscience vote on it. Of course, when the Australian Labor Party was in Government in 1975, the then Whitlam Government allowed a conscience vote on this matter. I am not quite sure on what grounds this Government has decided that it must caucus its members which is the Labor Party's only alternative to a conscience vote.
—Do not misrepresent the situation.

—Senator Grimes has told us in this place that he will not allow Government senators a conscience vote and that he will caucus them on this Bill. Now, because I bring it to the notice of the people of Australia that he is frightened of giving members of his Party the opportunity of voting how they choose--
—That is not so and you know it.
—I am terribly sorry. Why does Senator Grimes not change the ruling right now and make it a conscience vote.
—If anyone wants a conscience vote on any clause, he can have it.

—I was told yesterday by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) that that would mean a return to Caucus. Mr President, I believe one of my amendments will need a conscience vote. What will the Government do? Will it have a special Caucus meeting to decide whether it will permit its members to vote how they wish on that amendment? I thought that the Attorney-General believed time was rather important and that this debate should be carried out and the Bill passed in a speedy fashion. That cannot possibly be done if every time an amendment comes up-I gather there are a considerable number of them- Caucus has to meet to decide whether its members can vote the way their conscience tells them. It really is as ludicrous as that. Had Senator Mulvihill been here, I am quite sure that no such decision would have been taken in Caucus because he would have demanded his rights on this issue.
—And any other senator on this side can do so.
—We were told that it was a unanimous decision of Caucus that there should not be a conscience vote on this issue.
—If any honourable senator wishes to, he will do so.

—But that will happen only after a Caucus meeting. My goodness, this is a democracy. In the past we have been allowed a conscience vote on these issues, but of course that is not to be the case on this occasion. I will be interested to see what happens to some of the amendments I propose to put forward-whether Caucus will meet and say 'Okay boys, you can all vote how you like' or whether Caucus will say 'Not on your life. We might not get it through if you do. You will toe the line'. That is what it amounts to. That is consensus , is it not! The Government says: 'We started this Government with a consensus'. Gee Whiz! Senator Macklin also said that the Australian Democrats have various views on this Bill and that while they will not make it a conscience vote they will be allowed to vote as they like because they hold different opinions. I am not quite sure what all that means but, according to Senator Macklin, they will be voting all over the place too. At least the Opposition has always maintained the same discretion on any moral issue: Every member on this side of the chamber can vote exactly as he or she likes.
—Not all over the place. We are voting according to our consciences.

—Earlier, Senator Macklin told us that there is no such thing. The Family Law Bill was passed in 1975. Because it was passed with a majority of just one vote in the House of Representatives we were promised that there would be a review. That review took place under our former Government in 1980. The Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act was set up. I believe that the hearings conducted by that Committee, of which I was a member, made every politician on that Committee aware of the very great problems, traumas and, indeed, great sadness that accompanies divorce proceedings. That Committee submitted 72 recommendations. They were not unamimous recommendations but there were 72 of them. I am sure that that indicates to the Senate that the original Act was far from being a good Act and that the people of Australia had many problems with it. Individuals primarily affected by that Act did not appear before the Committee; groups represented them. It would not have been possible to have had individuals appear before the Committee. Those groups brought to our notice all of the problems created by the Act. It was from all of those opinions which were put to us that the Committee made 72 recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to discuss some of the figures relating to the number of divorces and the number of children involved in those divorces. I seek leave to have a table relating to those figures incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr President. The table begins at 1970, when there were 12,000 odd divorces. Quite a legitimate comparison to make is that there was, in that year, one divorce for every 9 1/2 marriages. Nearly 17,000 children were involved in those divorces. That is a considerable number.
