As divorce at that time involved proof of fault, parents in particular went through a pretty rough stage. I do not think that the fault provision protected the children in any way.

SPEECH.PARA: That all changed in 1975. At the end of 1975 the new Family Law Bill was enacted. Because under that Act no fault needed to be proved a very big backlog of divorces had to be dealt with. Obviously, people who had been separated for some time but who were not prepared to go through a divorce involving the proof of fault provision were now able to sue for divorce after being separated for the legal period of 12 months. So in 1976 there were over 63,000 divorces. Those divorces involved 73,645 dependent children. That is a tremendous number of children. There was one divorce for every nearly 1 1/2 marriages in that year. The number of divorces then decreased from the high figure in the years immediately after the enactment of the Bill. In 1978 there was a ratio of one divorce for every 2.8 marriages. So the divorce rate did sink. Of course, it started to rise again. This was a great disappointment to me. I could see the figures going down. I thought that when the figures flattened out they might be back to what they were before the new divorce laws came into effect. But we have not reached that stage. The figures started to rise again. I believe that the people of Australia and this Senate should be greatly concerned that these figures are now rising again.

In 1979, which was the low year after the backlog, there were nearly 38,000 divorces. Over 46,000 children were involved in those divorces. As I said, there was one divorce for every 2.8 marriages in that year. In 1980 the figures started to increase. There were over 39,000 divorces. Nearly 47,000 children were involved in those divorces. The figure as a ratio of divorces to marriage started to rise. The latest figure I have is for 1982, in which there were 44, 000 divorces. Fifty-three thousand children were involved in divorces that year. We are now back to the figure of one divorce for every 2.6 marriages in Australia. I believe that those figures are frightening. The Family Law Act states:
The Family Court shall, in the exercise of its jurisdiction . . . have regard to-
(a) the need to preserve and protect the institution of marriage as the union of man and woman to the exclusion of all others voluntarily entered into for life;

I believe that is a tremendously important section of the Act. If we took that out of the Act I would be very upset. The fact that it is in the Act means that we really must abide by it. The Bill should support the institution of marriage as indicated in that section of the Act. Unfortunately, I do not believe that all of the proposed amendments support that section. I will come to that.

I shall indicate some of the amendments with which I agree in the Bill. Under the Act there is a system of closed family courts. A tremendous number of complaints were brought to the Committee about these courts being closed. Judges of those courts now say that they believe that the courts should be open. The Committee visited Western Australia, which was the only State where family courts have always been held in open session because that was the only State which took up that responsibility. When we visited the Western Australian Family Court we found that people did not go to the court just to view the proceedings of the court. Some had said that the courts would be overflowing with spectators but people are not the busybodies that they are depicted to be. I believe that we have to make sure that the identity of the people who are going through this process is protected and I agree that the newspapers must not identify them when they are reporting on the procedures in the courts. As I said, many complaints were heard that closed courts were a bad thing. The judges now agree and they say that justice must not only be done but also must be seen to be done.

One of the other provisions with which I agree relates to injunctions for the personal protection of the wife and children. We were told on many occasions that whilst injunctions had been taken out, the police could not protect the mother and children from a husband who may enter the home against that injunction, threaten violence and often carry it out. That situation is being amended in this Bill and I agree with that. We have also considered the wishes of children. Under the old Act there was an age limit. The wishes of a child were not taken into account until the child reached the age of 14 years. Under the present amendment, children's wishes can be taken into account. But this is a tremendously difficult area. It is a traumatic and very sad area for the children. Many people gave evidence to our Committee. A doctor who specialises in the problems of children said: 'The new divorce law is quite all right for parents. They can get through their divorce very quickly and very easily with virtually no trauma but the children are the ones they seem to fight over and this has affected many children'. According to the evidence we had the problems that the children are now facing are very much greater than they were under the old Act.

Another provision with which I agree is that stepchildren born to the wife of the family and foster children should be treated as part of the family. Any child born through in vitro fertilisation should also be included. Yet another amendment with which I agree is that a third party should be considered in guardianship cases. I think that is most important. I think that often grandparents are the most appropriate people to bring up a child when perhaps both parents are no longer interested or suitable. Guardianship and maintenance can now be given to allow grandparents to bring up the child.

Another area of concern about which the Committee had a lot of evidence was that prior to a divorce, during the 12-month period of separation, many people organised their property to the disadvantage of the other party. We now have amendments which will stop any of this organisation of property until the divorce comes around when the judge will be able to organise the maintenance and property settlements. One of the other matters considered by the Committee was joint applications for divorce. I believe that if both parties want to put in a joint application there should be only the one fee and the Act will be amended to make this situation more equitable.

We now come to one of the provisions with which I do not agree, and that is divorce by post. It was a recommendation of the Committee of which I was a member. I dissociated myself from that particular recommendation and I put in a minority report on it. I believe that divorce by post is very aptly named. It substitutes the posting of documents for the appearance by the parties in court. I do not believe that that does anything at all for the institution of marriage. I quote again what the original Act was meant to do:

The Family Court shall, in the exercise of its jurisdiction . . . have regard to- (a) the need to preserve and protect the institution of marriage as the union of man and woman to the exclusion of all others voluntarily entered into for life;
If anyone can tell me that divorce by post upholds that statement in any way, I will be most surprised. I do not believe that it does. I quote from my minority report, in which I said:

I submit that this procedure devalues marriage. As marriage is an institution central to the continuation of our society, we must ensure that this legislation , while providing the mechanism for divorce, does not destroy the basic structure.

In the Committee's report to the Senate, in the second reading speech of Senator Gareth Evans and in a letter that he sent around trying to allay our fears about divorce by post the reasons for it are given. The reasons for this amendment are given. It is said that divorce by post will save costs, that the parties will not have to pay as much and that they will be able to get their divorce much more cheaply. That is the first reason. It was always No. 1 in the priority. The second reason is that it will save court time. Senator Evans has told us that the second reason for divorce by post was to save court time. The Committee also agreed that it would save court time. Surely to heavens there is more in the dissolution of marriage, more in a marriage vow than costs and the saving of time. I quote again from my minority report in which I said:

The Committee Report states that, quote: 'the real issue is one of costs, both to the State and to the parties involved'. This is the fundamental issue with which I disagree. The Report concludes that measures must be introduced which will save expense.

I do not believe that there is any need to go further on that issue. I do not believe that the prime objective in getting a divorce is how cheaply one can get it. There must be justice in it. I firmly believe that there is no doubt that the law of the land influences individuals and community values and it would therefore be irresponsible for the Parliament to set an example through legislation which failed to endorse a commitment to stable marriage. If all that is required to end a marriage is to fill in forms and post them off, then the concept of long term commitment to a shared partnership is weakened from the very beginning. That is how I wrote my minority report.

I will be moving an amendment in the Committee stage of the debate against divorce by post. It really does concern me greatly. If young people of today are told or become aware that all they have to do is to fill in a lot of forms and they can get a divorce, what value will they place on marriage? It will be so easy. There will be no trauma. There will be no sense of responsibility. It will be a matter of 'let us give it a go and if it does not work we can fill in the forms and get a divorce'. If that happens, in 10 years time, perhaps less, there will be hardly any need at all for any marriage vows of continuity. There is certainly no suggestion that what I quoted from the original Act to support the marriage concept is of any use in this particular amendment.

I will move another amendment because of my prime concern for children. As the Bill stands, with regard to custody very little direction is given to the court, although the proposed amendments give additional direction and guidelines. I will go into more detail on that later but I believe that further amendments should be brought forward for the protection of the child in that area. A further amendment-I have only three-will be in relation to maintenance and the guideline that the judge must follow in that regard. The amendment is very similar to that regarding custody. Again, I will go into it in more detail at the Committee stage. I believe that the judgment and interpretation to be exercised by the court make it necessary for the Senate to spell out its intentions a little more clearly. In her speech on the Bill last night Senator Crowley said:
I wonder a little about the absence of a clear definition of de facto arrangements being treated in the same way as legal marriages.

That concern was brought to the Committee in 1980 and it was decided that people who enter a de facto relationship have every right to do so. They do so because they do not want the ties. It comes through loud and clear that they do not want any legal interference. They do not want ties, formalisation of their marriage or full responsibility. They make a deliberate decision for freedom from all these areas. They say that if one wants to walk out one can. They do not want that legal tie. If, as a parliament, we interfere in their rights, where are they to go? It would force them to live in short term casual relationships, to avoid legal responsibilities. When people take on a de facto relationship, as many do these days, they say to the world loud and clear that they do not want any of these legal ties. It is not up to us as a parliament to force them to do so.

As I have only a few minutes left, I will deal with an area that concerns me. I refer again to divorce by post, because I am concerned that we have not yet seen any regulations. We have not yet seen what appropriate notices and documents must be filled out. Senator Evans, in his letter to us, said:
. . . the Family Court will still have to be satisfied on the basis of evidence before it that the ground for granting a divorce has been established . . .

How? At the moment the Senate has no idea. Senator Evans added that divorce by post would take place only 'where one party has requested it to do so and the other party has not objected'. The other party might not even know it is happening. How the Attorney-General plans to overcome that I am not quite sure. He continued:
It can be expected that the precise procedure to be specified will require the giving of appropriate notices by one party to the other . . .

He said 'it can be expected'. We have no idea how they will be able to contact the spouse of one party if they have no idea where they are. They may be overseas. They may not even know that the divorce is taking place. Again, how is a judge to satisfy himself that the best interests of the child have been catered for if he has not seen the parents? Only one parent would fill in the documents. The other parent may not necessarily be contacted. The judge then has to make a decision that the best interests of the child have been catered for. I do not believe that this is at all possible. It is all pie in the sky stuff. Unless the judge has before him both parents, the two people involved in the dissolution of marriage, how can he possibly assess not only the best interests of the child but also the just and equitable division of property or the amount of maintenance payment? My time has almost expired, but at the Committee stage of the Bill I will say more on the amendments that I have foreshadowed. Once again, I appeal to the Minister who is in charge of this legislation, Senator Grimes, to allow to members of his Government and his party, for example Senator Tate who is sitting beside him, the freedom to vote as they choose and not, having caucused his members--

TALK.START.PARA: —You do not know what arrangements I have made.
—You have picked the wrong person.
—I have just been told that we are not being allowed a conscience vote. Now Senator Tate tells me that I do not know what arrangements he has made.
—That is right; you do not.

—I am quite well aware that I do not. I can only take the word of your Attorney-General that it is not a conscience vote, that it is indeed a caucused vote. If that is not accurate, I would be most delighted to hear about it.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My purpose in participating in this debate tonight on the Family Law Amendment Bill is to try to enhance the institution of marriage, as difficult as that might be. In 1975, when the Family Law Act was passed, it was described as an enlightened piece of legislation. It was a major breakthrough, but with the passage of time it has brought its own problems. The chief persons who are affected or disadvantaged by this Act are the children of those families. It is proposed this week to make amendments which will in effect make divorce very much easier. One who has been very close to the situation of family breakdown in Launceston and who has had a very close relationship with those in need is the superintendent of the Launceston City Mission, Moreton Jones. Some time ago he wrote to me and I sought his permission to quote from that letter. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mr Watson,
As you would be well aware our work in the Mission is to do with families and family counselling.
We work with an average of 160 families per month-and what the family breakdown does-especially to children when you see it every day-would make you cry.
Now, to even give the slightest thought to making divorce easier is surely beyond all reasonable thinking, and is certainly against the laws of God.
I have had many discussions with Government officials-especially in the welfare sector.
The Government is saying on the one hand 'how on earth are we going to cope with the ever-increasing cost of Social Security-particularly as we have people coming on to Benefits each and every day'.

On the other hand, to think that they could even consider for one moment passing legislation to make divorce easier, is surely one of the most tragic pieces of legislation that there has ever been proposed in the long history of legislation.

Perhaps the thing we should do is pour more money into FAMILY EDUCATION PROGRAMMES and help the families of our so called 'lucky country' to see and understand that when the family breaks down so does every part or sector of the community.

The work force suffers because of bad home relationships-education suffers for the same reason-accommodation becomes an even greater problem-health costs soar- we breed more alcoholics-more drug addicts-more mental breakdowns occur-more crime, violence and vandalism is evident.
All this and more happens when the family breaks down-and now the proposed legislation will only send us further and further 'down the drain' of moral decay.

I plead with you on behalf of the hundreds this Mission services-and those I see personally-to fight for the defeat of this Proposal, and come together and do something constructive to build up the family life and not tear it down.

I think that is a very significant contribution from Moreton Jones of the Launceston City Mission. Professor Mitchell of Oxford University believes that the function of law is not only to protect individuals from harm but also to protect the institutions of society. These functions, he says, overlap since the sort of harm an individual may suffer to some extent is determined by the institutions he lives under. Now, we have a massive piece of legislation before us which is aimed at virtually streamlining the concept of divorce rather than reinforcing the concept of marriage. Figures from England show that the number of single parent families is rising by about 6 per cent annually. Further, we find that remarriages are prone to failure. Let me quote some figures. In 1976, 47.9 per cent of previously married couples separated within four years of marriage. However, by 1980 this figure had risen to 55.6 per cent. Toffler, in his book Future Shock, referred to this sort of 'plug-in' type society. I think many people today regard marriage in a similar light-a particular person for a particular age and so on. The cost to society is tremendous and cost alone, I suppose, should be one factor which discourages government from making divorce very much easier. But what is the effect of all of this? Actually, a cycle of marriage is being fostered-divorce and remarriage, second divorce and so on, with corresponding increases.

In my own small State of Tasmania the tragedy of divorce is seen from the figures. In 1981 there were 1,139 divorces. The number rose in 1982 to 1,391. However, 67.3 per cent of divorces in the 1982 figures involved children under 18 years of age. The point I am making is that children are the main sufferers when divorce is made easier. It is now too late to make fundamental changes to the Family Law Act but I hope that we can make sure that the amendments proposed in the legislation before us will not further destroy the fundamental institution of marriage which, according to the figures I have quoted, is disintegrating at an alarming rate. Today we are witnessing a divorce rate of something like one in every three marriages within the country. Since 1975 more than 400,000 children have seen their parents divorced.
I want to take issue with a number of matters that have been raised by Senator Gareth Evans. In this second reading speech he said:

Free from the burden of attributing fault, the Family Court can now concentrate on being satisfied as to the fact of marriage breakdown and on deciding the most equitable distribution of property, the proper level of maintenance and . . . the best possible arrangements for the welfare of any children . . .

How can a court satisfy itself as to marriage breakdown if it does not see anyone about that marriage? I do not agree that 12 months' separation is a sufficiently long period to prove that a breakdown has taken place. However, again, that is a matter of personal opinion. The other issue to which I wish to refer concerns clause 47. Senator Evans had this to say in his second reading speech:
. . . the Government is convinced of the value of this amendment as an important development towards streamlining the procedures of the Family Court and reducing costs to litigants.

There is an emphasis on reducing cost. We have before us a massive piece of legislation which is aimed essentially at streamlining divorce rather than reinforcing the concept of marriage. What really has been done since 1975 to try to reinforce the concept of marriage? Basically, there has been an effort to destroy it.

If we focus our attention on funding we can get some indication of what has been happening in this area. The Budget allocation for pre-marriage education courses in 1975 amounted to $50,000. In 1982-83 again only $50,000 was allocated . The amount allocated for marriage counselling in 1980 was $2.5m. In 1982-83 it was $3.3m. This funding represents an increasing cost to the community, apart from all the social costs and problems that arise. In 1980, $11m was allocated for Family Law Act services. An amount of $14.8m was allocated in 1981-82 and $ 16.1m in 1982-83.

In speaking against these amendments we should look at the statements made by the honourable member for Dundas, Philip Ruddock, when he tabled the report of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act on 28 August 1980. Mr Ruddock, speaking on behalf of his Committee, said:

The Committee shares a concern that marriage be supported and that steps be taken to ensure the stability of marriage. In our view there is a role for family law in supporting an ideal and stable view of marriage. It will be seen that the approach favoured by the Committee is that more emphasis be placed on marriage and the obligations that it entails, rather than the deterrent effects of the provisions of the divorce law as a factor influencing the stability of marriage.

I acknowledge that the Bill picks up about 37 of the 72 recommendations of that Committee but I believe that the legislation is becoming rather hypocritical. Streamlining provisions have been introduced to make divorce easier and these have the effect of breaking down the institution of marriage. Yet section 43, which Senator Walters quoted, states:
The Family Court shall, in the exercise of its jurisdiction . . . have regard to-
(a) the need to preserve and protect the institution of marriage as the union of a man and a woman to the exclusion of all others voluntarily entered into for life;

I presume that on the one hand we are trying in section 43 to enhance and protect the institution of marriage. On the other hand, amendments have been introduced that have the purpose and intent of effectively breaking down marriage. I think this is somewhat regrettable. I agree with the humanitarian view expressed by the Committee. I share its concern but I believe that the provisions of this Bill do not, as I mentioned earlier, enhance and emphasise the institution of marriage. Essentially marriage has become pretty much an unenforceable contract. People who argue in favour of clause 47 again point to the ease and low cost of divorce by post, as it is called. I believe that these concepts are a little bit misleading and are not necessarily always in the interests of those who are undergoing divorce.

Proponents of the Bill claim that the present proceedings surrounding an undefended divorce application are somewhat farcical and routine because many applications take less than one minute to be granted and in many cases the outcome is known well in advance. Although this is usually the case, I believe that for a variety of reasons it is still useful and beneficial to both parties to be present in the court unless it is ruled to be impossible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why?

—The termination of marriage is an important event and it needs to be marked by some sort of ceremony or some right of passage. This is done not to increase the hardship, the embarrassment or the pain of the couple but to allow them the opportunity to make a mark and to start their lives afresh. The appearance in court to some extent could be likened to a funeral service. It is a decisive act. It is an important part of the grief process. Some psychologists point out that it aids a healthy recovery from an emotional loss. It may be easier and it may be more comfortable initially if the parties do not have to attend a court hearing. But ease is not always good. Non-appearance allows people the opportunity to escape from the reality of the divorce and the failure of their relationship. But one of the most worrying aspects of divorce is the number of second marriages which also end in divorce. I cited those figures earlier. Unfortunately the numbers of second marriages ending in failure are increasing at an alarming rate which is a further indication of the breakdown of the institution of the family in our society, with all its consequent social problems.

SPEECH.PARA: I will be supporting a number of amendments including those proposed by Senator Walters and Senator Harradine. I believe that we are discussing a very important issue, an issue which I believe is going to have far reaching effects on the community at large. The stability of our society is very much at risk. I have some concern about the impact that these proposed amendments will have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President-(Quorum formed) The Senate is debating the Family Law Amendment Bill 1983. This particular measure had its genesis in the inquiry of the Senate Select Committee on the Family Law Act. The amendments now before us are not greatly dissimilar to those that were before us in 1982. In fact, they were first brought into the Senate in 1981. Insofar as the amendments give greater protection to children, tighten up measures which are designed to achieve some semblance of equity in property matters and enable a proper attention to be given to areas which previously were neglected, I support them. However, the amendments really amount to fiddling with a system which has been found to be wanting. The test of that, of course, is in the enormous amount of correspondence that each and every member of parliament receives, in the expressions of concern abut the operations of the Family Law Act and, indeed, in the expressions of genuine grievance which innocent persons feel as a result of having been through the Family Court system .

SPEECH.PARA: Nothing in this Bill will go towards remedying the deep sense of grievance and injustice experienced by those people. The reason for that is that this Bill does not go to the heart of the problem. The heart of the problem, insofar as it is legislative, is contained in the original Family Law Act and, specifically, in the definition of irretrievable breakdown which is the sole requirement for dissolution of marriage. That definition, as we all know, is simply separation for 12 months. Furthermore, in the original legislation there is not adequate emphasis on the need to ensure that the parties or the prospective parties have, and are required to have, access to marriage counselling and family counselling services which should achieve, if possible, reconciliation of the parties. These are evident failures, evident blemishes, in the legislation at the moment.

The facts have been stated before in this debate by the two previous speakers, Senator Watson and Senator Walters. The facts concerning marital breakdown, divorce, and their effects on the children, have been stated. Let me remind the Senate of those facts. There is a growing trend towards divorce within Australia . In 1982 there were over 44,000 divorces. The number of children under 18 years of age affected by those divorces was over 53,000, bringing the total number of children under the age of 18 affected by divorce since the family law registration came into effect in 1976 to more than 400,000. It is said by the advocates of the family law legislation that there is machinery-namely, the Family Court of Australia and the family law system-to which they can bring their differences and those differences are then determined by a decree of dissolution of the marriage.

But of course that does not determine the basic human problem. The problem very often is still with the persons concerned. In fact, the evidence for that is in the rate of marriage breakdown for second marriages. The rate of marriage breakdown in Australia for persons who have been divorced and have married for the second time is 50 per cent-almost twice the rate of breakdown of first marriages. The Family Law Amendment Bill 1983 does not even attempt to go to that problem. It fails to give genuine legislative support to the institution of marriage.

As I said at the commencement of my speech, I will support the majority of the amendments in the legislation before the Senate because most of them are not harmful. They tend to assist in certain areas. But they do not go to the heart of the matter. A number of honourable senators and members of the House of Representatives last year, concerned at the fact that the legislation did not give genuine support for the institution of marriage, and concerned at the continued and increasing sense of grievance experienced by a large number of persons who go through the Family Court, sat down and considered what amendments should be made to the original legislation. They were not there to knock the proposals in this Bill or those which were in the previous Bill that came before the Parliament, except of course the matter that has been raised relating to undefended divorces, or the so-called divorce by post proposition. They were not there to knock the other provisions. They sat down simply to grasp the opportunity which this amending Bill provided to do something about the heart of the matter, to go to the heart of the problem.

The meeting came up with certain amendments. A former senator went a good deal further and proposed other amendments which were acceptable to a number of persons. I refer to the amendments proposed by former Senator John Martyr of Western Australia. However, the majority of the meeting considered that those amendments at that stage would not attract majority support of the Parliament. We then proceeded to consider what amendments might attract majority support of the Parliament.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension of the sitting for dinner I had described how provisions of the Family Law Amendment Bill 1983 and those of its predecessor, the Family Law Amendment Bill 1981, had been discussed at length in this chamber. It is not my intention, at this stage, to canvass those propositions at length. It is my intention, however, at the Committee stage, to question the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) about some of the matters contained in the Family Law Amendment Bill 1983 and the differences between that Bill and the 1981 Bill. I mentioned also that most of the provisions in the Bill were unexceptionable and would receive my support. One of the glaring exceptions to that is, of course, the amendments to the Act relating to the divorce by post proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: I pointed out to the Senate that the Bill does not go to the heart of the problem. I pointed out that last year there were over 44,000 divorces with over 53,000 children affected, bringing the total, since 1976, to over 400,000 children-that is to say, children under the age of 18 years-affected by divorce. I said that the amending Bill which is before us does not assist those people who feel a grievous sense of injustice as a result of having gone through the Family Court, particularly those persons who have been deserted and whose partners made applications for the dissolution of marriage which were granted on the basis of 12 months separation. I indicated that a group of senators and members had met and had attempted to come to grips with this problem early last year when the 1981 Family Law Amendment Bill was before the Senate. They did this because the 1981 Amendment Bill and this Bill provide the opportunity for any member of the Parliament to move amendments to the original Act. That provision is contained within the Standing Orders.

Earlier I mentioned that a former honourable senator had put forward a number of wide ranging amendments with which, in principle, I agreed, but in practical terms it would have been impossible for the amendments to be accepted by the Senate. A number of amendments were proposed and were agreed to by that group of senators and members. The amendments attempted to come to grips with the real problem and provide some genuine legislative support for the institution of marriage. Those amendments related to required reconciliation counselling; the rights of applicants for dissolution of marriage; young marriages and the need for required reconciliation processes as well as the time lapse, required before an application for dissolution would be entertained; and additional matters relating to property settlements and the extension of the separation period. Copies of those amendments were circulated in this chamber last year at the time of the debate on the 1981 Bill. Each and every senator received a copy of those amendments. For the benefit of honourable senators I am having those amendments reprinted and redistributed. They were the subject matter of a considerable amount of discussion, and generally of agreement, by the people with whom the matters were raised.

Prior to this legislation coming before the Parliament, a further meeting was convened. Notice of that meeting was sent to a number of honourable senators requesting that they attend. Notice of the meeting was sent to the Whips of all the parties in the Senate and the House of Representatives with a request that others be notified so that consideration could be given to amendments which would give genuine legislative support for the institution of marriage. At that meeting a compendium was tabled. The people who attended the meeting received the compendium which listed the differences between the 1981 amending Bill and the 1983 amending Bill. It listed also the amendments which were foreshadowed during the debate on the 1981 amending Bill in 1982. It included also, of course , the 1983 amending Bill and the Attorney-General's second reading speech.

What concerns me is that these genuine attempts to come to grips with the real legislative problems about which there is so much concern within the community have been somewhat dented by the decision of the Government to declare this amending Bill a Government Bill and bind Government members to vote for it. I was told by an authoritative source within the Australian Labor Party that it was a general feeling that the amending Bill itself should go through, that members were bound to vote for the amending Bill by a decision of the party, and that if other matters were to be brought forward these should be brought forward by way of a private member's Bill. This was quite clear. In fact, this is the bottom line of what has happened. On 23 August the Attorney-General, in answer to a question that I raised in the Senate, replied:

. . . I recommended to my Party-I did indeed initiate this, Senator Harradine, and I make no apology for it-that the Bill be treated as a social measure of an ordinary government kind, save and except insofar as any individual Caucus member wanted to raise, within the Parliamentary Labor Party, the propriety of any particular clause in the Bill being treated in that way. Agreement was reached, without any dissent in the Labor Party room, that the Bill be treated in that particular way with the opportunity being given to honourable members to raise any particular clause of the Bill, as it was then before them and the Parliament, which they thought should attract a conscience or an undisciplined party vote and that the Caucus could then determine that the matter be dealt with in that particular way.

I then asked a supplementary question as to whether that decision bound members of the Australian Labor Party in respect of other amendments that came forward. By implication Senator Evans is now saying that it does not. He said that at that time too. He continued:
I do not think the Caucus decision should be taken as in any way referring to those amendments which have been previously foreshadowed but which are now formally before us.
He immediately went on to contradict that statement by saying, in relation to these amendments:
. . . they are not bound to do so;-
that is, to vote against them-

that is not what I am saying. If any individual wants the matter dealt with in that particular way, as I have indicated, I hope that the procedure to be applied is that that matter will be raised with me. Accordingly I, having the conduct of the legislation on the Government's side, will seek the adjournment of any such matter in order that a party room position on it can be worked out.

So far as I am concerned that is the thin end of the wedge. That puts paid to any attempt by honourable senators to seek to have freely considered amendments which give genuine legislative support to the institution of marriage. The Attorney-General has taken the unprecedented step of declaring matters concerning family law, abortion and the like as social policy of a government character. Senator Murphy did not do that in 1974. What, might I ask, through you, Mr Deputy President, is the position so far as the Caucus members are concerned in relation to the 23 amendments to the amending Bill which honourable senators received only at 12 noon today. What is the situation with respect to, for example, the 'young marriages' provision? Is that a Caucus or a bound vote?

TALK.START.PARA: —They do not know.

—Of course they do not know. The net result of all of this rigmarole by the Attorney-General to bind his party will be that members of the Labor Party who previously indicated support for the very moderate and reasoned amendments that I was going to propose, will not support them on this occasion.
—Nothing to do with their merits?
—They indicated support for them last time, Senator. The indication that the honourable senator has given now is that if any of them wish to support them on this occasion, they must report to him.
—Oh, come on! That is a nonsense statement and you know it.
—Then you must report that to the Caucus. These are your words --
—Senator Harradine, you should address your remarks to the Chair.
—I am sorry. Senator Coleman said that is wrong and that I know it to be.
—I said it is a nonsense.
—Of course it is a nonsense, but that is what Senator Evans has said. In answer to me he said:

SPEECH.PARA: If any individual wants the matter dealt with in that particular way-
that is, to free up the tied vote, the bound vote-

as I have indicated, I hope that the procedure to be applied is that that matter will be raised with me. Accordingly I, having the conduct of the legislation on the Government's side, will seek the adjournment of any such matter in order that a party room position on it can be worked out.

If that is not a party dictating to the individual consciences of the members of the Labor Party, I do not know what is. It does not allow a free and unfettered consideration by the members of the Labor Party of this matter. The only excuse that the Attorney-General has given-Senator Bolkus has not stated his decision; he gave it in Caucus--

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you know what he did in our Caucus?

—I know a good deal of what went on in your Caucus. The only reason given was that there has been a great deal of difficulty in bringing this legislation forward. That difficulty is not my fault. I went to a lot of trouble in relation to the compendium and in preparing the amendments. Honourable senators will see that I have not delayed it. There have been a lot of proposed amendments to this legislation. We have even had 23 more since noon today. In fact, we did not cause the delay. If the truth of the matter is known, the Attorney-General was largely responsible for the delay in these measures coming forth. I repeat that most of these proposals will have my support. I believe that an opportunity should be allowed to consider these matters on their merits.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I am grateful to all honourable senators for their contribution to the second reading debate on the Family Law Amendment Bill 1983-a contribution which for the most part has been constructive and has recognised the significance of the particular measure with which we are now dealing. It is very significant when compared with a good deal of other Commonwealth legislation that occupies the time of this Parliament . The Bill does contain a large number of measures which are of real significance for ordinary men and women in this country. For example, it will permit all children who have been treated as part of one family to be dealt with now by a single court at a single hearing in the event of a breakdown of that family.

SPEECH.PARA: The need to achieve a uniform jurisdiction in this respect, in relation to the guardianship question in particular, has been referred to by Senator Missen and Senator Macklin in this debate. The Bill will again permit a spouse to apply for a property settlement under the Family Law Act, which Act of course recognises indirect and non-financial contributions to the acquisition of property within the marriage without having first to go through a divorce proceeding, which is of course a measure of extreme importance to certain religious denominations. The Bill will now permit a surviving spouse to continue a property settlement action where the other spouse dies before the determination of that action. The Bill will permit the Family Court to be truly able to do justice between parties to the marriage where one party is entitled in the future to substantial superannuation benefits, one area in which there have been spectacular injustices in the way the present law has been operating. The Bill will allow the wishes of a child of any age, where these have been expressed, to be taken into account in the Court's determination of that child's future. No longer will the arbitrary rule apply, and this was adverted to by Senator Zakharov in the debate, that a child must have reached 14 years of age before his or her wishes will be taken into account.

The Bill will enable the Court to attach a power of arrest order to injunctions granted under the Act for the personal protection of spouses and children, again a matter to which Senator Zakharov drew attention in the second reading debate, as did Senator Crowley. The Bill will enable married people to obtain the benefit of State laws in relation to domestic violence in a way that has not hitherto been the case. The Bill will allow the Family Court to be open and the details of its proceedings to be published, with due regard to the privacy of those involved in the proceedings. Those are important measures which will, I believe, assist the public image and understanding of the Family Court and maybe make Family Court judges a little less insulated from public scrutiny than might otherwise be the case.

Most of these reforms have been under consideration for a very long time, some for almost as long as the Act itself has been in operation. Most of them have now been before the Senate, as Senator Harradine indicated, for close on two years. Given the significance to ordinary people in the community of all these measures in the Bill, and given the delays in the implementation of this legislation, it seems to the Government that the passage of this Bill is now a matter of the utmost urgency. This is the reason, as I explained yesterday in Question Time, why the Government has taken the action it has in relation to the free vote issue, an issue which has so exercised Senator Walters and Senator Harradine, that formidable Tasmanian duo-Senator Harradine and Senator Harridan, as someone once said--

TALK.START.PARA: —That won't wash. You could have made it a Government Bill for the purposes of the debate.

—I have explained the situation in that respect. Let me go on. Since Senator Harradine is so deeply interested in the internal processes of the Labor Caucus, having been party to them for so long, let me simply clarify the situation further by drawing to Senator Harradine's attention the actual terms of the Caucus resolution which was passed on 24 May-not earlier this week, as some newspaper reports had it-on this particular matter.
—I did not say it was earlier this week.
—You may not have, Senator, but that was the substance of some reports. The resolution was in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill not be treated as a free vote Bill except insofar as Caucus may resolve in relation to any particular clauses clearly raising conscience issues.

That resolution, as I said in a letter I wrote yesterday to other members of my Party, because I believe it is important to clarify this issue, was based on the Bill as it stood in May. Since then, as I told my fellow Caucus members, further consideration has been given to the Bill and I propose to move a series of further amendments. What I said to my Caucus colleagues in a letter, which I circulated after Question Time yesterday, was this:
I have also received notice from various non-Labor Senators of their intention to move further amendments. The amendments are as follows:
Senator Missen: see Attachment B;
Senator Durack: see Attachment C;
Senator Walters-
and I summarised the three amendments of which I had notice from her relating to clause 25, clause 30, and clause 47--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Harradine
INTERJECT.PARA: and I summarised the three particular matters with which I had clear intimation that Senator Harradine was going to proceed, namely, his amendments in relation to clause 4 and two amendments in relation to clause 20. I then said this:

I would be grateful if you would advise me immediately whether, in terms of the Caucus resolution set out above, you consider that any of these further amendments should be considered by Caucus with a view to resolving that the vote on such amendment be a free vote.

What I have said all along, and there seems to have been some misunderstanding by Senator Harradine about this, is simply that if a member of our Party believes that a particular matter raises a conscience issue he is fully entitled , in terms of our own internal Party processes, to raise that issue within the Caucus in order that a decision can be made by Caucus, not on whether that clause should be opposed or supported but on whether or not the debate and vote on that clause should be treated as a free vote matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, that is the same thing.
—If Senator Harradine believes it is the same thing, he is occupying a slightly different planet from the one on which I am standing at the moment. What I further said was this:

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to amendments which may be moved from the floor of the House and of which we have therefore not yet received notice, I propose that any Labor member who regards an amendment of this kind as requiring a free vote should raise the issue with me. I will then take steps to seek an adjournment of the debate on that amendment pending consideration by Caucus.

Again, the clear implication and my clear intention there was that the resolution of Caucus be to determine whether or not the vote on that particular clause should be a free one. I hope that has clarified the issue and set at rest the doubts that Senator Harradine has been so noisily expressing.

It is for the reason of the urgency and the significance of this measure that I do urge honourable senators not to use the debate on this Bill as an opportunity to indulge in a fruitless re-examination of the underlying philosophy of the Act . That must now be taken as settled, and the task before the Parliament is surely to make that Act work. In the course of this debate Senator Durack appeared to suggest that there had not been enough time for adequate consideration of this Bill since its introduction on 1 June. He was referring in particular to interested bodies such as the Family Law Council and the Law Council of Australia. I say to Senator Durack and anyone else who might be minded to take the same point that the Bill has been very fully considered by both these organisations, and most of the amendments that I will be moving tonight or tomorrow do result from the recommendations of those particular bodies.

Let me now foreshadow briefly the amendments that I propose to move in the Committee stage. In doing so I hope that I will be able to dispose of at least some of the issues which have been raised by earlier speakers in the second reading debate. For a start, there was some discussion in the debate last evening as to the fate of the negotiations with the States for a reference of family law powers. One of the obstacles to a successful conclusion of those negotiations has always been the issue of State child welfare law and the concern of the States that the Commonwealth somehow proposed to intrude into that area. On a number of occasions since assuming office I have endeavoured to assure my State counterparts that that is not so. In a further attempt to convince them of the Commonwealth's position on this matter, I will move an amendment to what is now section 10 of the Act to make it clear that orders made under the Act with respect to guardianship, custody and so on, of a child cannot override orders made in relation to the child under what is commonly termed State child welfare law.

In answer to Senator Missen's queries concerning the progress of the reference negotiations, I can say that earlier this year I was offered by certain States a reference on the terms that it be accompanied by an agreement that would have imposed, unfortunately, unacceptable restrictions on the exercise by the Commonwealth of the powers referred, restrictions that in a number of respects were incompatible with the Bill presently before the Senate. Therefore in July this year-just last month-I wrote to the States asking for a reference to be given in clear and unqualified terms, save for a qualification in respect to child welfare law, that is in terms similar to the proposal put to the Adelaide Constitutional Convention earlier this year, the unfortunate fate of which has already been mentioned by Senator Macklin.

Senator Durack also asserted in his speech that the provisions for parties to consider reconciliation in section 14 of the Family Law Act have become a dead letter. I am pleased to be able to tell him that, in line with a recent Family Law Council recommendation, I will move a group of amendments, the effect of which will be to revise the provisions in section 14 (6) which, as it stands at the moment, requires parties to a marriage of less than two years to consider reconciliation, with a marriage counsellor, prior to the hearing of their application for divorce. The revised provision will require those who have been married for less than two years to have reconciliation counselling prior to the filing of the application for divorce, rather than just before the hearing of the application.

Futhermore, I indicate that this revised provision will not be buried away in section 14, where it is at the moment, but will appear in section 44 of the Act, which deals with the institution of proceedings. I understand that particularly when parties act for themselves, as they now do often in dissolution proceedings , it is possible for them to overlook this requirement, buried as it is in a quite different part of the Act, for reconciliation counselling where the marriage is of less than two years duration. It is expected that, when parties act for themselves, they will at least look at the provisions in the Act where the basic procedures are laid out. That is now where this particular new and more far reaching requirement will be located. I draw this amendment particularly to Senator Harradine's attention since I understand that he is concerned particularly about the breakdown of short marriages-as well as, of course, about long ones and medium sized ones. But he has indicated a particular concern about short marriages and I believe that this amendment will seriously assist the cause, if it is a possible one, of saving at least some of those marriages from dissolution.

Another group of amendments that I will be moving relate to section 87 of the Act under which parties can enter into an agreement in substitution for their rights to apply for property settlement or maintenance orders under the Act. Such agreements must be approved by the Court before they can be of any effect but nonetheless they will make unnecessary a number of present court proceedings . I will leave the details of these amendments to the Committee stage. At this point I merely say that I did not include these amendments in the Bill when I originally introduced it in June because I considered that they were of such complexity and significance that they required consideration of the Family Law Council in conjunction with the Law Council of Australia and also a Family Court judges committee. That consideration and consultation has taken place and I am now, as a result, in a position to move these very important amendments to section 87. I take this opportunity to thank the Family Law Council and the Family Law Committee of the Law Council and the judges for their very prompt assistance in this very complex and difficult matter.

Similarly, most of the other significant amendments that I will be moving have resulted from recommendations of the Family Law Council, the Family Court Judges Law Reform Committee and the Law Council Committee. I will mention these amendments only briefly. They include, for example, an amendment to the wording of the definition of custody, amendments to the provisions concerning the exercise of additional powers by registrars and amendments to permit the publication of Family Court lists, by names of parties, in newspapers, at least in large cities, where there are exceptional circumstances of which the judges are persuaded.

I wish to say a few words about some of the more fundamental philosophical issues that have been canvassed, inevitably I fear, in this debate. As to any suggestion that the present separation period necessary to establish irretrievable breakdown as the sole ground for divorce should be extended from one year to two, as has been suggested by Senator Durack and which I believe is also favoured by Senator Harradine, it ought to be pointed out that that kind of move is at odds with experience in comparable countries elsewhere. In particular , in the United Kingdom the sole grounds for divorce is that a marriage has irretrievably broken down. That ground is established by several different kinds of proof: Proof of adultery, certainly; proof of intolerable behaviour or desertion by the respondent; as well as proof by separation for two years with the consent of the respondent to the divorce or, alternatively, separation for five years.

TALK.START.PARA: —It received no support from the joint committee investigating it .

—Indeed, and that is the very point that I want to make, Senator Missen. In a country where this, albeit as one among a number of grounds rather than the sole ground, is expressed in terms of a two-year separation period rather than one, the move has in fact been away from that back to a period of one year. In 1979 a committee of United Kingdom solicitors, in a report known as 'A Better Way Out', recommended that the sole ground for divorce should be irretrievable breakdown or marriage established by proof of separation of not less than one year immediately preceding the presentation of a petition. This recommendation was reviewed by a further committee in 1982 which endorsed the position of the 1979 committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The question of an extension of the separation period required for divorce was considered by the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act and that committee considered that there should be no change to the provisions of the Act relating to the grounds for divorce in this country. The Parliamentary Joint Select Committee received many submissions advocating extension of the period of separation required for divorce on the grounds that this would enhance the possibility for reconciliation. However, the Joint Committee accepted the evidence of those working in the area of marital therapy-I refer to marriage guidance organisations, the Family Court counselling service and the marriage guidance councils-that the prospect of reconciliation diminishes with the period the spouses remain separated. On the evidence of those bodies working at the coal face twelve months is ample for the full consequences of separation to be experienced.

Also it is true that many of the submissions received by the Joint Select Committee in this regard recommended the inclusion of adultery or various kinds of intolerable behaviour as grounds for instant divorce. It needs to be repeated that the Joint Select Committee emphatically rejected the reintroduction of the concept of fault into Australian divorce law. It was particularly critical of the introduction of instant grounds for divorce as an alternative to the ground requiring a separation period on the basis that that went much further towards establishing the genuineness of the irretrievability of the marriage breakdown than any more instant ground, however much more instant grounds might satisfy the moral fervour of some people in this chamber or who contributed to that debate.

I mention finally that Senator Durack has indicated that he and Senator Chaney intend to move an amendent to section 75(2) (f) of the Family Law Act that will have the effect of not requiring the Court to take into account pensions or benefits under any law of the Commonwealth, a State or Territory in the context of making maintenance orders. I point out immediately that, even if successful, that amendment would not prevent a court taking account of such pension or benefit under section 75(2) (o) which enables a court to take into account any fact or circumstance which, in its opinion, the justice of the case requires it to take account of.

The issue underlying all this, as to whether public funds should be utilised in supporting spouses and dependent children in the unfortunate event of a marriage breakdown, is, I readily acknowledge, a vexed and complex one. But I consider that persons who are capable of maintaining their spouses and children in need of financial support should not be relieved of their responsibilities because the dependent spouse is eligible for social service benefits. But against that, I also agree with the view expressed by the Parliamentary Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act that those without adequate means of support should be assisted by the State.

Inextricably linked with this issue is the present quite unsatisfactory state of maintenance enforcement and collection. I believe Senator Durack's amendment would result in higher maintenance awards and would place a much greater burden on the already inadequate maintenance enforcement system. Because of my concern about maintenance, I have established a departmental inquiry into the present state of collection and enforcement. That inquiry is now investigating the mechanisms in place in various States and overseas and examining the possibility of establishing a national maintenance enforcement and collection agency. That inquiry is well advanced and I anticipate receiving its recommendations by the end of this year. Until maintenance collection is operating properly and until there is clear evidence that there will be savings to the Commonwealth-it is no use having maintenance orders if they cannot be enforced and if the social security system has to bear the burden anyway-I am not disposed to accept this particular amendment foreshadowed by Senators Durack and Chaney.

TALK.START.PARA: —Were your views on this subject correctly reported in the Australian on 11 April this year?

—It is very rarely that my views are correctly reported in the Australian on this or any other matter. I will need to take that question on notice. Family law is of vital importance to hundreds of thousands of Australians. This Bill will effect a number of long overdue reforms in family law and procedure. I wish it, although I do not expect it to have, a speedy passage.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 and 2-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 3 (Interpretation).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 4, clause 3, lines 25 to 41, leave out proposed paragraphs (ea) and ( eb), substitute the following paragraphs:
'' '(ea) proceedings between- (i) the parties to a marriage; or
(ii) if one of the parties to a marriage has died-the other party to the marriage and the legal personal representative of the deceased party to the marriage,
being proceedings- (iii) for the enforcement of, or otherwise in relation to, a maintenance agreement that has been approved under section 87 and the approval of which has not been revoked;
(iv) in relation to a maintenance agreement the approval of which under section 87 has been revoked; or

(v) with respect to the enforcement under this Act of a maintenance agreement that is registered in a court under section 86 or an overseas maintenance agreement that is registered in a court under regulations made pursuant to section 89;
(eb) proceedings with respect to the enforcement of a decree made under the law of an overseas country in proceedings of a kind referred to in paragraph (c), ( cb), (cc), (cd) or (ce); or';''.
Essentially, this is a technical amendment on definitional matters. It is related to the more substantial group of amendments that I will be later moving in relation to clause 87.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 4 agreed to.
Proposed new clauses 4A, 4B and 4C.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 6, after clause 4 insert the following new clauses:
Child welfare law not affected
''4A. Section 10 of the Principal Act is amended- (a) by omitting from sub- section (2) 'Subject to sub-section (3), nothing' and substituting 'Nothing'; and

(b) by omitting from sub-section (3) 'and an order made in accordance with this sub-section has effect notwithstanding any order or action of the kind referred to in paragraph (2) (b) or (d) made or taken before the making of the order made in accordance with this sub-section'.
Conciliation
''4B. Section 14 of the Principal Act is amended by omitting sub-section (6).
Admissions made to marriage counsellors, &c.

''4C. Section 18 of the Principal Act is amended by omitting from paragraph (1) (b) 'in accordance with sub-section 14 (2A) or paragraph 14 (6) (a)' and substituting 'for the purposes of sub-section 14 (2A) or sub-paragraph 44 (1B) ( a) (ii)'.''.

I should explain the context of the amendment. Clause 4A amends sections 10 (2) and 10 (3) of the Family Law Act to provide that an order made under the Family Law Act with respect to the maintenance, custody or guardianship of the child of the marriage does not override an order made with respect to the child under what is commonly termed State child welfare law. As I indicated earlier, the impact of this is to preserve clearly State child welfare law for the States and make that absolutely clear and, in the process, one hopes assist the States to concentrate their minds on the merits of a reference of powers to the Commonwealth. Proposed new clauses 4B and 4C are simply consequentials related to amendment No. 3 which we will get to later on and which I understand is uncontroversial.

TALK.START.PARA: — A full explanation has not been given of the proposed new clauses. As I read the amending Bill, the position as previously envisaged by it could well have involved foster children in the decision-making process of the Family Court of Australia. Now clearly, were foster children ever to be considered by some natural parents to be, at some subsequent stage, subject to decision by the Family Court rather than the welfare agencies of the States, then those parents could well lose faith in the welfare agencies which had the responsibility to place their child in a home which reflected all of the circumstances of the case. I am not too sure whether the amendment which has now been moved by the Attorney-General to his Family Law Amendment Bill is designed to overcome that fear. It has been raised with me that there is a real fear that the credibility of welfare agencies in the States may be at stake were the original amending Bill carried in its pristine state. Maybe this amendment is an attempt to overcome that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I sought to make clear in my second reading speech and also in my brief account of what these proposed new clauses are about that that is indeed as I understand what the draftsman is about and what we are trying to accomplish here to make it absolutely clear that orders that are made in essentially child welfare matters by State courts are not overriden by the Family Court of Australia in the exercise of its essentially Family Court jurisdiction. It is to deal with that particular concern on which we are quite willing to accommodate the State that this exercise in clarification of what is actually section 10 of the Family Law Act was set in train. So I do not think there are any grounds for Senator Harradine to be concerned here. I think we have attended to what I understand to be the nature of his problem.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed new clauses agreed to.
Proposed new clause 4D.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 6, after clause 4, insert the following new clause:
''4D. Section 14 of the Principal Act is amended by omitting sub-section (6) and substituting the following sub-section:
'6. In any application for dissolution of marriage the court shall not hear the proceedings unless the court is satisfied that-

(a) the parties, together and separately, have had the assistance of a marriage counsellor, an approved marriage counselling organization or other suitable person or organization nominated by the Principal Director of Court Counselling of the Family Court or by an appropriate officer of a Family Court of a State for the purpose of considering a reconciliation; or
(b) there are special circumstances by reason of which the hearing should proceed.'.''.

The purpose of this amendment is to raise the question of required conciliation conferences in respect of applicants for dissolution of marriage. I am attempting to omit section 14 (6) which has already been omitted by Senator Gareth Evans. I believe that the amendment deserves the support of this Parliament. It relates to the situation in which two people who have made a covenant or a commitment to each other, for some reason or other come to the situation where one of them has made an application for dissolution of that covenant, namely, the dissolution of marriage. All members of parliament would feel, I think, that if something could be done to resolve that problem it ought to be done. At the moment it is quite clear that though the judge has the right to question whether cohabitation can be resumed and whether there has been counselling, those of us who know something about the operation of the Family Court know that much of the counselling is not reconciliation counselling but is in fact separation counselling. I do not deny that it is necessary for the parties to the dispute, if you like, to have made available to them by professional persons details of the consequences of their own actions as far as their children, their property and they themselves are concerned. What this amendment seeks to do, however, is to require reconciliation counselling. On the face of it, that may seem to be a contradiction of terms. How can one force a person to have reconciliation counselling? But of course this is provided for in other legislation. It is contained in the various pieces of racial discrimination legislation and it is in the sex discrimination legislation which is currently before the Parliament. In fact there is, under threat of heavy penalty, a requirement of the persons involved in those difficult areas of personal communications and personal conflict to come to what is called in those instances a conciliation conference.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has not much chance of success though, has it?

—I will come to that in a moment. It has a chance of success insofar as the Sex Discrimination Bill is concerned because of the powers of the person before whom the conciliation conference takes place. It is a bit like the conciliation and arbitration provisions. The conciliation processes are effective because of the recommendatory powers of the chairman of the conciliation conference or the conciliator. In this instance, of course, a report goes from the counsellor to the court. In my view, it is absolutely essential to raise this issue of required conciliation. The experience of conciliation counsellors in the field suggest that, whilst there is resentment sometimes when it is suggested that persons sit down and conciliate, once that resentment is directed to the proper area very often a settlement can be achieved. I believe that we as parliamentarians, if we are in the business of community consensus, which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) himself is very clear about, surely we ought to be in the business of giving legislative support for reconciliation consensus in the very important human relationship area of marriage.

SPEECH.PARA: I commend the Attorney-General for the additional amendment that he proposes to move in respect of young marriages, short marriages, call them what you will. In that instance the proposition which will be put before us at a later stage will be that there will be required conciliation with the aim of a reconciliation prior to the application for the dissolution in respect of marriages which are of a duration of less than two years. I am not proposing that that proposition be applied in this instance. I would like to see that occur. In fact, I would like to see the layers right out of it and their being required, before they submit any paper or document to the Family Court, to ensure that there is a conciliation process. Lawyers being lawyers, once the documents are filed people are in an adversary position and the parties very often feel that they are in a situation which is grinding to a conclusion. I apologise to lawyers for saying that.

This amendment does not do that. What it does is simply this: It requires conciliation for the purpose of considering a reconciliation after an application is made for the dissolution of a marriage, ensuring that the court does not hear the proceedings unless the court is satisfied that that has taken place. It is the old story-I think this is the real problem with the whole of the Family Law Act-that hard cases make bad law. I think that has been the problem from the start in the whole of the family law legislation. It might be said: 'Oh well, that is a hard case. We cannot get Joe Blow to conciliate, to come to the conference'. He might be overseas. He might be in a situation which makes it impossible for him to come to the conference. There might also be a situation in which the very presence before a conference of two people whose love has turned to absolute enmity might lead to physical conflict or something of that character. In this proposition that I am putting to the Senate I am leaving it open to the court to proceed when there are special circumstances under which the hearing should proceed. In all fairness, I suggest that this amendment merits the support of the whole of the Senate. I believe that it is not one of those measures that actually reopens the whole debate, although the next one will be. I believe that it is very worth while considering. It had the very strong support of a group of honourable senators, many of whom held quite divergent opinions on many other issues, on the last occasion it was debated. I ask the Attorney-General to consider this matter very thoroughly and if he cannot agree to it immediately at least to postpone consideration of the clause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine's amendment would make compulsory reconciliation counselling for all divorcing couples, not just those who have been married for less than two years. It is an attractive concept, I readily agree. Certainly, the opposition to it, which I feel now bound to express, is not based on any considerations of principle but rather on considerations of resources and the best cost benefit application of those necessarily scarce resources. It will be recalled-indeed, Senator Harradine mentioned it-that I will be moving my own amendment to section 14 (6) in a few minutes to replace it with new provisions in section 44 to require persons married for less than two years to have that kind of reconciliation counselling not just at the moment before they get into court but before they file their applications. I think that is sufficient demonstration of my desire and the Government's desire to accommodate as far as possible the kind of point Senator Harradine is making. The difficulty about it is that it would require a very considerable increase in resources both of the Family Court counselling service and approved marriage counselling organisations which play such a marvellous supplementary role.

SPEECH.PARA: For the last year for which we had complete figures readily available, 1980, there were 523 completed compulsory section 14 (6) counselling conferences. In the same year there were 39,258 divorces. Those 523 conferences represented just 2.2 per cent of all counselling provided by the Family Court counselling service . The stark reality of those figures would be readily apparent. There are just not the resources either within the counselling service itself or externally in the community to enable any kind of serious attempt to provide reconciliation counselling for all couples undergoing the divorce experience. Given that fact, it seems more desirable to focus reconciliation counselling attention on those areas where experience demonstrates that such counselling is likely to have the most useful impact. That is undoubtedly in the area of short or young marriages, as the case may be.

Moreover, the fear is that the extension of section 14 (6) to all divorce applications would be likely in practice to lead to little more than the applicants being required to go through a further procedural step. It would not be likely to be seriously regarded, particularly given resource constraints and presumably the necessity as a result to process people very much like sausages through the machine in order to satisfy this procedural step. That point itself was acknowledged by the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act. Nonetheless, it thought that section 14 (6) was certainly worth preserving in its present form for marriages of short duration. I can do no more than repeat that no further consideration of this in the present resource climate would alter the Government's reaction, although I am very tempted by the merits of Senator Harradine's proposal and very much appreciate the sincerity with which it is put forward. It is simply not a proposal that we are able to accommodate consistently with the resources available to the family law administration.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder whether that exhausts the ultimate view of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). It seems to me that it is something of an indictment of this community and this Parliament if our priorities are such that resources are not available to prevent the dissolution and failure of marriages. We may well find that there is merit in the amendment put forward and that with more concilliation we might have fewer divorces. That might be a cost saving in itself. As Senator Harradine said, there are compulsory conciliation provisions in other pieces of legislation. Marriage is a socially and legally binding contract and is one of those contracts that in many cases does not only influence and affect the direct participants but also may well have a traumatic and direct effect upon others such as the children to a marriage. I would have thought that it was a pretty unsatisfactory proposition to say that this amendment cannot be carried because the community cannot afford it. I ask Senator Evans to reconsider it on that basis.

—Senator Evans, I honestly am not being difficult in any way. I want to understand what you intend to do about the voting on your side? Would this be the sort of situation-I am not being difficult, I do not understand it-
—Senator Walters, I think, you should address your remarks through the Chair.

—Mr Chairman, could you ask Senator Evans? I fail to understand how these amendments are to be put through. I am not the only one on this side of the chamber who does not understand what procedure the Government is to adopt on the voting on these clauses. In all good faith, I honestly do not have a clue . I support Senator Crichton-Browne. I believe we could make a lot more use of the conciliatory services of the community. Many community services are not used to the hilt at the moment. They would, of course, need subsidising but not to the same extent as the family law councillors would need payment. We should not wipe off what Senator Evans has admitted is a very good idea. He said that the only reason he is not taking it up is that the cost to the taxpayer is too great and that we just do not have the facilities or the counsellors available. When we look at the figures he has given us we can understand the difficulties. But I think it would be a shame to wipe the idea off rather than attempt to alter the fault that is stopping its adoption.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The sentiments in paragraph ( a) of the amendment could not be disagreed with, as the Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans) has said. If it were brought into effect the real work would probably need to be done in the area of marriage counselling organisations . There is no doubt whatever that what should be in place of this clause is pre- marriage counselling. Young people should be encouraged to seek counselling prior to entering into marriage.
