A large and constant advertising program of the right kind should be mounted to encourage people to seek advice about the state of their marriage at a time when they understand or feel that it is not working as they would wish it to. If we get toothache we go to the dentist as soon as we get it. But for some reason in personal relationships there is a natural tendency to try to hide the problem and not talk about it, or else, talk about it to someone who is totally unsuitable to try to help solve it. We need some sort of educative program to encourage people to seek help at a very early stage preferably, in that instance, through a marriage counselling organisation rather than the court structure. The mere fact of going to a court counsellor at that time would perhaps make a person feel that he was getting near the stage of being in court. They are my views as to what we should aim for in the first part of the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: What really troubles me about the amendment is paragraph (b). I wonder what is really meant by 'there are special circumstances by reason of which the hearing should proceed'. I know that the same phrase appears in section 14 of the Family Law Act as it has been operating. It relates there, though, to the provision that the parties to a marriage of less than two years duration must have been to counselling with a view to seeking a reconciliation. It says that in the event a hearing can proceed if there are special circumstances. But in that situation if a person cannot establish that there are special circumstances at least he knows that he has only to wait for the expiration of the period of two years and then he is entitled to a divorce. It cannot be stopped. In this situation, the paragraph seems to me incredibly open-ended. In some cases a person may want a divorce-perhaps is entitled to it-and the other party, for no reason of genuine reconciliation, may use this device merely as a means of stringing out the process and making life more difficult for the party seeking the divorce.

My real concern is that paragraph (b) is incredibly open-ended in this situation. I say this even though I have a lot of sympathy for the concept of paragraph (a). However, I hope we would in fact work towards the advertising, promotion and education to which I have referred. However, I feel I really cannot support the amendment in view of the open-ended nature of paragraph (b).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I express a similar view to that of Senator Reid, that though it is desirable, of course, in the best of all worlds to have more conciliation, opportunities for conferences and so forth-of course this would help-the facilities of the court are restricted. There have been restrictions on the extent to which we have developed the Family Court system. We have never achieved a situation in which the Family Court covers the whole jurisdiction. A great deal is done by magistrates' courts, which do not have the facilities of a Family Court. I would accord a higher priority to the attempt to bring, to a lot more people in this country, the Family Court system and its facilities, than I would the provision before us.

SPEECH.PARA: I join Senator Reid in saying that I believe the proposed provision could be an obstruction to people who wanted to proceed. There may not be enough people to carry out the work that would have to be done. As a consequence, delays would be caused and perhaps people would not have their family situation resolved until much later than would otherwise be the case. That would be a poor feature of any such procedure. Having more conciliation has, of course, desirable features. There may be occasions on which people who have gone a fair way along the road to divorce may be conciliated and as a result withdraw their proceedings. However, once they had broken up, this would be a pretty rare occurrence. Therefore, I believe that the proposed amendment would very much hamper the ability of the court to bring justice-often quick justice-to people whose families are in a state of considerable disorder. For these reasons I think that the amendment should be opposed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like briefly to put my position in relation to the proposed amendment. I am not so concerned by the expressions of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) and my colleague Senator Missen about the costs and practical difficulties in implementing the provision because it is accepted that marriage breakdown itself is costing the community a great deal. Also I am not so concerned with the expression of concern by my colleague Senator Reid as to the broad language used in paragraph (b). I understand its purpose, which is to ensure that the court has added flexibility. But my concern is that the proposed amendment appears to be trying to resolve a problem far too late. Parties that come to the Family Law Court do so when their marriage has broken down. I do not believe the amendment will have the effect of saving marriages. If I thought it would I would have a different attitude to it and would support it. But I am afraid it is really trying to resolve a problem far too late.

SPEECH.PARA: When I spoke during the second reading debate on the legislation that was before the Senate in August of last year I put views similar to those of Senator Reid on that aspect. I said that the community and law should look to support marriage and the family, for example, in the encouragement of, and if necessary, financial assistance to, voluntary counselling organisations, in seeking ways to overcome the stress of unemployment, ways to overcome the damage caused by financial pressures and so on. I also mentioned that we should look at ways of reforming the income tax laws, which actually put pressure upon marriages. I think that if we looked in directions such as those we would have a better chance of achieving the purposes that Senator Harradine wishes in good faith to achieve by his amendment. However, I feel that the amendment, in the terms in which it has been put to the Committee tonight, will not achieve the purpose he desires.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only contrary point that I would like to make about Senator Hill's comment, that dissolution could reach a stage where counselling would be too late, is that the requirement to seek counselling would be part of an educative process. If people were aware that they must go to a counsellor before their case was actually heard in court it would be a fine way of educating people that it was right to do so. People would go to counsellors at an earlier stage. Senator Hill rightly said that people at this stage of the proceedings go-
—How will it get them to go to a counsellor earlier?

—Because it will become an accepted practice to go earlier. At the moment it is not an accepted practice. The figures that Senator Gareth Evans has given us tonight prove beyond any shadow of doubt that it is not at the moment the accepted practice in the community to go before a counsellor. If that is compulsory before one can get a divorce, people will be educated to the fact that it is an acceptable thing to do. I think that, as a result, people will go to a counsellor at an earlier stage, the stage at which, as Senator Hill has said, their problem should be picked up. However, because counselling is not yet acceptable in the community it is almost impossible to pick up people at that stage. For that very reason I would support the proposed amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find some difficulty in understanding what I perceive to be the almost universal view in this chamber, in support of the amendment proposed by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans), that participants in marriages of less than two years duration should be compelled to seek compulsory conciliation of one sort or another while at the same time one hears four or five arguments put that in respect of marriages of more than two years duration such a requirement is not necessary, will not work or deserves a poor priority. I would have thought that there was an absolute conflict in what had been said. I am sure that most of us have had the experience of having friends who over the years have separated. Inevitably one feels that if only they had been compelled to seek some form of conciliation and had overcome pride and a prejudiced view about conciliation, things might have been quite different. Perhaps if more wives had managed to get their husbands to the barrier, many of the hurdles that have caused marriages to fail for all the wrong reasons might have been overcome. I find it difficult to reconcile the support that has been given the Attorney-General's proposition and the lack of support that has been given to Senator Harradine's proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: I accept what the Attorney-General says, although I do not agree with him, that his only reservation concerns the cost. Whilst I thoroughly disagree with the priorities in the community, I find it difficult to reconcile the support that that proposition has with the lack of support that has been given to other arguments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to just add this: I would not wish it to be thought that the only point I was making was one relating to the hard cruel world of cost and resources. I did say that it was a matter of calculating both the costs and benefits involved and weighing one against the other. Of course, when one is trying to assess the benefits side of the equation in relation to compulsory counselling, there is more than one view abroad about that. The view of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act, for example, was that any counselling which is compulsory in character can very easily be reduced to a mere procedural formality. In fact, the expression ' farcical' was used. That is a concern that has been quite genuinely expressed by many people who otherwise are totally committed to the concept of counselling in appropriate cases.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the other view, of course, of the benefits of counselling is that there is merit in it in all situations whether it is compulsorily or voluntarily entered into. I think all I was really trying to say was that when one is weighing it all up, although on balance it may well be that counselling would be of very strategic and useful significance in particular cases of marriages of longer duration than just the short ones for which compulsory counselling will obtain, that benefit is not so obvious or startling that it would justify the really quite massive use of resources that are involved on the other side of the equation to match it. I think that is the sort of point that was being made by a number of other speakers in different ways.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you support it if you could afford it?

—I think I probably would but I would be concerned about the element of compulsion in relation to any aspect of counselling for the reasons that so many professionals in the field have put forward. I think that, on balance, I probably would support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It appears that the proposition has a good deal of support in principle. I am heartened by the last statement of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). The question, of course, boils down to three arguments. As I understand it the arguments against it are cost, consequent delay and the use of the device to string out the point that Senator Reid raised about the possibility that paragraph (b) was incredibly open-ended, to use Senator Reid's words. A couple of other points were made, one of which was that we ought to concentrate on pre-marital advice and education. I am not sure who made this point but it was stated that by the time people made an application to the Family Court it really was too late.

SPEECH.PARA: I will deal with those two latter comments first. In relation to the last matter, the fact is that we are about to vote in support of a proposition whereby to a person who goes to a lawyer and asks a lawyer to serve documents and then to file the documents with the Family Court will be required to undertake conciliation counselling. If the arguemnt is valid that it is all too late when the application is made to the court-that may be half an hour after the people have seen the lawyer-is that argument then valid in respect of the previous matter? Of course it is not. There is always hope for reconciliation. The point made by Senator Ried about pre-marital education and advice is very important. I think that point was made by Senator Hill as well. But too much lip service has been given to that issue over many years. Do honourable senators know how much the taxpayers of Australia spend on such advice? How much did the previous Government spend on it? It spent a miserable $50,000 a year. That is not enough to scratch oneself with. The amount spent has been the same for many years. As far as I know-the Attorney can correct me if I am wrong because I have not looked at the Budget figures this year-the Budget is the same this year. That is an indictment on us. I agree with what Senator Hill and Senator Ried have said. We do not give enough emphasis to pre-marital education. We do not even see-

TALK.START.PARA: —Organisations do try.

—Yes. There are a number of voluntary organisations in that field but those voluntary organisations are struggling. I come back to the major points. Another point that was made in passing related to cost. It is suggested in this amendment that the conciliation counselling should take the form of counselling by the court counsellors. As the Attorney has said, the fact of the matter is that only 2.2 per cent of all applicants for a dissolution of marriage receive any counselling whatsoever from either the Court or-I do not know whether the figures were meant to include-
—I doubt it.

—The figures probably include those from the Court. Much of that counselling is not conciliation counselling, as I mentioned before. It is really separation counselling in an endeavour to get them off the books. I do not think that that is an argument at all. If, by the carriage of my amendment, we salvaged only 1,000 marriages, how much would we save the taxpayer in the cost of the supporting parents' benefit and the like? The economic cost-I ask honourable senators to forget about the psychological cost for the moment-of marriage breakdowns and divorces is a matter which is coming to the fore in the consciousness of the Australian public. If we as a Parliament are not prepared to tackle this issue, to give conciliation a go in this area, then, in my view, we are not doing the job.

SPEECH.PARA: The major point that was raised by Senator Reid concerned the possible open- endedness of paragraph (b). I included paragraph (b) in my amendment specifically to enable the Family Court to declare that special circumstances exist. Those special circumstances may indeed not necessarily be related to the applicant for the dissolution of marriage or the other party. I have left it open-ended so as to ensure that the Family Court judge could decide on that particular issue. Otherwise, what could be done? What would Senator Reid do? Would she include in special circumstances such things as continuous adultery, and violence in marriage? That would bring in just causes. Does she want to do that? I am happy about that. If that is what she wants to do to amend it, it is fine by me. Let us not criticise this particular proposal by nitpicking in that way.

I believe very firmly that it is desirable to extend the spirit of reconciliation and consensus that is abroad in this nation and that has been declared by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to be abroad. Let us extend that to the institution of marriage. We have this spirit of reconciliation and consensus in human relationships disputes in the industrial area, the sex discrimination area and the racial discrimination area. The one area in which we do not have it is in the most fundamental area of human relationships, namely, the relationship between a man and a woman in a marriage covenant. The institution of marriage is the fundamental institution of society and if we have required conciliation and counselling in all other areas of human relationships, why can we not have that here? The argument about costs will not wash; the argument that it is too late will not wash; the argument that we cannot by definition have required conciliation will not wash, because we have it in all other areas. Of course we cannot force a person to conciliate. We can force a person to be there. Let me quote from an organisation involved in marriage counselling; namely, Centacare in Hobart. It has had this to say:

We believe that the approved community organisations should be given a higher profile in legislation, so that people seeking assistance in their marriages and family difficulties are made aware that other options for service exist. We have found that people can get locked into the legal system when their only assistance is offered within the court itself (whether or not court counsellors are housed separately from the Family Court). The opportunity to air grievances, hostilities and general marital discord away from legal centres can give people a broader view of problems and can open up possibilities for reconciliation.

TALK.START.PARA: —But these are not people seeking assistance.
—No, but in regard to this amendment this organisation said:

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment (Clause 5) changing 'may' to 'shall' can have one party forcing the other party into counselling. Whilst we have reservations about 'required counselling'. Agency experience indicates that unwilling counsellees can make rational decisions once initial hostility is appropriately directed.

That is from an organisation the professional business of which is in this particular area. I quote that in the hope that the Committee may adopt this proposition, and may adopt it in a free and open manner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Harradine's amendment because, as I expressed in the second reading debate, the time has come after many years of experimentation with the Family Law Act and the Family Court of Australia for this Parliament to have very serious regard for the way in which the Act has operated, in the light of the principles that the Act itself lays down and which I regret have been ignored by those who have administered it. Section 43 of the Act states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Family Court shall-
'shall', not 'may'-
in the exercise of its jurisdiction under this Act . . . have regard to-
(a) the need to preserve and protect the institution of marriage as the union of a man and a woman to the exclusion of all others voluntarily entered into for life;

(b) the need to give the widest possible protection and assistance to the family as the natural and fundamental group unit of society, particularly while it is responsible for the care and education of dependent children;

So it goes on. That is the major object of this Act, and it is the responsibility of the Family Court. Section 14 of the Act-I am talking about the Act that this Parliament passed in 1975, not the present Bill-

TALK.START.PARA: —The luxury of Opposition. Why did you not put this clause in your own Bill last year if it is such a good idea?
—The honourable senator should just listen to the section. This is what the Act says:

SPEECH.PARA: Where proceedings for a dissolution of marriage have been instituted, or financial or custodial proceedings have been instituted by a party to a subsisting marriage, it is the duty of the Judge or magistrate constituting the court and of every legal practitioner representing a party to give consideration , from time to time, to the possibility of a reconciliation of the parties.

As I understand it, one of the proposals before the Senate is that before any matters of dispute in relation to custody, property or maintenance go to the Court itself, they should be referred to a conference either before a registrar, if it is in relation to property, or a counsellor if it is in relation to custody of children. So this Bill, itself, recognises the need to enhance the role of conciliation between parties. Senator Harradine's proposed amendment, as I understand it, simply takes the procedure one step further and is entirely in accord with the philosophy and principles of the Act, to which I have referred. It has been a long-standing policy of not only the Family Law Act but also its predecessor, the Matrimonial Causes Act, to support marriage counselling organisations and successive governments over the years have done so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't we spend some money on it?

—Large sums have been spent on it. Certainly it may be a matter of debate that more money should be spent on the services of these organisations , but if there were a more specific encouragement or requirement for counselling to be undertaken then of course governments would be more encouraged and required to provide the funds for it.

SPEECH.PARA: I also believe that parties to the marriage should be prepared to pay to some extent, if necessary, for the services. Why should it all be provided by government? I could never understand the view that all marriage counselling organisations had to be supported and had to survive on only Government funding. Why should not people dealing with the most fundamental problem that they face in life be prepared to pay at least to some extent for this service? Certainly the Government could pay for those who cannot, but the majority of people could pay for it. If the Act were really serious in requiring the philosophy of section 43 of the Act to be carried out, or section 14 which places the responsibility fairly and squarely on judges, and if marriage partners could proceed under this Act only by seriously facing up to their obligations, particularly in regard to children, I am sure that people would feel the services provided for under the Act well worth their while even if they have to pay for them themselves. The amendment which Senator Harradine has moved seems to me to be very practical. It does not require that the parties appear before a counsellor of the Court at the time they-

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did you not suggest that while in government? The luxury of Opposition.

—Frankly, I wish I had thought of this. The proposal simply provides that the parties should have had the assistance of a marriage counsellor or an approved marriage counselling organisation. It does not say that it has to occur at the time the proceedings are going on. As I read it, it simply imposes a requirement on the parties to show that they have, in fact, faced up to this question and have had some assistance in it. If they had done so at the time they parted and it had failed to reconcile them the requirement of this amendment would be satisfied.

SPEECH.PARA: If further resources are required to be provided by the Court and if the Government is unable to provide the resources to enable people to receive immediate assistance, I do not think there is any great harm done in their having to wait a while or for them to have to organise assistance through some suitable marriage counsellor or marriage counselling organisation to satisfy this requirement. Obviously, practical problems would arise if one party disappeared and could not be found, and so on. As I understand it, the purpose of limb (b) is to provide that the Court can resolve an issue if it considers that special circumstances apply. That would be determined on the facts of the case. I think the second limb is desirable. It would provide a solution to that problem. It seems to me that the amendment is designed to give effect to the very clear philosophy and policy of this Act as set out in sections 14 and 43 to which I referred. The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) seemed to indicate that in principle he would agree with it, but he used an argument, which is familiar to me, that resources may make it difficult-

TALK.START.PARA: —That is pretty compelling.

—I have suggested that perhaps the time has come when people should be prepared to accept some responsibility themselves to satisfy these requirements. There is no reason for us to go on believing that this requirement has to be funded by the taxpayer all the time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Our committee of review received a considerable amount of evidence about conciliation and counselling. Many people believed that counselling had fallen down in the Family Court of Australia. Many of the counsellors who appeared before us were asked to provide figures on where they believed conciliation had taken place. As Senator Hill said, the cry from all of them was much the same. They said that in many cases by the time the people got to them it was too late, all they were able to do was to make the separation easier on the children and the partners and to try to cut out the bitterness. But in the majority of cases the counsellors told us that it was too late. They were very frustrated that they could not get to the people earlier. They felt that if there were some method of getting to people at an earlier stage they could succeed.
—This proposed new clause would not ensure that.

—I ask Senator Evans to wait until I have finished. I realise that it would not ensure that but, as Senator Durack said tonight, it would not limit it to people seeking divorce. The amendment does not say: 'You can seek it only when you have gone to your lawyer and are putting in your papers'. The amendment just says that some sort of counselling must have taken place. I do not know of any other way of altering attitudes in this country to make it acceptable, if one is having problems within one's marriage, to go to the conciliators, the counsellors. As I have said already, the figures which were provided tonight by the Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, prove that at the moment people's attitudes are that it is not acceptable to go to the counsellors.

SPEECH.PARA: We have a responsibility in this place to attempt to change that attitude. Can anyone in this chamber suggest a better way of changing attitudes than by saying to people 'There will be no divorce until you have had some sort of counselling' and by saying to the next generation 'People have counselling when they have problems; they have to have counselling before they can be divorced'? That is the only way I can see that we can change attitudes in this country which will, I am quite sure, eventually, over a period, help our divorce rate. We have to realise that about 400,000 children have been affected by divorce since the new law was introduced. In 1982 there were 44,000 divorces-that is, one divorce for every 2 1/2 marriages in this country. If we cannot introduce something in this chamber tonight that will change the attitudes of people who are having problems , by saying to them 'Go to the conciliators; it might work; give it a go', I think we are falling down on our responsibilities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment that has been moved by Senator Harradine. In this debate I follow eight honourable senators who, in the last hour, have taken up the issue of the public concern that there should be more attempt at reconciliation before the dissolution of marriage is reached in an attempt to avoid that dissolution. It is evident from what was said to the committee of review by way of submission from what has been put to us as senators by members of the public and from what has been echoed in the statements that have been made in our consideration of this matter today, that in the operation of this basically sound Act-that is, the Family Law Act-there is a great weakness in that there is not sufficient provision for counselling for reconciliation. Two objections have been put to the argument that I believe has been very well summarised by Senator Harradine, particularly in his second speech tonight, and also by the former Attorney-General, Senator Durack. He foreshadowed it in his speech at the second reading stage yesterday and, in detail, set out an excellent complementary speech to Senator Harradine's. The argument is this: The present procedures which seek counselling for reconciliation are affectively void; they do not amount to anything. Senator Durack summed up the situation in his speech yesterday in this way:

SPEECH.PARA: The Family Court pioneered this field and the role of counsellors is very important. I am not criticising it; nor do I want to be seen as criticising them . Nevertheless their approach was this: 'Well, it is too late at this stage to do anything. The parties have decided that they want a divorce and the best thing we can do is to ease them through it as painlessly as possible.'

What we need are better efforts to be made to counsel people towards reconciliation. This is not some attempt in this amendment to go back to some patronising, dragooning compulsion of persons to meet another bureaucratic step. It is not a bureaucratic step. It is a humane, neighbourly, direct encouragement for professional counselling by approved marriage counsellors before the full process of papers coming to the court for dissolution of a marriage are accepted and proceeded with.

Two arguments have been put. I acknowledge that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has in principle agreed to the spirit of the amendment. It applies to marriages of only two years duration. The exact procedure is in operation with regard to those marriages. It is workable for them and is seen to be of some benefit. The burden of the case that has been put by myself, by the mover of the amendment and by a number of us in the Senate tonight is: Why should not that procedure be applied to all marriages that are in danger of breaking down or that come to the court for dissolution?

If the argument is one of resources then I believe Senator Durack is right in saying that the words of the amendment allow flexibility as to the marriage counsellor. It can be any marriage counsellor or any marriage counselling organisation approved by the court. If there is a need for thousands of such marriage counselling sessions there will be sufficient professional persons in the community to deal with them and the partners themselves will pay for that professional service. They have to pay the court costs and legal costs in any event. Are we to expect that in the dissolution of a marriage-the most fundamental and important relationship that there is in our community-we do not make provision for professional services to be sought also by the persons involved that may lead to the avoidance of the breakdown of that marriage? I believe that the partners themselves should bear the cost of such professional marriage counselling. I know it is a farcical and trite analogy to draw, but the law of the land provides that persons seeking workers compensation must go to a professional person, a doctor, and pay for a medical certificate to show that they are suffering sickness or disability that will lead them to gain the compensation that the law of the land allows. I believe it is in a matter such as this, where the public is concerned, that more effort should be made at counselling for reconciliation in marriages that are breaking down, that this may well be a requirement.

My colleague from South Australia, Senator Hill, fears that it may well be too late for such counselling for reconcilation to be effective. I share the same fear that if 12 months of separation in a relationship have elapsed then there is a danger of reconciliation being too late. But if it is seen to be a requirement before the papers can be received by the court and if preliminary advice is sought either from the court or from a lawyer as to the eventual process in the dissolution of a marriage that is in difficulties, the parties will be encouraged, hopefully, by those persons to seek that counselling at an earlier stage.

In my mind the argument about resources does not stand up. The resources can be fully provided by the partners of the marriage. I believe it is well worth giving every encouragement to try that counselling towards reconciliation before it is too late. At least the principle has been approved by the government of the day in the case of marriages of a duration of only two years. It is seen to be of benefit to them. I maintain that it is also of benefit to other marriages. Therefore I not only support the amendment but also urge other honourable senators to support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I place on record my support for Senator Harradine's amendment. I consider that counselling for all marriages that are likely to break down is certainly very worth while. The Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans) mentioned the cost to the community. From figures provided by Senator Harradine apparently to date the Government has made available $50,000.
—Up to $80,000 this year.

—Well that is a big improvement. I suppose $30,000 might do a little bit of good for somebody. We hear of so many cases where after divorce husbands do not accept the responsibility of looking after their wives. The Government is then forced into quite a lot of extra expense in looking after wives and families that have been deserted. I guess that is fair enough, but I wonder whether it would not help the cost to the community and the Government if husbands were forced to take the necessary responsibility. I certainly agree with the idea of compulsory marriage counselling when we realise, as Senator Walters said, that there is one divorce for every 2 1/2 marriages. They are very bad figures and they do not speak very well at all for our community. I support the amendment that Senator Harradine has moved.

—I will oppose Senator Harradine's amendment for a reason which has not been expressed by anybody here tonight, and that is that paragraph (a) of proposed new clause 4D states 'for the purpose of considering a reconciliation'. There is a view in the community, which has not been expressed here, and that is that I do not believe any responsible counsellor would want to counsel a couple when he has a statutory obligation upon him to consider a reconciliation. Quite frankly, there are many marriages which should not be reconciled simply because of the enormous damage which is being done both to the spouse and to the children. This is based on a premise which is not accepted by a large number of people in the community-this view also has not been expressed here tonight-that there is nothing wrong with divorce, neither is there anything wrong with a marriage continuing. Tonight we have heard a covert religious debate. That is perfectly all right. I have a religious conviction about marriage-but I do not stand here tonight to express it. I stand here to express the views of a legislator. I believe we are doing a major disservice to a very large section of the community whose marriages should not continue because of the enormous personal damage that has already been committed.

—I take strong exception to what Senator Macklin said. It is nonsense to say that we are engaging in some covert religious debate. Does he suggest that the Attorney-General who has supported this proposal in principle, is engaging in some covert religious debate? That is absolute nonsense. I attempted to suggest that in the area of human relationships, where a clear commitment has been given, whether it be in a marriage, in an industrial relationship between a worker and an industry, in a matter between the sexes generally in regard to sex discrimination, or whether in a matter between white Australians and Aboriginal Australians, what is required of this legislature is that it give support to moves to bring reconciliation and consensus into the whole Australian community. I repeat for the information of Senator Macklin that that should apply to the most fundamental relationship in our society, that is, the institution of marriage. I have a good deal more to say but I do not think it is necessary for me to say it . While I have been listening to the debate I have been going over a couple of things which reinforce what has been said in support of this amendment. Time does not permit me to continue, but those matters are available to all members of the Senate and have been distributed.
-The Attorney-General has not answered my original question.

—That was an hour and a quarter ago but, because Senator Walters still has her nice voice on, I will do my best to help. As I recall it, the honourable senator asked me about what the Australian Labor Party would do in the event of matters that might prove controversial on a conscience front if they arose in the course of the debate. I endeavoured to tell the honourable senator precisely what we were going to do in the course of second reading reply. In case the honourable senator did not hear that particular exchange, I did read at length from a letter I sent to my Caucus colleagues. I indicated that if any of my colleagues at any stage indicated in relation to any amendement that they wanted it treated as a conscience matter, then I would seek an adjournment accordingly.
—What would happen if there was not an adjournment?

—I think that would be a matter for the member in question. The Labor Party has done remarkably well in handling its internal affairs without the assistance of Senator Kilgariff or anyone else. I find it a little tiresome to have to go on explaining that. It is something about which we have never been hypocritical. The way in which we conduct our affairs as a Party is perfectly open for all to perceive. I have explained the reasons why we are treating the measure in the way we are. I have also indicated that if any member of our Party does feel that a matter of conscience has arisen in the content of the original proposals before the Senate or in any amendment that might arise, then the Party would look at the matter accordingly and allow a free vote if the resolution of the Party was to that effect. I can assure the honourable senator that so far I have not had any request from any member on this side to treat a matter in this way, except from one member in relation to a clause that has been foreshadowed by Senator Harradine dealing with grounds for marriage. I think that that member will make his position clear in the course of that debate.

10.04)-I am sorry if the Attorney-General finds me tiresome. I understand that the Attorney-General agrees with a report in the Canberra Times because he has answered it to some degree. Would he not agree that what he is endeavouring to do within the Australian Labor Party is to take the matter out of the hands of the Senate and put it back in the hands of the Party?
—Do you believe everything you read in the newspapers?

—I will allow the Attorney-General to answer. This report is headed 'ALP drops conscience vote'. I am sure that the Attorney-General is quite capable of answering this media report. I do not think it is necessary for Senator Gietzelt to speak for him. If he needs assistance, then the honourable senator should go right ahead. Senator Gareth Evans, in his dictatorial manner, said in reply to Senator Harradine that he had initiated the action. The action to which he referred was the decision that if any person within the Labor Party felt that he or she as a matter of conscience could not vote with the Government , that person could not stand up in the Senate and put up a hand in a conscience vote. He or she would have to say: 'I do not like this. Will all the members of the Senate stand with me and have the matter adjourned so that I can go back to the Attorney-General and to the members of Caucus and ask whether they will change their minds?'. This is a very important matter, and the votes that will take place tonight and tomorrow--
—It is your problem, not ours.

—I know the honourable senator is upset and I can understand why. The Attorney-General in his dictatorial manner said that he had initiated such action not because he wanted to ram anything through Parliament but because he wanted to expedite an overdue piece of socially necessary legislation. That might be the Attorney-General's attitude. It might be his wish to see that a piece of socially necessary legislation is passed. But what about the senators in the Labor Party? The vote has been taken out of their hands because they cannot stand up in the Senate tonight and say: 'We vote against the Government's attitude and its proposals'. It is a pity that when a piece of legislation such as this comes before us-probably one of the most important pieces of legislation that has come before the Senate this year-the Attorney-General, the dictator, tells honourable senators on his side of the House how they will act. Should honourable senators on the Government side stand up and say: Please, give us your help. We want to adjourn the matter so that we can go back to Caucus and go down on our hands and knees and plead to be allowed to have a free conscience vote? What a lot of nonsense! Listening to the debate I have noticed varying degrees of views on this side of the chamber, occupied by members of the Liberal Party, the National Party of Australia, the Australian Democrats and the Independent, Senator Harradine. I hope that from these varying degrees of views some sanity will be brought into this legislation because we cannot expect it from the other side. Having listened to the debate tonight, I lean towards Senator Harradine's views and I believe the points he has made are quite good.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer--
—You are filibustering.

—This is no filibuster. I wish to refer to the amendment proposed by Senator Harradine, which refers to the desirability of marriage counselling. Proposed new sub-section (6) (a) states that proceedings shall not go ahead unless the Court is satisfied that the parties, together and separately , have had the assistance of a marriage counsellor for the purpose of considering a reconciliation. It seems to me that the point raised by Senator Macklin, and a matter of concern to a number of people, would be overcome if the final words of paragraph (a) of Senator Harradine's amendment, 'for the purpose of considering a reconcilitiation', were read as meaning 'for the purpose of considering the possibility and desirability of a reconciliation'. I imagine that is really part of the process of what is intended there anyway. It may very well be that there are circumstance in which it would be quite undesirable to encourage a women to go back to a situation simply for the sake of avoiding the trauma of a dissolution of marriage.

SPEECH.PARA: I spent some six years as the honorary secretary of the Legal Aid scheme. One of the saddest sights was to see battered women come in with little kids and ask for assistance for purposes of separation and for maintenance. Not very long afterwards, having been pressured by people to go back into that situation, they would return to my office, again battered, with wounds, with broken arms, with heads bandaged up and with all the rest of the trauma that results from marriages which are disasters-marriages to drunken, abusive, vile men who behave in that sort of way and who repeatedly bash the women and the kids. I do not want to see women pressured back into that situation. But I do believe in marriage counselling. I believe in the importance of it and I have for years advocated an increase in the funding for marriage guidance counselling organisations. I believe that a very useful purpose can be served by them.

I simply take the opportunity to say that I imagine that what Senator Harradine intends, and what people who passed this proposed amendment would want, is that the possibility and desirability of a reconciliation should be considered. I hope that that interpretation is adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I concur in what Senator Rae has just said. But I want to return to the issue of our procedure in considering whether we will adopt the amendment moved by Senator Harradine. In the last hour and a half there have been a dozen speakers. It may be tiresome to one or two honourable senators on the other side that there have been so many, but it is an important matter and I do not think other clauses of the Bill will be considered at such length. However, all of the speakers in the last hour and a half have been from this side of the chamber. Only the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has spoken from the Government side of the Senate. That, in practice, shows us the kinds of concerns that Senator Kilgariff has mentioned, that Senator Harradine mentioned earlier and that a number of speakers have referred to, are soundly based; that there is a barrier to Labor senators participating fully in a discussion of amendments to the Family Law Act.
—Is it not too important a subject to be scoring political points?

—I am not seeking, Senator Chipp, to score political points. I am seeking, whatever opposition there may be from the Australian Democrats or the Australian Labor Party to my speaking, the possibility of all of us in this chamber, having heard the debate, voting conscientiously on this issue. Is the whole hour and a half debate on this matter towards reconciliation in marriage all for nought? Is it already tied up? Let us consider the logic of the situation outlined to us by the Attorney-General. If one or two honourable senators on the Government side wish to support an amendment-for instance, this amendment-they will have to appeal to all of us in the Senate to adjourn the matter so that they can see whether they can persuade the Caucus to change its attitude and allow them to vote conscientiously. That may be fair enough.
—You would no doubt respect their wishes in that regard, wouldn't you?

—Senator Evans is appealing to us to allow his procedure to work. But anyone opposite who wants to vote according to his conscience must appeal to the rest of us to allow the debate to be adjourned in order to obtain that right . I believe that such a barrier has been placed in front of too many senators in this chamber; that it is not an appropriate way for us to debate on the Family Law Act.

SPEECH.PARA: I will sum up what I am saying in this way. Many of us on this side of the Senate are not convinced that there is a workable procedure which permits senators on the Government side to put conscientiously any objection to the course that the Government has already determined. I appeal to the Attorney- General, through you, Mr Chairman, for the establishment of a blanket provision whereby any amendment discussed here can conscientiously and directly be voted upon by any honourable senator on that side. In that way, we could appeal equally to all honourable senators in the chamber. We would not then just have honourable senators from this side speaking in the debate and appealing to honourable senators on their own side. I do not want to score political points; I want conscientiously to appeal to the Attorney-General to give blanket access to Government supporters to a conscientious and direct vote on each amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate quite clearly that I agree with the interpretation by Senator Rae concerning the desirability and possibility of reconciliation. It was for the very reason of the case that Senator Rae put that I put in paragraph (b) of my amendment the safeguard that there should be ' special circumstances by reason of which the hearing should proceed'. In cases such as those involving battered children, as described by Senator Rae, I have no doubt that when the affidavit is filed by the lawyer concerned, it will also include the point-no doubt made by the lawyer representing the applicant or the lawyer representing the other party as the case may be-that these special circumstances obtain and that therefore paragraph (b) should apply. To return to the point, quite clearly a reconciliation counsellor would be required to concentrate on the possibility and the desirability of reconciliation. I see no problem in that at all.
—Senator Peter Rae was just wondering whether Senator Harradine might be prepared to amend--
—Can't he ask his own questions?
—Senator Tate has not been here previously. Now, the first time he opens his mouth, it is to interject.
—I have been listening--
—Well, it would be a good idea for Senator Tate to be in here and contributing.
—Come on Shirley; you are doing very well.

—I thank Senator Evans very much for his solicitous comments. Senator Peter Rae was wondering whether we could perhaps amend the proposed amendment. I did not want the provision to be passed without the opportunity being taken to further amend Senator Harradine's amendment. That is why I rose to speak. I am simply giving Senator Harradine time to look at the wording of his amendment. I am not quite sure how long I will have to stand here. I wonder whether he is prepared to alter his amendment accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not see that there is any argument on the matter. The meaning is implicit in the words. If Senator Walters looks at amendment No. (3) proposed by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans), she will notice that is states in part:

SPEECH.PARA: (1B) An application for dissolution of a marriage shall not, without the leave of the court granted under sub-section (1C), be filed within the period of 2 years after the date of the marriage unless there is filed with the application a certificate in the prescribed form-
(a) stating that the parties to the marriage have considered a reconciliation, with the assistance of a specified person or organization, being-

It then lists those persons or organisations. The let out which is specified in the Attorney-General's proposed new sub-section (1C) is precisely the same as the let out that I have in my amendment, namely:

'' '(1C) Notwithstanding sub-section (1B), if the court is satisfied that there are special circumstances by reason of which the hearing of an application for dissolution of a marriage should proceed notwithstanding that the parties have not considered a reconciliation with assistance of the kind referred to in sub- section (1B), the court may-
It then indicates the action that the court may take.

TALK.START.PARA: —That only relates to under two-year marriages.

—Yes. I am saying that the principle applies. I am not much of a draftsman and I would be quite happy to incorporate in my proposed new clause the types of words which are included in that sub-section. I request that the consideration of the proposed new clause be postponed so that it can be redrafted accordingly.

—(Tasmania) (10.23)-I wonder whether the Attorney-General would agree that this is a matter on which time could be saved if it is postponed with a view to obtaining an agreed form of wording. It may be desirable to get that done outside the chamber rather than on the run.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly. I have no opposition to postponing consideration of this proposed new clause.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 9, page 7, lines 21 and 22, leave out 'inserting after sub-section ( 2)', insert 'omitting sub-section (2A) and substituting'.
(2) Clause 9, page 7, line 23, before proposed sub-section (AA), insert the following new sub-section:
'' '(2A) The Governor-General shall appoint-
(a) The person who, at the date of commencement of section 7 of the Family Law Amendment Act 1983, hold office as Judges of the Family Court of Western Australia; and
(b) any person who is subsequently appointed as a Judge of the Family Court of Western Australia,

as Judges of the Family Court of Australia, and a person so appointed may serve in the office of Judge of the Family Court of Australia notwithstanding that he continues to hold, and serve in, the office of Judge of the Family Court of Western Australia.''

The first amendment is purely a matter of construction. The second amendment is the substantial amendment. That amendment seeks to bring into the Family Law Amendment Bill recommendation 41 of the report of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act which states:
It is accordingly recommended that the Attorney-General pursuant to s.22 (2A) of the Family Law Act grant federal commissions to the judges of the Family Court of Western Australia.

Paragraph 7.31 of the report sets out why these powers should be given to the judges in Western Australia. There is already one judge in Western Australia who is a judge of the Family Court of Western Australia and who also has a Commission in the Federal Court of Australia. There may be more. Perhaps I should read paragraph 7.31 of the Committee's report. It states:

It has been submitted by the Government of Western Australia that steps should be taken to confer federal commissions on the judges of the Western Australian Family Court to enable them to participate in the appellate work of the court. The Committee agrees that judges of that court should be included in the appellate work under the Family Law Act.

I have had quite a discussion with officers of the Attorney-General's Department about this. I am aware that there is opposition to this proposal. But the Joint Committee felt it was desirable, as far as possible, that where there is a separate State court to which appeals can be lodged against decisions which may sometimes relate to State matters and sometimes relate to Federal jurisdictions these matters should be dealt with by judges who, in Western Australia, could also be able to sit on Federal matters. In accordance with the recommendation of the Joint Committee, I persist with these amendments because I believe they would be helpful. That was the view of the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is another one of those matters in respect of which the principle itself seems perfectly sound, namely, that judges of the Family Court of Western Australia should enjoy federal commissions although, I suppose, the point of principle could be made that it is a rather odd business, in effect, for Parliament by passage of a legislation provision, to be, in fact, making judicial appointments. But be that as it may, the principle has certain attractions. The problem that the Government perceives with this-it is a problem that was very much perceived by the former Government, as I am sure Senator Durack will indicate if he is minded to speak on this-is that there really are quite intractable practical problems. One aspect of that problem goes to the questions of comparative judicial status. The truth of the matter is that the Family Court of Western Australia has District Court status only in that State whereas the Family Court judges elsewhere are of at least Supreme Court level or approximating the status and level of judges of the Federal Court of Australia. That is perceived in a number of quarters to give rise to difficulties.

SPEECH.PARA: Another aspect of this is that it appears that it is not simply the commission itself that is being sought by those who wish to acquire the status but rather also a number of the things that go with that commission. There are financial implications for the Commonwealth if the full entitlement to cars and other privileges that accompany Family Court appointments-indeed all federal judicial appointments-are to be applied to the judges in question. It may well be possible to overcome, over time, these particular practical problems to which I have referred but it is not a situation that we have been able to solve so far. We believe that it would be quite premature to allow the very difficult practical problems that prove to exist in this area to be determined by an amendment to the Act. So while again expressing sympathy for the thought underlying this matter, I believe it is not something that could be accomplished by the legislation. Of course there is no barrier to the commissions being granted to the States' Family Court judges as a matter of Executive action under the existing legislative arrangements should that be thought desirable and should it prove practicable. So it is not as if there is some legislative barrier that we would be getting out of the way by this amendment. We are seeking rather to do the unprecedented thing-of accomplishing by legislation what is able to be accomplished in other ways but which has not, for practical reasons, been able to be accomplished so far.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the views expressed by the Attorney-General in relation to this matter. I think the amendment is inappropriate. It raises serious questions about the appointment of judges and the method of their appointment, and also it completely ignores the difficult problems that the Attorney-General has mentioned in regard to the structure of the Family Court of Western Australia. That Court has been created under the provisions of the Family Law Act, which enabled arrangements to be made with State governments for the establishment of State family courts to exercise jurisdiction under this Act. It was a major initiative of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act in the first place and of this Parliament in accepting the recommendations that this would be an alternative way of administering the Family Law Act. The initiative that the Western Australian Government took at the very commencement of the operation of the Act has been very successful. I think it is a great pity that other States did not take up the opportunity that was provided to them. The fact of the matter is that the Family Court of Western Australia is a State court. It has to fit into the structures of the Western Australian judicial system and, without going into any details-I do not have time anyway this evening to do so-I say briefly that there have proved to be, as the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has said, very intractable problems in fitting into the structure of that court commissions under the Federal Act. I think it would be, as I said, quite inappropriate for this Parliament to seek to solve those problems in this rather blunt manner.
