DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Death of Mr Benigno Aquino-Philippines: Human Rights-Excise on Grape Spirit- Radford College

PROCTEXT.PARA: Death of Mr Benigno Aquino-Philippines: Human Rights-Excise on Grape Spirit- Radford College

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —It being after 10.30 p.m., under sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight in my capacity as Chairman of the Parliamentary Amnesty International group to raise in this Parliament matters which I and other honourable senators will also be raising relating to the tragic death at the beginning of this week of Benigno Aquino, former senator of the Parliament of the Philippines who was killed on his arrival back in the Philippines. Remarks which I make on this matter will be supported and different things will be said by Senator Mason of the Australian Democrats and also by Senator Coleman. I want to say that this is a matter which is a culmination of many quite deplorable developments in the Phillipines. It is not just a sudden occurrence. We know that this man, who was at the time of his death still the Secretary General of the Liberal Party in the Philippines, was not a man of some wild or radical disposition but a man who, of course, came from a wealthy background and was well known in the Philippines. He had fought a valiant fight for many years, not only politically, to try to restore freedoms in the Philippines but also while in court. He had been subject to some very harassing experiences as had his family. He came back after a serious operation in the United States and, as we know, was killed upon his arrival in the Philippines. He was warned, of course, not only by Mrs Imelda Marcos in the United States that he might be killed if he went back, but also was warned while he was on the plane that it was likely that he would be killed on his arrival and that the person who killed him would be killed. It is strange that these things have come to pass.

SPEECH.PARA: We know that Senator Aquino has for years fought a battle against President Marcos and those who support his dictatorship. We know that in the Philippines there has been a gross betrayal of human rights for many years. One has only to refer, among many documents, to reports which the Amnesty organisation has made, and to its Amnesty Report of 1975 in which it set out the details of this man's struggle and the other conditions that were also taking place in the Philippines . Perhaps I can summarise some of the things that happened to Senator Aquino, who may well have succeeded President Marcos as President and could have, in 1973, if constitutional government had continued but of course it was succeeded by martial law. He was a man who came from the Tarlac province of central Luzon, a traditional centre for support for the revolutionary movement there. He held office in those areas. After his arrest, which immediately followed the declaration of martial law in 1972, he was charged with the murder of a local official in Tarlac, with subversion and illegal possession of firearms. The people called as witnesses against him were people who themselves had been charged with other offences. He suffered considerably in imprisonment and from the victimisation of his family and was of course in due course convicted and sentenced to death but was permitted by President Marcos, in 1980, to go to the United States for medical treatment. After that he was determined to return to his country to continue his fight for democratic rights. It will be recalled that when he was brought for trial, it was not under the normal laws of the Philippines or under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, to which the Philippines has committed itself over the years, but it was to a military commission and he had to struggle to vindicate himself. He continued to do that and to confront and embarrass President Maros. In 1977 he demanded that his case be transferred to a civilian court, but this was refused. When he was permitted to leave the country and have a serious operation in the United States , he might well have stayed there. He might well have protected himself but he did not choose to do so and he made it clear that he was intending to come back. He must, of course, have known and did know, the dangers that he was facing. He must have known-of course he knew-the background of violence which has accompanied President Marcos. In fact President Marcos first came to national notice, and this was pointed out in the Sydney Morning Herald yesterday, in the late 1930s when he was convicted of the murder of the candidate who defeated his father for Congress. The winning candidate had been shot brushing his teeth, and when Mr Marcos ran for President 30 years later, oppositions rallies waved thousands of toothbrushes as a reminder. Therefore, there has been this record of violence in the country. We know that in the present state of politics, with the President declining in health, that there are factions and the faction that supports Mrs Marcos is largely led by General Ver and he and his troops controlled the airport at which the assassination took place. It has been said in an article in the Sydney Morning Herald which Alfred McCoy wrote yesterday that he would have been all right once out of the airport, that he would then have been under the protection of the other faction and beyond General Ver's reach. I do not go into the details, with which we are all familiar as to the way he met his death. We know that there are the gravest doubts as to whether this was an accidental or individual action. I do not know who the person was.

TALK.START.PARA: —It certainly was not accidental.

—It was certainly not accidental, but I mean accidental in the sense that an individual gets through all the security of the airport and manages to kill him. There are witnesses who say they saw the troops actually firing and striking down Aquino. As the Sydney Morning Herald said, we do not know who killed him or the circumstances of the person who killed him. But, of course, dead men tell no tales as they say, and that man was shot straight away. I do not speak of this just because of the death of this man. I remind honourable senators of the fact that there have been the most recent and gruesome reports of the activities of the Marcos regime in the Philippines. I draw the attention of honourable senators to the report of an Amnesty International mission to the Republic of the Philippines dated 11-28 November 1981. In that report Amnesty set out in very graphic detail the way in which so many other people in the Philippines are being treated at the moment. It refers to the extent to which the various rights of the people have been denied. Many examples are given of deaths and disappearances of political opponents in the Philippines and of the complete abolition of the rule of law. There is also the detention of many people without any charge whatsoever being made.

SPEECH.PARA: It is necessary for all of us who are democrats to stand up and be counted when something like this happens. We must not allow this type of dramatic death of a democrat who really stood for three major things in the Philippines. He believed strongly in a free Press, which the Philippines does not have. He stood for an independent judiciary, which that country surely does not now have, and for a parliament which, of course, has entirely gone. He was drawing around him support from people who took similar causes to heart. I believe it was to remove this idealistic but very practical leadership that this man's life was destroyed . There has been a cynical leadership of the Philippines. Last year when I was in Lagos with the Inter-Parliamentary Union I sat in a drafting committee with one of the Philippine delegates. He was very hot and strong on civil rights and helped me draft resolutions which upset the Russian and other delegates. I could not help thinking what a shame it was that his excellent command of these ideas was not translated in some way into the legislation and activity of his country.

We are to be concerned with the future. We are to be concerned with what we can do to highlight the activities in the Philippines which need to be changed. We must be concerned that our ally, the United States of America, should be firm likewise. It has a considerable strength and ability to influence the Philippines. I hope that the President of the United States will not visit that country as planned. I read that he is now doubting whether he should make his anticipated visit to the Philippines. Last year President Marcos was welcomed in the United States and returned to his country and put more people into prison. It is important for the United States too to stand up and be counted in this situation.

John Dowd, the President in Australia of the International Commission of Jurists, in the last few days has said that there is a need for an international inquiry into this killing, into how it happened and into what the situation is. I believe that would be excellent. It ought to be pressed by us and by others. People often will say: 'Oh, you cannot interfere with the internal affairs of other countries'. We in the Amnesty organisation never accept that when matters of human liberty, victimisation, death and disappearances are concerned. We will not accept that we can stand by and ignore these things. We will not stand by just because we have important trading relations with a particular country. I believe that it is very important that the Government, the Parliament and its members exercise every influence they can to ensure that these facts are known, that every effort is made to turn the Philippines away from this path of oppression and that the sacrifice and loss of Benigno Aquino will not have been suffered in vain.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I felt it important as a senator in this Parliament, as a long time member of the parliamentary group of Amnesty International and as a person who has raised the subject of human rights, particularly in the Philippines, many times in this place, to express my concern at the death-I suppose one could say the untimely death, but that is not quite the phrase I am looking for-of Benigno Aquino of the Philippines. I believe we are speaking for all honourable senators in this chamber and indeed for all members of parliament when we say how deeply concerned we are about his death and particularly about the manner in which he died. We have to recognise that it was only recently that Benigno Aquino determined to return to the Philippines and fight to bring the country back to what he thought was a democratic situation.

SPEECH.PARA: The whole affair of his arrival has that air of suspicion about it which I am sure has been raised in everybody's mind. There are a number of questions that a lot of us would like to have answered. Some two days before he arrived an assurance was given, at least to the leader of his party, about the security of the airport. Yet at the very time he arrived he was escorted from the plane by armed military personnel and was taken, not through the normal arrival channels, but to an area where an assassin was able to get within 50 centimetres of him and to shoot him dead. Therefore, there are a number of questions that have to be asked and should be answered. For instance, we have to ask why his body was left lying as it was for the benefit, it would appear, only of photographers. We have to ask perhaps the ultimate question: Why was this one man so important that he could not be allowed to communicate with his people in his own country? The answer to that, of course, is that he was the one person who perhaps could have led that country to a democratic situation. The editorial in the Age on 23 August puts it very well. It reads:
Whether the Marcos Government likes it or not, there is about this affair an aura of conspiracy and orchestration which only a completely open and honest inquiry will dispel.
3It continues:

If Mr Aquino's death could have one positive effect it would be to convince the Americans that they must speak and act clearly and consistently against self- aggrandisement of a sinister and destructive form. That, after all, is what the defence of democracy is supposed to be about. Mr Aquino knew it, and it cost him his life.

The editorial also mentions the comments of President Reagan in relation to the Philippines, when he said that great progress had been made in the area of human rights in that country since martial law was lifted. I think it was Vice- President Bush who complimented the present regime's adherence to democratic processes. The editorial warns that the whole attitude of other countries must be reviewed in the light of recent events. I believe that Australia has to review its attitude to the Philippines in the light of those recent events.

As I said earlier, I have spoken about human rights in the Philippines many times. The last occasion on which I raised the issue in this place was 4 May when I spoke about a lay preacher in the Philippines in the area of Davao, Mindanao. I spoke about Karl Gasper who was working with a Christian development centre. I had been advised that he had been arrested without having committed a crime, that we were aware of, and that he was to stand trial. The advice that I had at that time was that he was being permitted to receive his family and that he was being represented by counsel at his trial. I expressed my concern at that time that the counsel had not been selected by him or by his family but had been appointed by his prosecutor, by the Government itself. I said then that I was concerned that I was unable to get any information on his whereabouts even through people from all over Australia who were involved in church movements, in Christian movements, were expressing concern to the Philippine Embassy that we were unable to find out any information at all. It would not advise us whether he had been arrested, where he was being held or whether we could communicate with him. It was through the Department of Foreign Affairs that I eventually found where he was being held. Through Mr Cyril Gare, who will be very well known to all Western Australian senators, I received a communication that I want to read into the Hansard because I believe it is important. It shows exactly what is happening in the Philippines at the moment as far as human rights, or the lack of them, is concerned. The communication was written by Karl Gasper on 8 June 1983 from the Davao Metro Discom Detention Center in Davao City. I received it on 12 June. This is the first opportunity I have had to bring it to the attention of honourable senators. The letter states:
Dear Friends,

Greetings of peace! Here comes another letter from prison on my 75th day of detention. Today I celebrate my birthday with friends and co-detainees. It is a rather unique setting for celebrations. One can't really be fully happy, given the situation of the political detainees here and our loss of freedom (although one can console himself with the thought that there really isn't that much freedom out there anyway.)

Our situation has worsened since I last wrote. There hasn't been any improvement in any way. We've had two very distinguished visitors lately, Atty. Cesar Europa, the President of the Davao Chapter of the Integrated Bar Association; and Mrs. Tan-Gatue, the wife of the PC/INP regional Command. Both asked for feedback on our condition and both listened to our complaints. Our relatives have followed up on our petitions. Despite all these, nothing has been done by the military authorities to respond to our demands.

In fact just a few days ago, they added new rulings. No tape recorders are to be allowed inside the cells, since supposedly these are used to play ' revolutionary songs' and for receiving/sending out communications. We had no choice but surrender the source of news, our contact with the outside world, and the music that compensates for the tediousness of life behind bars. Last Sunday, they were going to take away our guitars. We fought back and managed to hold on to our only remaining source of music. There seems to be a conspiracy to take away our music, our songs. They don't want us 'to sing songs'.
The 'bunlot' practice has claimed another victim. The poem below is about him, and is a cry of despair.

I think it is important to read the poem because it talks about all of the things that we are discussing here tonight and it tells how they happen in places like the Philippines. The poem is entitled Still another detainee salvaged. It reads:
We heard he was padlocked
All alone by himself
In the bartolina
On a Sunday
We didn't know who he was
Where he came from
Why he was arrested
And on what day
We all knew intuitively
That he needed urgent help
There could be further torture
If there was delay
We couldn't do anything else
But pass the word outside
Help! send a lawyer!
Ora mismo! today!
Sunday and Monday passed
No relatives and lawyer came
But he was finally surfaced
On the third day
He was brought out in the sun
A figure straight from el greco
Gaunt, thin, soulful eyes
Half-dead, that Tuesday
We embraced him with our eyes
Saw the wound on he forehead
Blood was still oozing out
Then, they took him away
Again, the bastards took him away
Haven't they extracted everything
From Him? So why go on?
He's practically dead anyway
Like Lazarus he came out of the tomb
But in the light, there wasn't
Much promise of joy
For us, that Tuesday
Wednesday, Thursday passed
We didn't see him anymore
We wanted to know where he was
But there was no way
Friday night, word came in a whisper
He is no longer in prison
At 2:00 o'clock that afternoon
They brought him to a place far away
Is he alive? or is he dead?
No one knows among us
As he disappeared, we couldn't
Do anything, but pray.
Then he adds the final verse:
A day after I wrote this poem
Word came from a detainee
He said he saw him inside a Fiera
There his dead body lay.
He continued:

Since I last wrote three detainees have joined us. Two were spared the pain of torture, but the third went through the works. He was isolated from the other detainees for a week, and surfaced only the other night.

There have been some joys in the past week. Two detainees were released. Both were victims of the brutal dehumanization of torture. One lost his sanity and the other ended up with a broken back. We all celebrated their release. Still we have some really sick people here inside.

The coming of the rains is also very much joyfully welcomed not only because the peasants can now plant, but also because our cells are a little cooler when it rains. There are bursts of creativity in the cells as detainees learn to paint, do art work, play the guitar. Our Sunday liturgies have become more meaningful and enriching as we continue to be joined by relatives and friends who share their songs and prayers. Friendships deepen as detainees get to know each other and there are many inspiring moments as detainees reach out to one another to provide solace and comfort, consolation and encouragement.

Day after tomorrow I will appear before the Regional Trial Court, 11th Judicial Region, Branch IX here in Davao City with my case No. 9198 for Inciting to Rebellion. Like the cases of the other detainees, this one might just drag on for months. The witnesses of the military have a bad habit of not appearing at trial hearings, which necessiatate endless postponements. As if by delaying justice, they can further instill fear among the victims of injustice.

Four days from now, we celebrate Independence Day. It is also the start of Ramadhan. We all look forward to this day, especially because it is a Sunday. All of us detainees will be all gathered together for Sunday liturgy. Perhaps we might even have a more meaningful liturgy, as we are preparing the liturgy ourselves. Since the event itself is very significant, one can foresee high spirits during the celebration.

It is very ironic that our dictatorial government will make a big show of this Independence Day as they did in the past years. But the irony is not lost among more and more people. There can never be a genuine Independence Day celebration for as long as there are political detainees. The blood shed by the heroes of the 1890s that led to the event of June 12, 1898 has not yet led to the birth of a truly free and independent nation. More blood is being shed and will still flow before peace and freedom will reign.

We are going to celebrate this day with a fast. Enclosed is our statement which we will read during our own celebration here, which explains why we are going to fast. We hope you could be one with us on this day. We hope to keep you updated on our fast as we go along. While we hope it won't take long before our demands are met, we are also aware of the risks we are going to take. Please keep vigil with us. Your prayers and expressions of solidarity will be greatly appreciated.

I end with a prayer which was on a greeting card from a friend: 'I pray for you constantly, asking Abba our Father to flood your heart with light, so that you may know the great Hope, to which He has called you, that you may understand, how very great is His power in us who believe'.
The letter is signed:
Peace, Karl

That is one letter form a political detainee in the Philippines. We have heard already of other matters that have been raised through the Amnesty International . I believe that until such time as the Philippines can demonstrate that it is really concerned with human rights, that it has a peaceful process whereby people can have justice delivered to them as justice is meant to be delivered and not in the manner in which that country sees fit, Australia should look very carefully at its program in relation to both trade with and provision of aid to that country as it should with any other country that denies people the right to dignity and humanity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak briefly on the same subject. I begin with two comments. The first is from Cardinal Jaime Sin, the spiritual leader of 38 million Catholics in the Philippines who, speaking of his people when interviewed in the latest edition of Newsweek, said:

SPEECH.PARA: We have been deprived of our civil liberties for some time . . .
The second quote is from Mrs Imelda Marcos who, speaking of the late Senator Aquino, said:
If he comes back he's dead.

Mr Aquino was no communist, no left wing extremist. Rather, he was very much the product of the right wing Manila establishment. At the time he entered the Senate in the Philippines legislature he was the youngest senator ever to sit in that place. He was imprisoned by the Marcos regime and was allowed to go to the United States of America for medical treatment. When he returned to Manila, as we know, he was murdered in highly suspicious circumstances as he got off the aircraft.

His death brings those circumstances of poverty, oppression and economic disparity in the Philippines that have been a cause for disquiet to so many people for so long to an outrageous, even bizarre pitch. I say 'bizarre' because I think the time has been reached where I would agree with Senator Coleman that continued normal association of Australia with the Philippines must now be called into serious question. I think we must ask ourselves how far we are prepared to go in concurrence with and actual assistance to regimes which prey on their own peoples, which use murder and torture to maintain a rigorous oppression and which force the bulk of those people into virtual starvation to benefit a few who are indecently rich. That is certainly the case in the Philippines, as any honourable senator who has been there will know.

Some honourable senators who might have been to the Philippines will have been to the enormously affluent suburbs of Manila, like Forbes Park, where displays of wealth are quite shameless when one considers the poverty of the majority of the people. When I visited Forbes Park some years ago-perhaps it is not the same now-what I found interesting about it was that it is a fortress. It is a virtual castle. One can only get into the place by passing barbed wire barriers, with guard dogs and armed guards on duty. The ordinary people have no access to it.

The whole question of the status of the population of the Philippines came to our attention again forcibly some months ago because of the case involving Perth -born Columbian priest Father Brian Gore. I have made a number of inquiries about Father Gore. I feel that it is fair enough, when one of our nationals in another country is accused of certain things, for us to check out the reliability of that person. Everyone I have spoken to who knows Father Gore says that he is a man of peace, a good man, an honest man and a principled man who is not moved to wrath or to action easily or quickly. Apparently he could not stomach the sight of what was happening to the ordinary people in his area. Ordinary Filipinos were being preyed on by the local soldiers. I heard from the Columbian fathers of one charming case involving a Filipino who had bought a jacket which had been cast off by the military and which still carried the shoulder flash. Soldiers came upon this Filipino in the market. They forced him to take it off, chew it and swallow it. I gather that that was not an isolated incident. Reports of similar incidents and of people disappearing are common. People being put in prison for no apparent reason is also a common occurrence. The attempts by Father Gore to draw attention to the misery of those people led to his being held on a series of charges which give every appearance of having been trumped up.

I think we must ask ourselves what we achieve by supporting such regimes. Those who say we must go on supporting them-and of course, there are those who say that-are ignoring the plain history of the last four decades. It was the counsel of that kind of person which resulted in China becoming communist and in Vietnam , Laos and Cambodia becoming communist. Support of the privileged autocracies, the Chiangs, the Suns and the Ngo Dinh Diems of this world led directly to that consequence. If we believe that we are assisting regional stablity by supporting such regimes we are deluding ourselves sorely. It is not in our hands, of course , to interfere in the affairs of another nation. But, by the same token, we should not encourage what is plainly wrong and what are clear and repeated breaches of what should be fundamental to human rights.

I ask the Government to act responsibly in this matter, in regard to our relationship with the Philippines now, and to realise that acting responsibly and acting cynically are not the same thing. The world is going through a phase in which the number of democracies reduces year by year. I cannot see that a cynical view of humanity, as representing so many counters in a power game to the exclusion of all other factors, is responsible or wise. Oppressed societies can be pushed only so far. That is also the lesson of the last four decades. If we support those oppressive regimes and find them replaced by something we like even less we will have only ourselves to thank.

The Aquino killing seems to me to have been a blatant intrusion on the political process of the Philippines and, indeed, of the world. It could hardly have been cruder or more brutal. If that is the sort of world we want then so be it but, if not, we will have to apply every effort we can to change it. We should not dissemble, should not try to disguise or cloak the disapproval and disgust we feel, and feel reasonably. I think we should express these views. The more of us who express these views, and the sooner we do so, the better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address myself briefly to the same matter. I am indebted to those honourable senators who have already raised this question in the adjournment debate. I say to those who have raised it that it is necessary for us to address the matter again at a time when a substantial debate can take place during the normal hours of the Senate. The matter which has been raised is of considerable concern or should be to the whole of the Senate and, in fact, to the nation. I have stated recently that what is emerging to the north of us is a military fascism which we cannot tolerate. What happened in the Philipines underlines and emphasises that very fact. This thuggery is apparent not only in the Philippines but also in Indonesia and now in Sri Lanka. We should be taking a very firm stand against it. I am certain that if the matter is raised-as it should be-as a matter of public importance, the ensuing debate on both sides of the chamber will show the concern that we have about what is occurring to the north of us.

SPEECH.PARA: I have before me some figures which indicate that we give considerable aid, including military aid, to the countries which I have mentioned. In fact, we train personnel. It is possible that the person who was responsible for the assassination may have been trained in methods of military oppression by Australia. The numbers of foreign troops trained in Australia are as follows: Papua New Guinea, 197; Indonesia, 91; Malaysia, 415; Singapore, 73; and Thailand , 110. Some 119 Filipino personnel were trained in this country last year. For what reason were they trained? They have been trained in this country and given aid by this country to be used against their own populations, in order to oppress and deprive.

Aid is given also to other countries although perhaps at a lower level. Aid is given to Sri Lanka. In Sri Lanka at the present time the Tamul people are persecuted and slaughtered. People are dying by the thousands. In the streets of Jakarta, possibly as a result of aid that we have given, training that we have given and arms that we have supplied, many are dying. It could be argued-it is argued by the Indonesians-that such action is directed against criminals. But who defines who are the criminals? It seems to me that in the Philippines the criminals are those who politically oppose the government of the day.

I will not speak much longer on this matter. I wish merely to express my concern and add it to the concern of others. I suggest that at an opportune time we should engage in a full debate which will indicate to the people in those countries who are in responsible positions that we will not condone such action. I think it is important that the Senate express that view. It is important that we should express to the Indonesians the view that we are not prepared to appease such thuggery. We should express to the Government of the Philippines also the view that we are not prepared to appease such thuggery in that country. We should now look at what is happening in Sri Lanka and say to that country: ' We are not prepared to appease and to condone such thuggery'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise another subject which is of some concern in my State. It relates to the announcement last night of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) of the imposition of excise on grape spirit used in fortifying wine at the rate of $2.50 per litre of alcohol. It should be noted that in fact, due to the Government's decision to index excises, the actual rate to apply immediately is $2.61 per litre of alcohol. To say that this has caused concern amongst winemakers in South Australia is a gross understatement. Their concern obviously is justified. In placing a tax on wine the Government has chosen the worst possible option and the one that is likely to do most damage to sections of the industry. The Government has chosen to place an excise on grape spirit, which is basically a raw material used in the manufacture of certain wine products, for instance, sherries, ports and muscats.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the winter recess South Australians constantly heard talk about the possible imposition of a general tax on all wines. I think it is not overstating the case to say that all South Australians viewed that proposal with a great deal of concern as they recognised the importance to South Australia of the wine industry. That is particularly important at the moment when the economy of the State is in such disorder. Over that period various State and Federal Ministers and some South Australian Federal Labor members ran around the State assuring everybody that this action would not occur. Indeed, one can well remember that at the pre-election meeting at McLaren Vale the now Minister for Primary Industry, Mr John Kerin, definitively stated:
The industry will welcome Labor's pledge not to contemplate a wine tax.

There we have it. One wonders what the Australian Labor Party would have dreamt up had it turned its mind to it. Even as late as July, in the Riverland area of South Australia, Senator Bolkus confidently predicted that no wine tax would be imposed. Those assurances have proven absolutely worthless and we now have an excise imposed on the most important part of the industry. I would like to explain to the Senate why it is such an important part. The grape industry in South Australia is subject to surpluses and shortages in the same way as most primary production is. It is a tradition in the industry that in years of surplus wine makers take in the surplus grapes and press them for spirit to be used in the manufacture of brandy and/or fortified wines in later times when there may be shortages. The obvious result is that this provides some stability in the industry, especially to the small grape growers who occupy small tenancies or properties in the Riverland and other parts of the State. It has been a conscious and traditional part of the industry.

The imposition of an excise is about the most iniquitous form of taxation that the Government could have applied to that part of the industry. The excise has to be paid within a very short time of the grape spirit being used. From present indications given by the department responsible for this matter, makers will have to pay within seven days of the use of the spirit. In other words, they will have to pay in advance of the time when they collect from the sale of the goods for which the spirit is used. Previously an excise operated, but not in this way. It was not paid until after the produce itself had been cleared for sale. The reason for that is obvious. Fortified wines require varying years of maturation. For example, good quality ports like Galway Pipe take 15 years to mature, and Directors' Choice takes eight years. By paying the excise at the time of the release of the produce, the sale proceeds of the goods could in fact be used to pay the tax.

But this will not apply in this case. The excise will be demanded immediately the spirit is made, not at the time the final product is made. Therefore, the Government will have use of tax money before the growers actually sell their produce. Producers will have to cover those costs and in many cases this may require financing for periods of up to 15 years, as I have just demonstrated in the case of ports. The cost of this will be enormous. I believe that the Treasurer, by stating that the Government was simply re-introducing this excise, was trying to lull producers into the belief that the old excise arrangements which I just outlined would apply. I would certainly appreciate the assurance of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) that my understanding of the facts as I have outlined them is correct. If he has other views I would very much like to hear his correction.

In 1981 and 1982, out of the total wine beverage production of 303,040,000 litres, fortified wines totalled roughly 52 million litres, or approximately one -sixth. This excise discriminates against regions within Australia, chiefly the Riverland area in South Australia, the Griffith-Leeton area in New South Wales and the Sunraysia district in Victoria. Those areas will be hardest hit. South Australia will be slugged the most by the impost because about 65 per cent of grape spirit is manufactured in that State. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a table which I think the Attorney-General has seen.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. That table is based on Australian Bureau of Statistics figures. It clearly reinforces the contention that the tax will bite hardest in South Australia, particularly in the Riverland area of the State. In talks with Riverland winemakers today, I was constantly told how they believed that this discriminatory impost would have a devastating effect on that area. For instance, one winemaker who used about half a million litres of alcohol grape spirit is faced with extra costs of the order of $1.25m plus the cost of financing that amount. At the rate of 16 per cent per annum, which is roughly the overdraft rate today, that will add another $200,000 a year to his operating costs. That starts seven days after the commencement of the production of grape spirit. Obviously this will have an enormous impact on the cost of processing and consequently will find its way into prices.

SPEECH.PARA: Given that some 9.9 million litres of grape spirit alcohol were used in 1981 and 1982, this exercise is likely to bring in about $25m in revenue. As I said before, 65 per cent of that will come from South Australians. If ever South Australians needed further proof that their needs are ignored by Federal Labor governments, they now have it. This measure will have a very adverse effect on the liquidity of the industry in the State at a time when the State's economy is in poor shape. The Government should examine immediately the way in which this excise is to be paid. If the method of payment-that is, seven days after usage- is to be persisted with then I suggest that the Government will need to look very carefully at the future of the wine and grape spirit industry in my State. I urge the Government to consider how it may develop an alternative method of payment of this tax, perhaps along the lines which have been traditionally adopted for the payment of excise rather than by a confiscatory method of collecting the tax seven days after the production of the spirit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, tonight I want briefly to canvass a matter about which I had hoped to be able to ask a question of the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) this afternoon. However, I was not able to do so. It arises from a report which she published recently, known as the Radford report, on the impact of Radford College on Australian Capital Territory schools. A committee of inquiry was set up for the purpose of looking into that project. The report was released by the Minister on 21 July this year and at that time she asked for public comments on it to be made available by 31 August. Subsequently, when it was found that volume I was not available in large enough numbers for people to study it properly, she announced that the time for public inquiry would be extended until 30 September. I understand that volume I of the report has been made available to only a limited number of people. One hundred copies were made originally and I have been told that a further 100 copies were photocopied and distributed. But that is still only 200 copies for a community such as ours which, I am sure everyone agrees, has a fairly high level of interest in education.

SPEECH.PARA: The implications of this report are much wider than that. In fact, I think it is of interest to people throughout Australia who are concerned about the quality of education in our community. From one point of view one might suggest that public comment should be sought and allowed to come in for, say, two months after people have had an opportunity to fully examine the report.

There is another quite disturbing aspect of the report. As I said, volume I was available in limited quantities. Volume III was freely available but that was merely a summary of the recommendations. Volume II has not yet appeared. I understand that it is with the Government Printer and is not yet available. Volume I indicates that one needs to read volume II to perhaps fully understand volume I. Certainly, one needs to read volume I to get the full implications of the way in which some of the recommendations are worded and set out in volume III. I think that many people would be very reluctant to respond to the report without having volume II available to them. I ask the Minister: When will volume II be available and what length of time will she allow for public comment?

Of course, we are interested in the Government response and we would like to know when it will be forthcoming. Will it be before or after public comment has come in? I think the Government should respond to this. I can understand the Government wanting to wait until it gets public comment but I suggest that the public has already commented. Last week two meetings were held in Canberra-one in the Albert Hall at which over 700 people attended and the other in a suburb called Florey at which over 900 people attended. I think that those two meetings said a great deal about what people think of the content of the report. It may well be that the Government will respond to that public comment and make an announcement quite soon as to what its reaction to the Radford report will be.

It is quite clear that the committee went well beyond the terms of reference in inquiring into the impact of Radford College upon the school system in the Australian Capital Territory. It was referred to at the meeting held in the Albert Hall the other night as a tyrannical abuse of power that the committee should have been ranged so widely. Certainly it has caused a great deal of distress and concern in this community among people who believe in the right of choice in the matter of education. The committee went beyond the question of choice in education in that, in part, it referred to technical and further education colleges and their future. As I understand it, none of the TAFE colleges in the Australian Capital Territory gave evidence to the committee or were even invited or given the opportunity to put in a submission. Notwithstanding that, the committee has sought to gather them up in this report.

The most important aspect of the report from the point of view of members of the public who have been responding to it is the question of the integration of non-government schools into the government school system. I do not think one could pretend that that was something which the committee was intended to do but , in fact, it did so. A number of aspects of that have caused great concern to the community. One of those is the local Australian Labor Party policy with respect to the non-government school system, part of which stated that an ALP government would establish procedures to enable private schools to integrate into a restructured public schools system. The local Teachers Federation has been very vocal in its opposition to non-government schools. I do not think anyone doubts that it wishes to see them wiped out completely. When one considers those two facts and a report from a committee set up by the Minister, which makes comments on integration, which this committee has done, I think one can understand why there has been such wide public response.

Subsequent to that we have had the new education guidelines which seriously attack the future viability of non-government schools. Again, that has added to the community's concern about any commitment towards choice in education. The link between the funding of non-government schools with the cost of educating a child in the government school system has been broken in a way which many people feel indicates that the funding arrangements for the future will be far from certain. I think that the Minister should make the Government's position clear. I suggest to her that she make her position clear in this her electorate. I ask: Will she denounce the integration of non-government schools into the government system? Will she denounce the Teachers Federation's attitude towards the existence of non-government schools and the concept of choice in education? Will she denounce also a paper put out in the last couple of weeks by the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority which, I must say, most provocatively at the very least, refers to the future of public and subsidised schools? It could refer to public and private schools; it could refer to government and non- government schools; it could refer to fully subsidised and partially subsidised schools; but to put out a paper entitled 'Public and Subsidised Schools' can do nothing but make this debate more inflammatory. I think the Minister should make her personal position quite clear on all of these matters so that the community knows exactly where she stands. A number of other matters are relevant to the debate. I think that I have ranged a little more widely than I might have had the opportunity to do in Question Time, but I have at least cancasseed and touched on matters which I think are very important and which need to be answered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of honourable senators have spoken tonight about the tragic, senseless, and indeed the sickening, death of former Senator Benigno Aquino in Manila on 21 August. In Question Time yesterday I made clear the Government's attitude to that assassination and I can do no more than repeat briefly tonight the substance of our reaction. Former Senator Aquino was, of course, a symbol of opposition in the Philippines and to the existing Government. According to a statement which was to have been released on his return, and which was subsequently distributed by his relatives, Aquino said that he had returned to the Philippines of his own free will to join the ranks of those struggling to restore rights and freedoms through non-violence. It is a tragedy indeed that his violent death prevented him from following such a course. The Australian Government deplores his assassination and offers its condolences to all those in the Philippines-not just Senator Aquino's family-who are aggrieved by it.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the question of aid to the Philippines, which was raised by Senator Sibraa yesterday in his question to me, and briefly adverted to by Senator Georges in his contribution tonight, I answer by saying: The Government believes it can best improve the lot of the people of the Philippines by continuing its development assistance programs. Poverty and under-development themselves are, in important senses, violations of the human rights of those affected. Senator Aquino was a man internationally known and respected for his human rights concerns. Rather than his death leading Australia to abandon its concern for the under privileged of the Philippines, it should reinforce our concern to ensure that Australian assistance goes to alleviate in some ways their poverty.

Senator Messner spoke of the implications of the grape spirit excise. I wish to not reply in detail to what he said but perhaps to put some of his remarks in perspective by saying that the effect on the price of a bottle of port, per bottle, is, on our calculations, less than 25c. As such it can hardly be expected to have massive implications for the industry. That calculation was supplied by my comrade in arms, the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh, whose figuring on these matters is usually impeccable. I am advised by him that one litre of spirit has 860 millilitres of alcohol which, at a rate of 3c per millilitre, would produce a situation as follows: Port wine fortifies with approximately 75 millilitres of alcohol-that is to say, 10 per cent-and, therefore, the additional cost per bottle, by virtue of this excise, is 22.5c. I am further advised by my colleague-no doubt, again, this is based on impeccable information-that if Mr Howard were still the Treasurer a 20 per cent sales tax would have been imposed on all wine, producing a result of around 80c being added to the price of a bottle of wine. Senator Messner would really have had something to yelp about under those circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is exactly my point and you missed it.

—Quite possibly, but the night is late and the speeches were tedious. The final speech to which I am obliged to respond is that of Senator Reid. In response to what she had to say about the report of the committee of review into the impact of Radford College, I am simply advised by my colleague the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) that she plans to table in this place volumes I and III of the report tomorrow and will make a short statement on the issue at that time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 22 April 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC) extend home loans to members of its executive and its staff at below market rates.
(2) Did the AIDC, in August 1972, extend a $30,000 loan at 3 per cent over 25 years to Sir Alan Westerman, the Chairman of AIDC.
(3) Was this loan secured by first mortgage over a house at 47 Tasmania Circle, Forrest, ACT, a house owned by Sir Alan Westerman.
(4) What other below-market home loans have been given to members of the executive and staff of the AIDC since that body was established in 1970.
(5) Who are the members of the executive and staff who have received such loans .
(6) What amount of money was loaned in each case.
(7) What was the rate of interest charged in each case.
(8) What period was each loan taken over.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Under section 33 of the Australian Industry Development Corporation Act 1970, the Corporation is empowered, among other things, to provide financial benefits in connection with housing for its executive and staff, who are not public servants. The effect of section 33 is to enable the Corporation to offer such conditions as are necessary to attract, in competition with other businesses, executive and professional staff of the appropriate calibre and with the required skills and experience. The provision of staff housing benefits is a common occurrence in the finance industry. Housing loans have, therefore, been made to executive and professional members of the Corporation's staff at an interest rate similar to that which, I am informed, is used by a major private bank when making housing loans to its staff.

Particulars of remuneration and any benefits provided to staff of private enterprise firms are confidential between the employer and the employee. Staff of the Corporation, I consider, should be in the same position. However, the AIDC has advised that no director or member of staff of the Corporation has ever received a housing finance package at a cost to the officer as low as 3 per cent per annum. In this connection I am advised that some documents available from the Titles Office do not accurately reflect the terms on which housing benefits were provided.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 21 April 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the regulations covering the discharges and admissions to hospitals in the Australian Capital Territory.

(2) Is there any special provision made for patients to be discharged for one or two nights under special circumstances, as part of a rehabilitation programme ; if not, have there been any such provisions in the past, and if so, when and why were the relevant regulations altered.

(3) Would long-term patients, such as cancer sufferers, those undergoing mastectomies and various rehabilitation programmes, benefit from special provisions for short-term discharge under special circumstances.
(4) Will the current regulations be altered to accommodate special circumstances as outlined in the above questions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The admission and discharge of patients from hospitals conducted by the Capital Territory Health Commission is not specifically regulated by statute.

(2) Yes, but not under regulation. The discharge from hospital of long-term patients for short periods is established hospital administrative practice when of therapeutic value in the opinion of professional clinical staff. This policy is currently in force and has been operative for many years.
(3) Yes.
(4) No, this is not a matter requiring specific statutory control by regulation .

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, upon notice , on 3 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Are students who are in de facto relationships eligible for independent status for TEAS allowances upon the basis of those de facto relationships: (a) if not, were students previously able to qualify for independent status in this way; (b) if so, when were the regulations altered; and (c) will the Government alter the regulations so de facto relationships are once again recognised for the purpose of qualifying for independent status.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: No. One of the decisions of the previous Government following the Review of Commonwealth Functions was that with effect from 1 January 1982, de facto relationships would no longer provide a basis for eligibility for independent status under the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme (TEAS). The situation prior to the Review of Commonwealth Functions was that students were able to be considered for independent status if they had lived in a de facto relationship for two years continuously or for one year if they had a child. The regulations were amended on 27 November 1981. There is no present intention of altering the decision.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 3 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is Australian foreign aid designed to be: (a) an instrument of foreign policy, or
(b) an instrument of economic and social advancement for recipients.
(2) How will Australian aid serve foreign policy requirements, as well as humanitarian concerns.
(3) What will be the determinant for giving aid if foreign policy requirements and humanitarian considerations are in conflict.
(4) How will the Government give humanitarian factors the fullest consideration if there are no non-government aid agencies on the current review committee.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government views the economic and social advancement of recipients as a fundamental consideration in framing its aid policies. Bilateral aid provided by Australia on a government to government basis, however, cannot be divorced from our broader relations with the recipient.

(2) and (3). One of the tasks of the committee established to review Australia' s overseas aid program is to make recommendations on the future form and direction of our aid with a view to ensuring that it reflects Australia's interests and values and makes a real contribution to the economic and social advancement of the people of recipient countries.

(4) The review committee is made up of people who bring considerable personal skills and experience to the task. While there are no non-government agencies on the committee, one of the committee members is a past Chairman of the Australian Council for Overseas Aid and also served as the president of one of the major non-governmental agencies.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry , upon notice, on 4 April 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Minister for Trade consider the introduction of a royalty or levy on the export of Australian pearls, by weight, to eliminate the possibility of manipulation of 'floor price' valuations in the countries of destination; if not , what alternative measures would permit Australia to better share the economic benefits of this diminishing resource.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The economic benefit to Australia from unprocessed products primarily sold on the export market is a matter which is kept under continual review by the Government. I am advised that the Commissioner of Taxation takes a close interest in situations where it is possible to manipulate the price paid for such products to the Australian producer or partner in such industries.

The Government is not considering a royalty or levy on the export of Australian pearls. The effect that any such levy or royalty would have on the demand for Australian pearls, its impact on the net return to Australian partners and the impact on our international trading relations would need to be carefully evaluated before the Government could consider taking any such action. The announcement by Australia's largest operator that it will be terminating activities would suggest that the industry would be hard pressed to survive imposition of a special royalty or levy.

In the event of price manipulation by overseas buyers being identified, it is open in the first instance to Australian producers to introduce marketing measures to counter such practices and thereby achieve maximum commercial returns for their industry. The success of such measures would be expected to be dependent on the supply and demand for pearls from time to time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 17 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: What are the names and addresses of all those organisations for whom payroll deduction facilities are permitted in relation to voluntary deductions made by Commonwealth employees.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Under the Finance Directions-made pursuant to the Audit Act-Commonwealth employees can have voluntary deductions in respect of- (a) premiums on life insurance policies on behalf of an approved life insurance company;
(b) approved Public Service funds;
(c) loan repayments and savings deposits to approved credit unions and permanent building societies;
(d) subscriptions for membership of an association or union registered as an organisation pursuant to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act;
(e) a hospital/medical benefits fund registered under the National Health Act;
(f) repayment of housing loans to the Defence Service Homes Corporation, the Department of Territories and Local Government or the Department of Home Affairs and Environment;
(g) rent of residence, furniture and/or appliances provided by the Commonwealth ;
(h) repayments under the Reserve Price Instalment Scheme for the purchase of land in the A.C.T.;
(i) national savings groups (not available through the Department of Finance ADP Payroll System).

In relation to such deductions by Commonwealth employees (numbering approximately 165,000) paid through the Department of Finance pay system the Department currently remits deductions to 47 approved life assurance companies; 57 unions/associations; 47 departments/ authorities receiving home loan repayments or home and/or furniture rental payments; 51 hospital/medical benefit societies; 11 Public Service funds; 102 approved credit unions and 55 permanent building societies.

Over all categories, there are some 370 individual deduction authorities. However union/association subscriptions are paid on a state basis, thereby increasing considerably the number of names and addresses stored by the system.

To provide complete details in response to the honourable senator's question- even if confined to deductions made under the Department of Finance Pay System- would involve the provision of more than 700 names and addresses. Given the considerable clerical and administrative effort that would be involved, the information provided above has been limited to the approved categories of organisations to which voluntary deductions may be made. Names and addresses of organisations within any given category could be made available to the honourable senator if required.

Information in respect of those payrolls not the responsibility of the Department of Finance (for example, those of the Defence Force, Telecom Australia, Australia Post, various other commissions and authorities and some wages payrolls) would need to be obtained separately.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 19 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Minister for Veterans' Affairs claim at a recent conference of the Vietnam Veterans Association (VVA) in Sydney that the former Government's record on the Vietnam chemical issue had been 'shameful'.
(2) Did the former Government establish the Vietnam Veterans' Counselling Service (VVCS).

(3) Did the former Government set up scientific investigations of (a) the health problems of Vietnam veterans' (b) the incidents of birth defects amongst the children of Vietnam veterans, and (c) the rate of mortality amongst Vietnam veterans.
(4) Did the former Government establish free treatment in urgent cases for Vietnam veterans and their families at repatriation hospitals and other, including country, hospitals.
(5) Did the former Government establish a 'fast lane' system for handling Vietnam veterans' claims.
(6) Did the former Government establish a committee of review of all repatriation legislation.
(7) Did the former Government enact legislation to establish a test for liability of the government to compensation on a basis common to all categories of veterans.
(8) Did the former Government establish a National Advisory Committee on the operation of the Vietnam Veterans' Counselling Centres.
(9) Did the former Government set in train the extension into country areas of VVCS.
(10) Did the former Government provide compensation to some 7000 Vietnam veterans.

(11) Was the former Government provided with a most detailed and comprehensive report by the Department of Defence on the result of an examination of some 20, 000 files, previously unlocated but providing significant information about Australia's involvement with chemicals in Vietnam.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 24 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister for Foreign Affairs attention been drawn to an article in The Bulletin dated 17 May 1983 based on authenticated Amnesty International accounts, detailing the horrible tortures meted out to prisoners and their families in Iran.
(2) Has the Minister received any information from his representatives in Iran, regarding such activities.
(3) Will the Minister ask his representatives in Iran to investigate this matter and provide further information.
(4) Does the Minister intend to take any action to seek an explanation of these charges from the Iranian Government or its representatives in Australia.
(5) Has the Minister considered taking any actions against the Iranian Government in the absence of a satisfactory explanation.
(6) Will Australia respond as a civilised community should, to actions which are such a flagrant violation of fundamental human rights.
(7) What measures will the Minister institute against the government of Iran in response to such contemptible treatment of human beings.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) and (3) The Australian Embassy in Tehran reports on a continuing basis the information it can obtain on the human rights situation in Iran. The Government also pays careful attention to information from other sources, such as reports prepared by Amnesty International, which can have access to information that is not available to diplomatic missions.

(4) (5) (6) and (7) The Australian Government has on several occasions made known to the Iranian authorities its concern at the lack of respect for human rights in Iran. The Government has made unilateral approaches to Iranian officials both in Canberra and Tehran. It has taken part in joint action with other concerned missions in Tehran. The government has also been active in the appropriate international fora, such as the United Nations Commission on Human Rights, to register its concern over human rights in Iran. In all cases where other countries fail to respect human rights, the Government will continue to take appropriate action in all these fields as circumstances warrant.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister for State, upon notice, on 24 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What research on the level of informal voting and the reasons for informal voting has been conducted by the Australian Electoral Office in the past six years, including research at the divisional level.
(2) Will the Special Minister of State release this research for public information.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) In 1979, the Australian Electoral Office prepared a document entitled 'A Survey of Informal Voting at the December 1977 Elections'. It contained a detailed analysis of the informal vote recorded for both House and Senate in all divisions. A copy of the Survey has been provided to the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, which has authorised its publication.

At the request of the Committee, a similar (though not identical) analysis was made of the informal votes cast in fourteen divisions at the 5 March 1983 Senate elections. The publication of this analysis has also been authorised by the Committee.

In addition to these national surveys, a differently based analysis was carried out in Tasmania in 1978 on the informal votes cast in the divisions of Denison, Franklin and Wilmot at the 1977 elections. Copies of the tables setting out the results of this analysis are available from the Australian Electoral Office on request.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 19 May 1983:

(2) Did TAA previously announce June 1982 and September 1982 as dates for the Airbus to service Adelaide regularly; if so, what has caused the delay.
(3) Why is the Airbus servicing Perth regularly, but not Adelaide.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —TAA has provided the Minister for Aviation with the following information in relation to the honourable senator's question:

(3) The nature of the Perth market is different from that of Adelaide and can more easily sustain Airbus operations, especially with the higher volume of cargo demand and greater proportion of premium class traffic.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 24 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Australian Government make a contribution towards the salary of a ' fraud officer' located in the Commonwealth Secretariat in London: if so, (a) what are this officer's duties; (b) what contribution does the Australian Government make to the officer's salary; (c) what benefit does the Australian Government receive from this contribution; and (d) has the Australian Government received requests for a further contribution so that an additional officer or officers may be employed, if so, what has been the Australian Government's response.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: An officer having special responsibility for commercial crime enforcement was appointed to the Commonwealth Secretariat early in 1982. This was in response to concerns expressed by Ministers at the Commonwealth Law Ministers' meeting in Barbados in 1980. The Australian Government contributes to the salary of this officer through its assessed contribution to the overall budget of the Commonwealth Secretariat.

The duties of the position are as follows: (a) Facilitating and promoting judicial assistance between Commonwealth countries and in appropriate cases with non-Commonwealth countries in regard to commercial crime enforcement and related matters;

(b) Developing criminal commercial intelligence and other intelligence bases between Commonwealth law enforcement agencies and between Commonwealth and such other agencies as may be appropriate and, to this end, in a catalytic manner engendering and enhancing the flow of information to and between Commonwealth law enforcement agencies from both official and unofficial sources;
(c) Gathering and disseminating relevant information with particular regard to criminal modus operandi, targeting and new facilities relating to combating commercial crime and related matters;

(d) Assisting in the development of appropriate training programmes, exchange of personnel and the publicising of existing training opportunities both within countries and organised by other international agencies;

(e) Providing a general facility for liaison for cooperation in combating commercial crime and related matters in the Commonwealth including in the area of international investigations, and in particular the development of close liaison with the General Secretariat of ICPOINTERPOL and other such international organisations;
(f) Facilitating and, where appropriate, conducting studies relevant to the combating of commercial crime and related matters;
(g) Assisting in the establishment of a Commonwealth Panel of Experts (as called for by Commonwealth Law Ministers at Barbados) and the servicing of this Panel.

The meeting of Commonwealth Law Ministers in Colombo in February 1983 reviewed the appointment of the fraud officer. The communique issued at the conclusion of that meeting indicated that 'Ministers welcomed the appointment of the fraud officer for a trial period to assist them to combat serious international commercial crime. They said that dramatic results had been obtained in just one year. The seriousness of the cases already referred to the officer, and the prompt action taken, had amply justified the initiative taken in Barbados. In order to consolidate the advances made, they requested the Secretary-General to constitute the post on a permanent basis.'

As regards the question whether the Australian Government has received requests for a further contribution so that an additional officer or officers may be employed, the Commonwealth Secretariat budget for 1983/84 has provision for the establishment of an additional post of project officer to assist the fraud officer's functions. The Finance Committee (on which Australia is represented) recommended the approval of the Commonwealth Secretariat budget on 28 June 1983.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications , upon notice, on 25 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does Telecom Australia use commercial debt collection agencies; if so, for how many years have they been used and what was the annual cost of employing such agencies for each year.
(2) Why was it considered necessary to use commercial debt collection agencies instead of public sector bodies.
(3) What was the success rate of legal action to recover bad debts in (a) 1981- 82; (b) 1980-81 and (c) 1979-80.

(4) Has Telecom decided not to take legal action against certain categories of subscribers; if so: (a) when was this decision made; and (b) was it because of the high cost of legal action and low success rate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from the Australian Telecommunications Commission:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Telecom Australia has used commercial debt collection agencies since 1 September 1981. The estimated annual cost of employing the agencies for 1982-83 is $770,142.

(3) The success rate of legal action to recover bad debts, expressed in relation to amounts referred to the Deputy Crown Solicitor or Mercantile Agent is as follows:
Recoveries Referrals Percentage
