QUESTION.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 1 June 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was Mr H. M. Loveday, MBE, Australian Ambassador to the Federal Republic of Germany in 1980.
(2) When was the Frankfurt Book Fair held in 1980, and did Mr Loveday make an official visit to that Fair.
(3) Did Mr Loveday submit travel and accommodation claims for this visit for himself, his wife and his driver.
(4) Did those claims include travel to, and accommodation at, Lindau am Bodensee.
(5) How far from Frankfurt is Lindau am Bodensee, and is it located at the border between the Federal Republic of Germany and Austria.
(6) How many days on this occasion were Mr Loveday, his wife and driver, absent from Bonn, and what were the total costs claimed, including vehicle costs.
(7) Did Mr Loveday, his wife and driver, travel into Austria on this occasion; if so, why and where.
(8) Does travel by an ambassador outside the country to which he is accredited need to be approved by the Department of Foreign Affairs.
(9) Was such approval sought on the occasion; if not, why not.
(10) Did Mr Loveday inform the Federal Republic of Germany's Foreign Minister of Foreign Ministry, of his proposed absence from his post.
(11) Did Mr Loveday subsequently take recreation leave in Austria; if so, when and where.
(12) Who decided the uses to which the Department of Foreign Affairs travel vote was put in Bonn during 1980.
(13) For what percentage of that travel vote did Mr Loveday submit claims.

(14) Will the Minister for Foreign Affairs now inquire into the financial and other accountability of Australian ambassadors on such matters, in light of his answers to this question and the Department of Finance Inquriy into Mr I. Bowden .

(15) Did the heads of the Department of the Treasury (Mr John Stone) and the Department of Trade and Resources (Mr Jim Scully) make complaints to the Secretary of the Department of Foreign Affairs (Mr Henderson) about Mr H. M. Loveday's management of the Bonn Embassy.

(16) Did a number of staff serving under Mr Loveday in Bonn make complaints ( including embezzlement) to Mr Henderson and his senior staff; if so, what action , if any, did Mr Henderson take to investigate these complaints.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Mr Loveday was Australian Ambassador to the Federal Republic of Germany from 1977 to 1982.
(2) The Frankfurt Book Fair was held in 1980, and on 9 October 1980 Mr Loveday made an official visit to that Fair. Mr Loveday also made an official visit to that Fair in 1979.

(3) In respect of the visit in 1980, Mr Loveday did not submit travel or accommodation claims for himself, his wife or his driver. Vehicle running sheets show that the travel on 9 October 1980 was to Frankfurt and Hanau, returning to Bonn on the same day. In 1979 Mr Loveday visited the Frankfurt Book Fair on 12 October 1979 and then travelled further, visiting the cities of Ulm and Fribourg . In respect of that visit he submitted accommodation claims for himself and his wife for the period 12-14 October 1979. A separate claim for the period was submitted by his driver.
(4) The claims for travel in1979 included travel to and accommodation at Lindau am Bodensee.
(5) Lindau am Bodensee is approximately 400 kilometres by road from Bonn. It is within 10 kilometres of the border between the Federal Republic of Germany and Austria.
(6) Mr Loveday, his wife and driver were absent from Bonn in 1979 for two days 5 1/2 hours. Total costs claimed amounted to Deutsche marks 1138.14 ($A581.88).
(7) On 13 October, 1979 Mr Loveday and his wife made visits out of Lindau returning that evening. During that day he crossed the border into Austria and remained in Austria for some hours.

(8) Yes, as a general rule. Where, however, the absence from the country of accreditation is brief as it was on this occasion, particularly in Europe where distances are relatively short, brief visits to neighbouring countries do not always require approval to be sought from the Department of Foreign Affairs.

(9) Approval was not sought on this occasion. I am informed that Mr Loveday believed the visit to be of such short duration, not involving his absence from the country of accreditation overnight, that approval need not be sought.

(10) Mr Loveday did not inform the Foreign Minister or Foreign Ministry of the Federal Republic of Germany on this occasion. I am informed that it is not a formal requirement of the Federal Republic that an ambassador notify the Foreign Ministry of proposed absences from his post. The Foreign Ministry does, however, expect ambassadors to notify it when they leave the country, because it needs to know who will be in charge of the mission during such absences. The Foreign Ministry does not expect such notification when an ambassador leaves the country for a very short time only, for example, a visit of a few hours during a weekend .
(11) Not in connection with this visit.

(12) The Ambassador has overall responsibility for the management of the Embassy's travel vote. In practice much of the expenditure was approved by the First Secretary (Consular and Administrative). This included expenditure on hire cars and taxis, meal allowances and officers' travel away from the post.

(13) The post's total expenditure against its travel vote in 1980-81 was $A17, 938. Of this amount, $A5273 (29.4 per cent) related to claims submitted by Mr Loveday. In 1979-80 the total expenditure against the post's travel vote was $ A19,365. Of this amount $A9494 (43.9 per cent) related to claims submitted by Mr Loveday.

(14) The financial and other accountability of Australian ambassadors is already subject to scrutiny. The Government requires that Australian ambassadors observe the highest standards of propriety and will continue to place emphasis on the Ambassador's management of financial and human resources in assessing his performance.
(15) No. Mr Stone and Mr Scully confirmed in writing that they did not make any complaint to the Secretary of the Department of Foreign Affairs about Mr Loveday 's management of the Embassy in Bonn.

(16) I am informed that no complaints alleging embezzlement or any other financial impropriety were made by staff serving under Mr Loveday in Bonn to Mr Henderson or senior staff of the Department. The management of the post was the subject of examination as part of the Department's regular program of review of posts. The results of such examinations are carefully considered and action taken where appropriate.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 1 June 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) For what period was Mr H. M. Loveday, MBE, Australian Ambassador to the Federal Republic of Germany.
(2) What is the normal or expected term of duty at the Australian Embassy to the Federal Republic of Germany of: (a) foreign affairs officials; and (b) consular and administrative officers.
(3) How many such officers resigned from the service or transferred out of the Department of Foreign Affairs having served under the Ambassador, Mr Loveday, in the Embassy in Bonn.
(4) How many such officers were withdrawn from Bonn prior to the expiration of the normal or expected term of duty, during the period when Mr Loveday was Ambassador.
(5) How many senior administrative officers served under Mr Loveday during his term as Ambassador to the Federal Republic of Germany.
(6) Is it intended that Mr Loveday be offered a further ambassadorial appointment.
(7) Was Mr Loveday offered the position of Australian Ambassador to the Netherlands, which was later withdrawn; if so, who is going to the Netherlands in Mr Loveday's stead.
(8) Did Mr Loveday's brother visit the Federal Republic of Germany while Mr Loveday was Ambassador and did he use an official car; if so, what are the full details of the arrangements made.
(9) Did an official car transport Mr Loveday or his brother outside the Federal Republic of Germany.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Mr H. M. Loveday, MBE, was Australian Ambassador to the Federal Republic of Germany from October 1977 until October 1982.

(2) The normal tour of duty in the Federal Republic of Germany is three years for Foreign Affairs officers and consular and administrative officers, with a period of two years for unaccompanied Fourth Division officers. These periods are often subject to minor variations.
(3) Of the officers whose posting in Bonn coincided in part or whole with Mr Loveday's posting as Ambassador, eight have since left the Department.
(4) Five officers who served the whole or part of their term whilst Mr Loveday was Ambassador served less than a normal tour of duty.
(5) Four senior administrative officers served under Mr Loveday during his term as Ambassador.

(7) At one stage in the course of consideration, which is still continuing, of the future disposition of senior staff of the Department of Foreign Affairs, Mr Loveday was identified as a successor to the present Ambassador to the Netherlands. In the event this was not proceeded with and the question of a successor to the present Ambassador is still under consideration.

(8) and (9) I am informed that in the course of a visit to various West European countries in August and September 1978, Mr Loveday's brother visited Mr Loveday in the Federal Republic of Germany. He met Mr Loveday in Hamburg, on or about 21 August 1978, where Mr Loveday was making a regular visit to the Australian Consulate-General and to various German business firms in the Hamburg /Bremen area. On 23 August Mr Loveday travelled by his official car from Hamburg to West Berlin where, in his capacity as Head of the Australian Military Mission , Berlin, he inspected the Berlin office and called on German and Allied officials. He returned to Bonn by official car on 24 August. Mr Loveday's brother accompanied him from Hamburg to West Berlin and back to Bonn, after which he continued his travel making his own travelling arrangements.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters, upon notice, on 2 June 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: What steps are being taken to alleviate the staffing problems in the Commonwealth Ombudsman's office which is causing a growing backlog of cases needing investigation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Office of the Public Service Board, in consultation with the Ombudsman's office, has been considering the systems and procedures of operation of the Ombudsman's office as well as its staffing structure with a view to identifying what adjustments could be made to improve the productivity of the office.

The study of methods of operation of the Ombudsman's office identified several areas warranting further investigation. These include the scope for an upgrading of word and data processing equipment to enable procedures to be streamlined and productivity improved. The Ombudsman's office will be seeking the advice of a consultant in further investigating these areas.

The Board's office has also discussed with the Ombudsman's office the latter's establishment, and has concluded that adjustments to the classification levels of investigator positions should help to reduce staff turnover in the Australian Capital Territory office and enable more efficient methods of investigation. The question of additional staffing is being considered in the context of staffing estimates for 1983-84.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 2 June 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What improvement did the Australian Safeguards Office recommend for Australian uranium mines during the period 1981-82.
(2) Why is a list of these recommendations not included in the annual report of the Australian Safeguards Office.
(3) Will the Australian Government continue funding uranium enrichment research at Lucas Heights.

(4) Does the Australian Mineral Development Laboratories research contract to study physiochemical methods of separating sulphide and radionuclide concentrates from the Australian uranium mill tailings involve the transport to Adelaide of tailings; if so, what quantity and how are these tailings stored in Adelaide.
(5) Have tests been carried out on samples of Caesium 137 found in Adelaide water tanks to determine their origin; if not, why not; and if so, what were the results.
(6) What will happen to radioactive parts of the HIFAR reactor of Lucas Heights which will be replaced during the five year refurbishing program?
(7) How much will the parts weigh and what will be the levels of radioactivity of these parts.

(8) What are the estimates of the amount of radioactivity that could be released in the event of a nuclear reactor accident at Lucas Heights, in view of the statement in the Australian Atomic Energy Commission's thirtieth annual report that estimates of the amount of radioactivity which could be released to the environment in nuclear reactor accidents are fundamental to the licensing and regulatory process, since they determine the restrictions to be placed on the use of land surrounding reactor sites, such as limits on population density and the detailed planning requirements for emergency response.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Safeguards Office (ASO) provided recommendations for improved physical protection procedures at one mine site in respect of a part of the plant containing uranium ore concentrates. At another site, it provided a specification for a storehouse to hold uranium ore concentrates.
(2) Recommendations are not included in ASO's annual report as their publication could compromise the effectiveness of security arrangements at the sites concerned.
(3) It is intended to phase down uranium enrichment research at Lucas Heights.

(4) The Australian Atomic Energy Commission (AAEC) has awarded a research contract to the Australian Mineral Development Laboratories (AMDEL) to study physiochemical methods of separating sulphide and radionuclide concentrates from Australian mill tailings. In this connection, small samples (totalling some 130 kg) of uranium mill tailings, derived from uranium ores at Jabiluka, Mary Kathleen and Nabarlek, were sent to AMDEL in June 1979 and February 1981. As AMDEL is an independent contracting organisation, established and operating under South Australian legislation, the Commonwealth Government has not involved itself in the operating procedures adopted by AMDEL.
(5) The control of radioactive materials within South Australia is a matter for the South Australian Government.

(6) There is only one radioactive component of the HIFAR reactor which will be replaced during the refurbishing program. This is an aluminium fuel storage tank which has low levels of radioactive contamination on its inner surfaces. After its removal, it is intended to decontaminate the tank.
(7) The tank weighs about 600 kg, and following decontamination will have negligible levels of radioactivity.

(8) I am advised that in the most serious case, a reactor accident involving melting or severe damage to HIFAR fuel elements (which is considered a highly unlikely possibility), the main health hazard would be that occasioned by the release of radioactive iodine gas.

The AAEC Regulatory Bureau, in its advice on HIFAR safety, follows the current recommendations of the United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC). This approach is also followed by nuclear regulatory authorities in Japan and many EEC countries.

Taking into account NRC recommendations, and the high standard of leak- tightness of the HIFAR containment building, the fraction of radioiodine which could escape into the outside environment is considered likely to be significantly less than one percent of the total radioactivity which could escape into the containment, i.e. no more than one quarter of one percent of the total radioiodine inventory present in the reactor. This would represent a maximum release of radioactivity of significantly less than 1250 curies. In such a hypothetical event, doses to individual members of the public would be very substantially less than the levels recommended by the National Health and Medical Research Council as indicating the need for urgent counter measures such as evacuation.

The NRC is currently re-examining its assumptions, in the light of a U.S. Department of Energy report which suggests that the release of radioactive iodine from a light water power reactor under accident conditions could be a factor of 50 less than that currently assumed for licensing purposes. The NRC conclusions are expected in mid-1984. AAEC scientists are also currently revising their earlier estimates of possible releases from HIFAR, taking into account this new information.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 3 June 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Resources and Energy aware of experiments being pursued in Germany to develop engines using coal dust as fuel; if so have these experiments been successful.
(2) Is any parallel research taking place in Australia either under the auspices of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation or any other body.
(3) What priority will the Minister give to research in this field; given the huge deposits of coal in Australia compared with the relatively limited reserves of petroleum.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. I am aware that a company in Hamburg, Germany, has claimed to have developed engines which use coal dust as fuel. Technical details of this development have not yet been published. Allied research in Germany and elsewhere is directed to the use of diesel engines of coal dust mixed with oil. Preliminary findings of this research indicate that satisfactory engine performance in the short term can be obtained by use of certain coal/oil mixtures as fuel, but engine wear is higher than when using straight oil fuels. The increased wear has been attributed to the ash liberated in the combustion of the coal.

(2) Yes. In 1981 CSIRO's Division of Energy Technology commenced research into the use of mixtures of coal dust and diesel oil as fuel for conventional diesel engines. The aims of the research are: to develop methods for reducing the amount of ash in the coal and thereby decrease engine wear;
to determine the conditions needed for complete combustion of the coal particles during the short time drops of the fuel mixture spend in the engine cylinder;
to determine what coal types and size range of particles give the best performance.

(3) Energy technologies related to the conservation of liquid fuels have been assigned a high priority in the 'Guidelines and priorities for grants' under the national energy research, development and demonstration program.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hearn Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 2 June 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: What Australian defence equipment will be on display at the Trade Fair in Kuala Lumpur in September 1983.
Which companies will be exhibiting.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

ANSWER.PARA: Details of the companies and organisations which have indicated that they will be participating in the Defence Support Equipment and Services Display, Kuala Lumpur, 13-14 September 1983 and the products and or services they intend to display are set out below:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 22 April 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do notices on traffic lights in Adelaide display a sign which advises members of the public to report failures in traffic signals by telephoning a local number 260 0400.
(2) Do these calls have to be paid for.
(3) Can Telecom operate reverse metering, or free calls, on this particular number.
(4) Is it possible to make a separate line available; if not, why not.
(5) Has Telecom advised that, as a matter of policy, such arrangements for free telephone calls are not possible; if so, what is the basis of this policy.
(6) Would a co-operative arrangement between Telecom and the Highways Department in South Australia lead to a more effective and efficient method of reporting failures and faults at traffic signals.
(7) Will the Government ask Telecom to review its policy in relation to this matter.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question based on advice from the Australian Telecommunications Commission:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Traffic and pedestrian lights located in the Adelaide urban and nearby rural areas and controlled by the Highways Department display such a sign.
(2) Yes.

(3) and (4) Telecom currently does not have a reverse charge facility for local calls to either a direct exchange line or to an extension of a PABX such as that mentioned in question (3). However an experimental reverse charge local call service is on trial in Victoria but some time will elapse before the technical and other problems associated with it can be overcome and a satisfactory service can be made available as a general facility.

(5) Telecom (General) By-law 53 provides that a fee is payable for each local call, the only exception being the 000 emergency service which was approved prior to the establishment of Telecom. The provision of free calls to other services such as traffic light reporting would invariably lead to many other claims from equally worthy causes. Consequently, a considerable loss of revenue could result to Telecom from such a development nationwide. The provision of such free services clearly would not be in harmony with the broad Charter of the Commission.
(6) and (7) Any co-operative arrangement between Telecom and the Highways Department in South Australia must await the outcome of the Victorian study referred to in answer to questions (3) and (4).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 1 June 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine analyse an Australian study on the causes of skin cancer in women.
(2) Did this analysis show a link between fluorescent lighting and skin cancer.
(3) Did this study especially indicate a link between fluorescent lighting and malignant melanoma.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian study to which the honourable senator's question refers was analysed jointly by workers from Sydney Hospital and the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine. The study was designed to test for a link between oral contraceptive use and malignant melanoma.

(2) and (3) The study did not examine skin cancer other than malignant melanoma . However, as well as finding that fluorescent lighting at work was associated with an increased risk of malignant melanoma, the study also found that fluorescent lighting in the home was associated with a decreased risk: only the former finding has received any publicity. The authors concluded . . . 'The findings should be interpreted cautiously until further relevant data accumulate '. The report has also been criticised heavily in correspondence to the journal in which it was published.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 May 1983 (Hansard, page 306) Senator Elstob asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice regarding regulations or practice about the disposal of medical records of patients in situations where a medical practitioner retires, closes the practice or dies.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:
According to information available at the present time, there is no Commonwealth or State legislation regarding the disposal of patients' medical records on cessation of a medical practice.

The overall view taken by the Australian Medical Association is that patients' records should be retained wherever possible. In situations where the practitioner retires and the practice is not sold, it is assumed that the practice has probably been allowed to run down. As a consequence, many of the records may no longer be active. I am advised, however, that as a general rule the Association would recommend that patients' records should be maintained for a considerable period because of the potential for their need should litigation be initiated for any reason.

With regard to Senator Elstob's suggestion for the establishment of a central register which would provide a record of drugs prescribed to patients, it is considered that the Australian health care delivery system does not lend itself readily to the operation of such a register.

The matter was examined last year by the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee which put forward a proposal for the creation of registers of groups of patients who have been prescribed certain newly marketed drugs. It is envisaged that the project would involve groups of about 10 000 patients for each drug. A discussion paper outlining the proposal was widely distributed to professional and consumer groups in May 1982 and responses are being evaluated.

It is acknowledged that, while such registers would provide a valuable additional resource of surveillance of the safety of new drugs in Australia, they would not record all patients who might be taking a particular drug. The creation of such registers would also require resolution of questions regarding the possible invasion of personal privacy and the maintenance of confidentiality . These issues are important elements in the Committee's current consideration of the proposal.

Fears that the Australian registers as proposed would be very expensive to maintain would appear to be borne out by recent United Kingdom experience where a proposal for a large scale, but not all-embracing, register to permit retrospective assessment of drug safety was abandoned partly due to the high cost involved.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 May 1983 (Hansard, page 676) Senator McIntosh asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice covering surgeons: performance of operations. I undertook to seek further details from the Minister. The Minister for Health has provided the following additional information:

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Health has no substantial information to suggest that this type of practice is widespread. However, in recent times the following matters have come to the Department's notice: One matter in South Australia involved referral to the Australian Federal Police of a case in which an account was raised for an operation by a medical practitioner who was not apparently present at the operation. It emerged that this was a 'one-off' case which arose because of a misunderstanding and no further action was taken.
In Queensland, inquiries are presently being undertaken into cases where accounts were raised for operations by practitioners who may not, in fact, have performed the operations.

Section 129 of the Health Insurance Act provides, in effect, that a person shall not issue a document such as an account for a medical service that is false in a material particular and is capable of being used for the purpose of obtaining payment of medical benefits. If, in the circumstances outlined by Senator McIntosh, a medical practitioner issued an account for the performance by him of an operation which he did not, in fact, perform, it is likely that this would constitute an offence under section 129.

Any cases of apparent medical benefits fraud which come to the notice of the Department of Health are investigated by the Department. If Senator McIntosh, or any other person, possesses information concerning possible cases of medical benefits fraud, I ask that that information be provided to the Department of Health.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, without notice, on 26 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Can the Minister representing the Minister for Health outline this Government's proposals for supporting worker health centres which provide such important awareness of worker health hazards? Can the Minister comment in particular on the Government's plans to have the hazardous material asbestos banned from use where alternatives exist and, where asbestos must be used, to have the process guaranteed to ensure worker safety?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I share the honourable senator's concern that due emphasis is given to occupational health and safety.

Workers' health centres-though not referred to specifically in statements relating to the Government's occupational health and safety policies-are regarded as State-based services. As such, they are the responsibility of the respective State Governments, though Federal funding is already provided to the States for these services through identified health care components of the general revenue grants.
Under the Medicare arrangements, the States will receive an additional $18m per year for community health services, including services provided by workers' health centres.

My Department has no jursidiction over the use of asbestos. The Department has, however, been actively involved in the development of the National Health and Medical Research Council Report on the Health Hazards of Asbestos. This report, published in 1982, contains detailed information on the health effects of asbestos and includes codes of practice on handling, processing and repair of asbestos-based friction materials; working with asbestos cement (fibrocement) building materials; safe removal of asbestos-based thermal/acoustic insulating materials; and asbestos and demolition.

The report has been distributed widely to Federal and State authorities, unions and industry. However, as is the case with other recommendations emanating from the National Health and Medical Research Council, it is a matter for consideration by the individual State and Territory governments as regards their possible incorporation into State legislation.
